150548495.review:
If you want a classic Mega Man game true to the NES formula then this is it . It follows the same structure , has the same core mechanics and provides fair challenge . I do have some pretty significant issues with it however , so let's get them out of the way first :

1) No replay value . When you finish the main campaign once there is hardly anything else to do afterwards , besides maybe replay it on a higher difficulty , but even then it's just the same thing but enemies take less damage from you and there are no health drops . There are no other playable characters , nor any extra stages , and the challenges the game provides range from okay (Dr Light's trials) to borderline stupid (jump saver).

2) It's too short . Really ? only 2 actual Wily Castle stages ? Thank god those are at least pretty fucking great (rare to see for a Wily castle !) . Well , except for the boss rush . Seriously game devs should stop implementing boss rushes to the games , it is one of the laziest ways i can think of to pad put runtime .

3) The shop destroys any challenge the game can provide . Easy , play a stage once ( you don't even have to beat it , just game over) and I guarantee that you will have enough bolts for 5 E Tanks and whatever else . The drop rate of bolts is RIDICCULOUS , and I can't tell if it was intentional , or an oversight on the development team's behalf (It doesn't even change on Superhero mode !!) . If you want to play this game and actually be challenged , do not use the shop . Or even ...

4) The Double Gear system . I know this sounds very controversial but honestly , I think the Double gear system , while good in itself , should have either been an unlockable on new game plus , or exclusive from the start to the easier modes . The speed Gear makes things a whole lot easier when it comes to platforming , and the power gear ... I actually don't really mind that one because powering your special weapons up is cool as Fuck . Thankfully there is a cooldown and you cant use it excessively , which saves it from being completely game breaking .

Mega Man 11 is a decent little game for old time fans of the classic series , and a pretty fantastic entry point for new fans . I know I sounded very negative towards it but trust me everything else that I have to say is praiseworthy at the very least . I think 30 dollars is a bit too much for what it's offering , but if you see a price drop absolutely get it .

150097649.review:
This game is supposed to be a celebration/revival/modernisation of classic Mega Man. It feels like an insult instead.

The art style looks unappealing and bland especially for a game which is only five years old, and especially considering the rest of the series at least looks good.
The music is hit-or-miss, when the rest of the series tends to have hit after hit after hit. (The Gear Fortress theme is good though)
The plot is bland and tries to pose moral questions with obvious answers while ignoring other actual moral dilemmas.
The voice acting is cheesy and campy but somehow isn't funny? I don't know, bad voice acting is funnier when it's from 1997.
You can't change your controls for accessing the pause menu (always P on keyboard) or the weapon select menu (always R on keyboard). I cannot figure out why.

These are all minor pickings compared to the gameplay, though. And the gameplay is tedious and mediocre, with boring & frustrating level gimmicks, confounding enemy placement, and barely used special weapons (aside from the Block Dropper).
The levels' lengths have been increased across the board, with each level's central gimmick being repeated multiple times throughout a level, and a midboss being in every level. This sucks. Checkpoints are fewer and further between than in classic Mega Man, and dying three times still sends you back to the very start. Even Mega Man 8, a mediocre game in its own right, had continue points to solve this issue! It makes the first few stages you pick very frustrating.

All-in-all, this feels like a much worse revival of classic Mega Man than 9 or 10 were, and I hope that a Mega Man 12 would learn from this game's mistakes.

11/10 garbage.

147594164.review:
[h2] INTRODUCCIÓN [/h2]
[code] [b] La Saga Clásica de Mega Man ya estaba mas que terminada, a posterior había venido la Saga X, la Saga Zero y la Saga ZX, cual seria la lógica de sacar una precuela de todo eso y continuar la saga Clásica del Bombardero Azul? No se pero a Capcom no hay quien los entienda, después de ser Anunciado en 2017, finalmente en Octubre del 2018 sale a la venta Mega Man 11. [/b] [/code]

[h2] HISTORIA [/h2]
[code] [b] La Saga Clásica no es caracterizada por tener historias súper elaboradas y este juego no es la excepción, simplemente Light retomo el proyecto abandonado de Willy (el Doble Mega) para que Mega Man pudiese hacerle frente. Si bien no es la gran cosa me gusta que le de alguna profundidad a la existencia del Doble Mega, como dato este juego actuá como una precuela del Mega Man 10 el cual acaba con la redención de Willy dejando las curas del la Roboenza. [/b] [/code]

[h2] JUGABILIDAD / MECÁNICAS [/h2]
[code] [b] Con respecto a este apartado los controles se sienten muy frescos y tiene unos controles muy cómodos y se siente perfectamente la transición de un Mega Man Clásico a este que vendría ser de una era “Moderna”. Un gran Plus en este juego vendría siendo el Doble Mega que nos permite tanto como ralentizar el tiempo (la Megavelocidad) o poder disparar ataques muy potentes con el Buster (la Megapotencia). Todo esto por tiempo Limitado debido a que al usarlo de manera prolongada se acaba sobre calentando y teniendo que esperar a que se enfrié para poder volver a utilizar. Por otro lado también esta la Tienda que no permite comprar Vidas, Tanques de Energía o Mejoras que nos permiten diversas cosas como: poder usar el Doble Mega por mas tiempo sin el Sobrecalentamiento,  que el Buster se recargue automáticamente, etc. [/b] [/code]

[h2] GRÁFICOS [/h2]
[code] [b] A diferencia de sus antecesores Clásicos de 8 Bits este juego experimenta con un 3D nuevo que esta bastante innovador para la Saga y permite tener un estilo único en la franquicia que se ve muy bien, este estilo Grafico hace recordar mucho al New Súper Mario Bros sobre todo al de la Wii y los dos coinciden en siempre en sus Sagas Clásicas tener un estilo 8 Bits muy marcado y en que los dos pasaron a este 3D plataformero que se ve muy bien. [/b] [/code]

[h2] PERSONAJES [/h2]
[code] [b] El Juego aparte de traer a los típicos como Light, Willy Mega Man y Roll, también trae los típicos Robot Masters pero que en este caso en lugar de ser los típicos Robot Masters que parecían humanos comunes disfrazados este juego nos trae unos personajes que se asemejan a los Mavericks de Mega Man X, cada uno con un diseño Único y Humanoide, junto a sus propias características que combinan con sus habilidades y/o diseño. Lamentablemente algunos personajes como Protoman o Bass quedaron descartados. [/b] [/code]

[h2] NIVELES [/h2]
[code] [b] Los Escenarios tienen un Diseño y nivel de Detalle increíble Ambientando perfectamente el lugar a donde estas ubicado, los mejores podrían ser la Excavación de Impact Man, el Parque de Diversiones de Blast Man o el Campamento de Torch Man, Cada uno se adecuá muy bien al Personaje al que le pertenece cada Nivel y se ve Estéticamente muy bien a donde esta Situado. [/b] [/code]

[h2] SONIDO [/h2]
[code] [b] Los Efectos de Sonido son de una Calidad muy Alta como tendría que ser para un Titulo de una Franquicia tan Trascendental como lo es Mega Man, junto a eso también hay que hablar de la Banda Sonora que igualmente es muy Buena, no es la que mas Resalta de toda las Saga pero no por eso es mala, cada Soundtrack combina perfectamente con el Nivel en el que se reproduce. [/b] [/code]

[h2] CONCLUSIÓN [/h2]
[code] [b] Este Juego es una Gran Obra que merece ser Jugada y es muy buena para ingresar al Mundo Mega Man ya que tiene la Dificultad justa para poder ser un Titulo Disfrutable para cualquier usuario tanto para Veteranos como jugadores Nuevos, Perfectamente Recomendado. [/b] [/code]

147214496.review: El perfecto Mega Man para empezar si nunca jugaste uno antes, ya que tiene para elegir dificultad, y cuanto más dificil lo pones, más gratificante se siente ganar, la tienda te da muchas opciones para facilitarte las dificultades más altas y el sistema doble gear se siente muy bien en usarlo. Las armas son muy útiles, cosa que en no todos los Mega Man se logra hacer, ya que siempre una o dos se usaba para los niveles y el resto solo lo usas contra el robot master debil al arma, pero en este caso todas son muy útiles. También los nuevos atajos con el joystick derecho para las armas y un solo botón para usar el Rush Coil son excelentes QoL que por alguna razón ni en fan games se pensó, lo que demuestra que se necesita que CAPCOM sigue sacando más juegos de esta larga y longeva franquicia, que aunque no lo parezca, tiene aún mucho jugo para sacar.

Good game! It's like classic MegaMan, but with modern graphics. Nothing groundbreaking new here, it's pretty much the same recipe as always.

Story itself is mediocre at best and the English voice acting is not very good. Music is decent. Controls felt good and responsive, at least it did for me. Level design was ok, but could have been better. Boss fights are primarily you recalling what moves the boss does and when. There's about 5 hours of gameplay, provided you're not struggling with any particular level.

If you're new to MegaMan, then beware that this game is HARD! New players should turn the difficulty all the way down, at least for the first playthrough. Some parts of the levels can be quite frustrating, requiring multiple fast and precise maneuvers while at the same time being attacked/pushed by enemies or while running from a death wall.

All in all a good game if you're a fan of the MegaMan series or difficult platformers in general.

142390976.review:
Mega man 11 is a brilliant game, a modern take on an established classic which is both brutal in it's challenge but also incredibly accessible to newcomers.

The formula is unchanged, you select which robot master you want to fight first and then run, gun and platform your way to the boss. It's a game that has felt the need to innovate since its debut back on the NES and for good reason, the gameplay loop is classic and the feeling of beating a boss and earning their ability never gets old. 

This game also brings new elements to the mega man formula mainly in the gear system, at the press of a button you can either increase damage output or even completely change the property of some attacks or slow down time completely. These are neat editions that compliment gameplay and you will need to utilise them in your adventures. 

The game does have a story, I didn't care about it at all but you might, I'm not someone who pays much attention to mega man lore so what was there was serviceable more hardcore fans may either love or hate the story, I genuinely don't know what the take is.

Music is quite a disappointing aspect of this game however, for a series rooted in music with many iconic tunes and references you'd think this game would be jam packed with incredible tracks but alas it was a bit lacking.

Overall a fantastic game which will test your limits but will ultimately leave you very satisfied.

141487525.review: Megaman 1-10 were difficult for the most part, but still rewarding at the end and overall fun to play. This game is nothing but a glorified rage inducer. It's fun to see the updated graphics on an original Megaman , and for the most part the game isn't all bad. The things I have to complain about are simple, but honestly make this game unplayable for me. Number one is the input latency that I experience in this game, I have tried at least five different controllers, some wireless, some wired, and still have issues with buttons reacting late to being pressed or being pressed and nothing happening at all. (This issue does not happen in any other games that I play.) The second thing is the inability to aim your blaster shots. How do you put that feature in a game (Megaman 10) that looks like it came out of the late 80s/early 90s, but can't put it in a modern looking and feeling game? The amount of times that I was on a ledge or conveyor belt and got knocked off to my death because an enemy was coming in from above me is idiotic. That shouldn't even be a concern. Third thing is level length and lack of checkpoints, the levels feel like they go on forever and have very little checkpoints, you want to make the game hard? Go ahead, but for the love of all that is holy, put in some checkpoints so I don't have to replay the same difficult part 800 times. Look, I get it, "Megaman is supposed to be hard, it's supposed to make you rip your hair out and give you an ulcer. You just suck at it." But there is a difference between a challenging game, and one that was designed to make you throw your controller through your monitor, and this seems to be the latter. So unfortunately as much as I love Megaman, I can't recommend this game.

140422173.review:
Mega Man 11 is an achievement that has, in many ways, surpassed it's predecessors, including the 8-bit styled 9 and 10. It doesn't take better graphics to move a series forward, but this game doesn't need to be the best looking Mega Man game to also be the one that moves the series forward the most in terms of mechanics, while keeping the physics of the 8-bit games that people love so much. The gears actually add a lot to the gameplay and are essential for mastering the game, although everything in the game is possible without touching the gears, for those who are the tryest of tryhards (there isn't even an achievement for beating the game without the gears; the devs don't expect you to do it, despite having a laundry list of really difficult achievements like 9 and 10). Definitely master those gears and play the game a LOT before trying anything as dumb as not using them.

The multiple difficulty levels have much more depth and differences than 9 or 10's difficulty selection, and those, combined with the achievements you get for playing through the game in certain ways, incentivize multiple playthoughs, even across the same difficulty settings more than once.

The game also includes a multitude of bonus challenges, as well as time trials with online leaderboards, so there isn't really a shortage of content. 

You can certainly wait for a sale (there have definitely been a few) but make sure to buy this game at some point to ensure the future of Mega Man. The people behind this game know what they are doing and the resulting product has very few flaws, probably the fewest of any of the classic Mega Man games, although how flawless a game is won't necessarily correlate to how much you like it, and that's just fine. You will probably enjoy this one a lot, regardless, if you like these games.

Just a couple of quick tips: make sure your sound effects volume is set three notches below normal, the music is set to max, and the voice volume is left unchanged. The music could unfortunately be mixed better and is often drowned out by the sound effects otherwise, but there are some amazing tunes in here that are worth enjoying to the fullest.

140330122.review: This looks like a game for kids, but I feel like a chad when I play it

140245764.review:
[b]Only recommended if you can get it on sale![/b]

Fans of classic Mega Man games should feel right at home with [i]Mega Man 11[/i], as it largely stays true to its roots. While it doesn't lean into the nostalgia factor as hard as the 8-bit styled [i]Mega Man 10[/i], the gameplay feels very familiar and levels are organized in the classic Mega Man fashion, where you can choose to fight the eight robot masters in any order before moving on to Dr. Wily's boss stages. Basically, if you've played a Mega Man game before, you know what to expect here.

However, even as a Mega Man fan, there are some aspects of [i]Mega Man 11[/i] that adhere too slavishly to old-school design sensibilities that were left in the past for a reason. For instance, the lives system, the one-hit kills from spike traps and bottomless pits, the jumps that require near-pixel-perfect accuracy, etc. These were always fairly transparent ways to pad out the length of games that didn't really have a ton of content, but that was commonplace and acceptable in the 8 and 16-bit eras. These days, it just feels like the game is wasting my time.

The double gear system is a good addition, and opens up new gameplay opportunities and strategies. It is the game's biggest departure from the classic formula, but I think Capcom did a good job of making it always helpful but rarely absolutely necessary. Weapon design is a mixed bag, though. Some weapons are very powerful and effective against many enemies (Tundra Storm, Blazing Torch, Chain Blast), whereas others are situational at best (Block Dropper, Pile Driver).

Overall, if you like Mega Man, you'll probably like [i]Mega Man 11[/i], but it's hard to recommend at the full price for anyone but the most diehard fans.

If you like classic Mega Man then you will love this game. From a gameplay perspective it is an amazing game.
The gear system is a welcome addition that can make things easier for newer players and can be easily ignored by those who want a traditional challenge. The game also features plenty of difficulty modes, the highest one being way harder than any of the classic MM titles.

My biggest issues with the game would be:
-The ost is underwhelming
-The plot of the game is just too basic. Classic MM has never had elaborated plots but you'd expect something a bit more involved or memorable for the return of this series.
-No DLC or additional characters. Not only are fan favorites like Protoman and Bass missing entirely from the plot, there are no additional characters either which is a big letdown considering how good this game is.

All in all, great game but it is somewhat disappointing that Capcom didn't went the extra mile to make this the best classic MM possible.

[h2]Short Game Description[/h2]
The Mega Man franchise returns with Mega Man 11, bringing better graphics, the same game formula as the others, and one new mechanic.
[list]
[*][h3]Positives[/h3]
Discussing the positives, first of all, this entry was more balanced, with different difficulty levels for the unexperienced players, making it more fair. Secondly, they introduced a new double-gear mechanic that was quite interesting despite being pretty simple, achieving a more tactic gameplay instead of a spamming one. Lastly, it had good graphics and some unique platform levels.
[*][h3]Negatives[/h3]
On the negative side, it still continues to recycle over and over the same concept; even the boss of the first Mega Man, which was interesting to fight, feels somewhat repetitive. Besides that, the soundtrack, despite being good, was not at the same level as the others.
[/list][h2][u]Conclusion[/u][/h2]
To sum up, it has good graphics with challenging and more fair gameplay, but sadly, it can feel repetitive at the same time as the soundtrack is not as good as the previous ones. The game is a 6.25/10.

139298702.review:
[b]TL;DR: Having relatively recently played the whole legacy series (1-10) for the first time through both legacy collections on Steam, Mega Man 11 comes as a very refreshing update both aimed at fans of the series while solving some of the more serious accessibility issues faced by even more recent entries in the series. Normal mode is very hard from a modern perspective, and you can't change difficulty without starting a new game, so make sure to choose wisely. [/b]

First off, while this is not the first legacy Mega Man with a 2.5D aesthetic (8 did so too), this one succeeds much better in that regard. Visuals are clean, beautiful, and the numerous effects balance chaos and readability effectively. It also brings back most of the more advanced recurring mechanics from the series, including the slides and chargeable buster. The traditional 8 unique (for each game) special weapon upgrades come back as usual, and this time especially, look and feel powerful, impressive, varied.

The usual architecture of 8 stages to beat in a custom order, followed by the much longer final stage divided in parts, also comes back as usual, for better or worse (some stages feel much more difficult than others). The shop, only found in later games, is also there, with a surprisingly large arrays of items and upgrade parts, potentially making the difference between a ridiculously hard time and a trivial experience through a level.

The game offers 4 levels of difficulty right off the bat, making it way more accessible than most games in the series. Yet my experience was a bit so-so with its current implementation. Even though I had gone through the first 10 games (to be fair with the possibility to save at every checkpoint, as permitted within both collections), normal mode felt incredibly difficult, with the frustrating tendency of having one or few short, but wild difficulty spikes far in a very long stage, forcing you to redo the whole thing (whether the rest of it is easy, and thus gets boring quick, or not). 

It doesn't help that the imperfect navigation system through narrows spaces (somehow, jumping through a small hole is way harder than it should be) makes a few areas like the moving wall of flames in the Torch Man stage feel like serious bs. I then tried the newcomer difficulty setting, which in turn felt too easy, despite a few challenging areas in Wily's fortress, assuming I wouldn't use plenty of items (should have gone with casual I suppose). Overall, I wish one could play casual, or even normal mode, without limited lives, as redoing full levels because of one random area bores me more than anything else. Being able to change difficulty without starting a new game would be nice too.

Otherwise, assuming you don't replay stages multiple times, the game is relatively short. If, like me, you tend to prefer going through various games without replaying them much, the full 30USD price might seem a tad steep coming from a big studio. Regardless, the game is technically well made and all in all, fun to play. In fact, I feel it simply plays better than most other games in the series, at least from the perspective of someone who didn't grow up with them.

The music is chill, but forgettable. I didn't mind the voices at all neither. They aren't the absolute train-wreck which Mega Man 8's voice acting consisted of.

It's fun, pretty, well made, and it brings very fresh ideas on the table (notably the quite interesting double gear system). 
8/10

138645683.review:
[H1]So what's it about?[/H1]
Dr. Light is doing the yearly check up on his eight robots when suddenly Dr. Wiley enters the laboratory and steals all of them. Megaman promises Dr Light to get the robots back and sets off on an adventure. 

Megaman XI is a retro platformer which old style mechanics.

[H1]The good[/H1]
It's great that tutorials are offered throughout the game and you can always go back to test out your weaponry and skills.

The retro music is nice - going back to the 1990 - 2000 :-).

You can select any of the levels from the start - it is not necessary to beat one boss or level before the other.

After you have completed a level and beaten the boss you take their abilities. Then during the next level, you can use the beaten boss' abilities to beat the next boss. Part of the game revolves around finding out which boss to beat first so it can give you an advantage in the next level.

[SPOILER]I found the following sequence to work best: Block, Acid, Impact, Bounch, Fuse, Tundra, Torch and Blast.[/SPOILER]

There are four difficulty levels and many challenges to replay the game. The levels aren't that long so if you feel like you want to replay it again the opportunity is there.

The levels are 2.5d with some of the bosses becoming 3d at times and making use of that. It looks OK and the graphics design is clean and crisp with an old-style flavour to it.

[H1]The not so good[/H1]
The limited lives, sparsely spread-out checkpoints and instant killing spikes all feel punishing for no good reason other than to prolong the game. Dead Cells was brutal at first but always fair - I didn't feel Megaman is fair: it is limiting itself too much to a time long past and it should have adapted improvements of games that were released in the last decades. I mean we now we have Mario Odyssey and we didn't stay in the 8-bit era?

Megaman relies on cheap mechanics to make things feel difficult but it is not working. The time stop and extra power feel poorly designed. There is no wall jumping, no double jump and no rolling. Then we have saving slots like we're playing SNES / NES and the worst of it: if you forget to use the save slot you will lose your progress as there is no autosave and the menu structure is poorly designed.

Shooting is limited to horizontal only except if you have a certain type of mega man - it's frustrating to get hit by an enemy from the top or bottom and you can't hit them. Then the basic powers are limited – so if you run out of energy there is no way to shoot or blast unless you find a refill. They are difficult to find. 

On top of this all, we have particularly unfair mechanism like a wave of fire chasing you multiple times in a level, robots crushing you if you are not fast enough etc. It is not fun. 

The physics and especially the jumping feels much like 1987 but times have evolved and going back to that mechanism after having played a game like Dead Cells or Ray Man Legends is a rough experience. It like you are on Jupiter or so and before you know you’re back on the ground.

The levels are not continuous loading – so half way the game the next part has to be loaded. On modern systems this mechanic is no longer required so unless it was applied for retro reasons it is just not good. Then we have the enemies: if they are 1 pixel out of the screen, they are reloaded like Super Mario 1 - so in especially tedious levels you get hit by a missile that you may not be able to destroy, then you fall down and the enemies that you killed before are all there ready to have a shot at you with their auto aim. To make matters worse enemies will stun you when they hit you and, in many parts, they spawn continuously. 

Boss fights are - especially without proper basic dodge control - more about how much you can cheese them then skill. A boss might be super hard but then you switch to another form and five seconds later the fight is over. It feels like there is little balance and it makes all of it not interesting. 

The story is completely forgettable and the voice acting is so poor. The whole acting feels it has the pace of an eighties anime: yes it was great back then but we would like a faster pace now. Also the samples  are poor quality – perhaps to relive the good old time? 

The game is really short (normally that would be bad but considering all the negative in this case it is a good thing). At the end you have to fight all the bosses again, fight the final boss and that’s it. There is little replay value.

[H1]Bug and glitches[/H1]
After launching the game, it is not possible to Alt-Tab back to desktop. 

[H1]The DLCs[/H1]
There are two DLCs - I only got the Wily Numbers: Instrumental Stage Tracks: it offers retro music to the stages and it's fine. 

[H1]Summary[/H1]
If you are looking for a retro game experience with retro game mechanics on a PC then Megaman XI might appeal to you - but then again why wouldn't you use an emulator and get a better experience? 

We live in 2023 and games have thankfully evolved since Super Mario 1 came out. I just wish all the great improvements various devs came up with, were introduced in Megaman XI. The game is stuck in the past and I can't recommend it - it is tedious and boring. I pushed through to see if things would improve when I got more abilities but they don't. 

Please do yourself a favour and if you are looking for a great platformer pick [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/588650/Dead_Cells/]Dead Cells[/url] or [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/632360/Risk_of_Rain_2/]Risk of Rain 2[/url] or [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/242550/Rayman_Legends/]Rayman Legends[/url]. These games offer so many improvements: there is no reason not to play those instead.

134938547.review:
The game is fine. I beat it on the Switch, but the PC version doesn't seem any different. It's just another classic series Mega Man game. The stage design is good, the graphics are good, the character design and overall art direction is good, the sound design is okay, the music is pretty good, and the voice acting is okay. But, given the game's content and short runtime, it's overall not really worth 30 dollars. It does, however, frequently go on sale for around 10, which I would say is definitely worth it. 

So the game is good. Why am I leaving a negative review? Uh, I just personally don't like it. I feel like 10 was a wonderful leave-off for the classic series, having 3 playable characters and difficulties. Mega Man 10 is highly replayable and a preferable game in my opinion. I always thought that if they ever made another classic series Mega Man game, it would have to be very final.

So, with Mega Man 10 being so good, what do they do to try and top it? Well, they add a new gimmick. You can slow down time or buff up your buster shots with only a button press. It's difficult to get used to and unsatisfying to use. Yeah, I personally dislike the new gimmick. I've never really liked gimmicks like this in video games.
The game was designed so that you could beat it without using the gimmick but trying to play without it would be stupid since a lot of the stage design is designed around it.

Bosses have a berserk mode, this is another new thing in 11. I also dislike this. I think it would be okay if it didn't give them an entirely new health bar, but as it stands it's just frustrating and annoying to deal with -- because while the bosses are in this berserk mode I feel like all progress in this boss fight has halted because I have to deal with this new berserk mode. 

Okay now that I talked about what IS in this game, let me talk about what's NOT in it.

There aren't enough checkpoints. Only 3 checkpoints was fine in the NES games since the stages were short but the stages in this game are about twice the length. I appreciate difficult games but despise having to reset progress constantly. It's just not worth getting all the way to the boss and getting a game over and having to restart. It's actually very frustrating, having this happen. Moreso than in the NES games.

Here is something only longtime fans will care about: Bass and Proto Man aren't in the game. I don't just mean as playable characters -- they aren't a part of this game at all. It's a damn shame because I love the robot trio. Mega Man, Proto Man, and Bass. They were always a pleasant sight to see. Proto Man with his whistle tune and helpful power-ups. Bass, with his cool theme song and awesome boss fights. They're just completely absent. Characters, that I believe, are iconic to the series, just gone. Like a Mario game without Luigi or Toad. Like a Sonic game without Tails or Knuckles. It's just a shame.

Okay time to nitpick. 11 is a weird number. Couldn't they have just dropped the numbering system at this point? It makes people feel pressured to play the first 10 games before this one -- which is a lot and not everybody will want to do. Seeing how back-to-basics this plot is, not adding to any of the previous games in any way, the numbering isn't really necessary and just hinders its potential playerbase, I believe.

This just isn't a Mega Man game I would personally play over and over again like I would with Mega Man 1, 2, 4, 6, and 10. Give us a new Mega Man ZX game, I would play the hell out of that. A new Mega Man X would be good, too ... at least to wrap up the story with that series. Also the Gameboy games! Give us a collection with the handheld games! The 3DS Eshop is down, my old 3DS that had the games broke, and I wanna play them!

Okayokay time to wrap up:
You can't jump through doors. 0/10.

134864814.review:
Artwise, Mega Man 11 is everything I'd want a 3D side-scroller Mega Man to be. It does a wonderful job recreating the feel of the characters and environments of the best-looking entries of the series. But when it comes to the gameplay, the Double Gear system didn't do it for me and it often felt like the game tries to make up for frustrating levels by having you buy extra lives and energy tanks with the currency you earn by killing enemies. 

Now, I've got to admit: Mega Man 8 aside, I'm not much of a a fan of the main series. I highly value the motion-rich movesets from the X, Zero, and ZX games. Given that 11 is a main series game, I'd likely refrain from posting a review were it not for a bigger issue. For some reason, the game doesn't go well with some specs (mine included) and the framerate stays as low as 25, matched with slowdowns which turn autoscrolling sections (especially Torch Man's) into a hot mess.

134085803.review:
MEGA MAN 11's greatest asset is its 2.5D high fidelity graphics.  The game looks fantastic yet manages to retain the retro feel brought back by Mega Man 9 and 10.



MEGA MAN 11's gimmick is the new DOUBLE GEAR SYSTEM.  The shoulder buttons allow you to activate either the SPEED GEAR - to slow the action down, or the POWER GEAR to double the impact of your weapons.  I found myself using the speed gear most of the time as the power gear often overwhelmed me.  Power gear charged shots pack a helluva recoil and can get you injured as easily as they damage the enemy.  Many puzzles are designed to require the Speed Gear over the power gear. 

Making a return is the "shop which lets you equip Mega Man with items and power ups that do everything from granting extra lives to extra energy/ammo - or even the most important BEAT.  He'll swoop in to save you from bottomless pits.  The first time I saw this in action in MM5 I was so elated.  However, why couldn't Rush Jet have been used for this?  There's also spike boot protectors which grant you a single use protection if you accidentally fall on insta-death spike traps.  One item: The BOLT CATCHER  allows you to collect more bolts during a stage which will help you reach currency levels allowing you to buy the two most expensive items, totaling 6000 bolts. Unfortunately, this can only be purchased on SATURDAY (the computer's clock regulates this).  There's also an ENERGY catcher  and a WEAPON ENERGY catcher that allow you to more frequently get energy cells or weapon cells.  These items can only be used one at a time, but in portions of the game where you can kill endlessly respawning enemies, you can quickly stock up.  

The enemies in this game are basically clones of thee very same enemies from the classic games, but they've been given more dialogue and personalities which they'll demonstrate shortly before you turn them to scrap metal. 

As with any Mega Man game you must demonstrate mastery of the Boss weapons, Rush coil, Rush jet, and the Double Gear system.   Because you'll more than likely cheat by using online guides to tell you the appropriate boss order,  the game isn't as difficult as some of the classic games (MM3 was a nightmare by comparison).   Grinding for bolt currency will allow you to buy enough items/power ups to ensure that you'll be able to restore health or weapons while the boss enemies are no match for you.  You can replay stages to get more currency and approach the final stages completely maxed out.  Dr. Wily won't stand a chance. 

The Music in-game really isn't as enjoyable as the memorable chip tunes from the NES.  MM1, 2, 3 and 4 had probably the best music in the entire series.  MM5 and 6 had a few good tracks while Mega Man 7 and 8 had mostly forgettable themes held afloat only by the SNES' higher fidelity, bass heavy presentation. 
Music in Mega Man 9 and 10 returned to the chip tune style but offered far more imaginative themes which I thoroughly enjoyed.    Mega Man 11  has forgettable, yet momentarily catchy J-pop electronica which, while somewhat entertaining, loops itself into obscurity as most of the themes sound the same and lack distinctiveness. 

The levels can sometimes be obnoxiously and frustratingly long.  Classic Mega Man games had stages that could be finished in fewer than 5 minutes.  Added to the difficulty  in NORMAL mode (or higher) and you could be facing much longer challenges - upwards of 20 minutes possibly.  I understand the developers wanted to "give you more", but they'd have done better offering you more thoughtful checkpoints.  Sometimes you'll die and be sent back way further than you want to be. If you manage to beat a mini-boss, that'll most likely be your main save point in a stage, but if you fall-short of him, or lose all your lives before reaching the Robot Master, you're going back to the beginning.  This can be a good thing in that you'll grind more bolt currency so you can buy more items to help you, but you must be wise about spending money or else you'll end up wasting it.  My strategy is to stock up on E-tanks and W-tanks while saving my Energy Tank for the ultimate battle with Wily at the very end.    An E-tank and W-tank combined are cheaper than a single M-Tank by a considerable margin.   




I bought Mega Man 11 for $12 on STEAM sale and I earned that money back through Youtube superchats.  I don't think I'll find myself casually replaying this game as much as I am likely to replay Mega Man 1 or 2, but this is a must-have for Mega Man fans and anyone else with a taste for old school Nintendo-hard gaming.

130672330.review:
Our blue boy is back!!!
I started directly into the harder difficulty and I found it fair. One thing I must highlight is how accessible this entry is; You really make your own difficulty, not only with the new and shiny dual gear system, but with the equipment available.

"Finding too easy still?", I'm pretty sure you can complete, at least every robot master, I haven't reach the final stages yet, without using the gears once and any equipment if you don't want to. "Finding too difficult?", stack restores, life, and make good use of slow down and you should be go to go. I can't understand if someone using all resources available to still find this game too difficult, I would suggest another game then. It's not this game's fault at all.

"Does it has some rough edges?" Yes? It has some, but I feel it's nothing that can't be overlooked AND it brings a lot of nice innovations to the franchise. Other than the double gear system, and the adjustable difficulty, enemies have more clear attack patterns, bosses, oh the BOSSES! Has been a long time I felt the robot masters' fights were so intense!! It's a FIGHT now, not a push-over Spark Mandrill, AND they have second forms/ultimates that spice everything. It feels much more alive, which I didn't even think the series needed until I played it.

"Could it have better graphics?" yea, sure. But for the innovation and animation it brings, I feel it's justified. It's finally in 3D after the last two entries that were 8-bits, so it needs to be praised for it. They did a very good job here. It could have been better, but they made a solid foundation.

I guess the most pressing argument is, "should you buy it full price?" yea, I think so. That's the market price for 2D platformers and this has a smooth 3D coat on top. If you're a fan of 2D platformers or Mega Man, I believe getting with a discount is a no-brainer. You get a well nice thought-out that could just reuse the same beaten formula, but dared to not to. It definitely should be praised for it!

This is the game we waited for, and now, I only wish for more!

129860203.review:
A tip:
When I first played the game 4 years ago it took me twice as long to beat the game (no exaggeration - 6 vs 3 hours on my save files). It seemed much less painful this time. When I compared save files, apparently in my first playthrough I just never bought the item that makes you find more bolts (currency). I didn't even remember that that was an option to buy the first time, but it was the first thing I bought this time and it made the game much quicker. When I looked up why, apparently the item is only available in the in-game store on Saturdays. WTF? WHY?? I don't know why developers do this sort of thing. But, screw you apparently if you start it on a Tuesday and want to play through without using an outside guide.

Otherwise, it's mostly a great game. It's a big adjustment from prior Mega Man games in that the levels are really long, (but you still only get 2 extra lives) so you'll likely end up starting over a few times until you learn the levels (unless you get the item I mentioned - then you can just stock up on extra lives and E-tanks and save a ton of time).

Also, the music is boring which is a real crime for a Mega Man game. But overall, the bosses are neat and the gameplay was fun and it's still worth playing.

128061241.review:
Splendid addition to classic mega man series. 

Long time ago I played the demo and didn't like the game that much. But then I tried the full game and gosh, I'm impressed how fun it is. 

This game adds the gimmick of double gear, which probably will never return. I can see Mega Man introducing new gimmick in every game to keep it fresh, would be fun. Anyway, double gear allows you to power up your moves or slow down time, but you can keep it up only for a limited time. If you're close to death you can activate both at once. A lot of mechanics on the stages revolve around you using your gears properly. Although many of those sections can be also beat without it.

At the beginning you'll probably use speed-up gear more, it's uses are more obvious. There are also some escape sequences, where you can't succeed without your speed-up (I think). But each weapon you unlock gets additional mode when used with power-up gear. So as you progress in the game the power gear gets more and more useful. There are many places you can make child's play by just using proper weapon + gear combo. Trying stuff out and getting hard boss killed in seconds is always a good feeling.

The weapons are... possibly the most fun ever in the series. This time, thanks to 3D graphics, you don't just change colors, but also get some different parts when you transform. Nice touch. Also, after getting a weapon you can freely experiment with it in training stage, to get the feel for it's uses. Couple this, with the fact that nearly all weapons are useful during stage traversal and you have a recipe for success. Also, using powered up version of the weapons doesn't seem to use more  energy, so you're free to go crazy.

This game has 4 difficulty levels. Difficulty levels are nothing new for mega man series, but in the past you often had a choice between insultingly easy and normal. Here you have very easy option for newcomers. Mode named casual, which increases your lives, checkpoints and decreases damage taken, but it doesn't really break the game, as easier modes often did. It feels very fun, and it also refills your energy if you die, which allows you to go all out. Normal difficulty is what you'd expect. But they've also added harder challenge difficulty. Nice.

You can collect bolts on the stage to purchase upgrades, which honestly are rather strong and useful. Most of them at least. There are also some secret ones to break the game, so you can have fun like that too.

The controls are superb. You can change your weapons quickly with triggers(gets less useful as you get further into the game), the menuses are good looking and work very smoothly. Rush is now accessed by pressing one of two dedicated buttons. Both modes of Rush share energy. I think it might have already been done in the past, but honestly I don't remember. But it all works out really well in this game.

The story is actually very good for classic mega man standards. More involved than I expected. Although remember that I probably already typed more words than the whole game uses.

You have some other goodies - time attacks, challenge modes, "jump as little as possible" and other game modifiers. There's also a gallery and some online rankings. Overall the game feels like a complete package.

They also had some nice attention to detail. You can only have 3 shots on the screen like in classic games. But there's also one place that they completely failed on. You don't fly trough the door with kick if you jump at them. This is unacceptable, please refund my money.

Some of the stages feel a bit bland, I especially didn't like Block Man stage. That's the one used in demo, and might explain why my first impression of the game was so bad. Some of the stages are very inventive, with Bounce Man stage being my favorite. I'm not sure if there was ever anything like that in the past.

I also like how weaknesses work in this game against bosses. For some bosses the same weapon that works against them is also good against the hazards on the stage, so you have to think where to use energy. Also, they put up a bit more fight than usual, even with the weakness. Some weaknesses aren't that obvious or simple to use. 

While I came to like the visuals, I never came to really like the music. It's inoffensive. But this is mega man game. The music should rock hard. There's nothing like Wily stage from MM2 here. 

All things considered I'd like to see MM12, MMX9 or MZX3 or maybe some Zero spin-off. Use the same engine and deliver please. Thank you Capcom.

124251932.review:
This game sure was mega man 11.
here are my main criticisms:
1. robot master weapons in general were awkward to use, especially against boss fights. Doing them buster only is way easier, at least it was for me. 
2. the double gear system is very lopsided, i felt no inclination to use the power gear because the speed gear is better in every way.
3.  Unlocking upgrades is unintuitive and the upgrades themselves as a whole are ridiculously broken. I should never be able to carry 9 e-tanks at a time, especially given how cheap they are at the shop and how easy it is to grind bolts. Making speed gear even better and letting you use it more often is also insane. 
4. Wily stages were underwhelming. there are only 4 stages, 2 of those are the refights and the final boss, which leaves room for only 2 stages, neither of which were very memorable. The final boss might have been hard, but when you can carry 9 e-tanks, 9 w-tanks and an s-tank, and can slow down time, you're basically guaranteed to win. 

More minor criticisms/nitpicks:

-voice acting was subpar for the most part. the robot master voice lines are especially cringe, roll and dr wily were pretty good though.
-lack of wily wiggling his eyebrows 
- not a huge fan of the artstyle, also megaman's alternate outfits when switching weapons look very stupid imo
-the soundtrack, while not bad by any means, certainly isn't beating out any of the other games. It's mediocre, and for a mega man game that isn't exactly good enough

All that being said, it's not terrible or anything, just woefully mediocre. I bought it on sale for 8 bucks or something and I would say its worth it, but under no circumstances should you pay full price for this game.

I hope if they make a mega man 12 or X9, it's better than this.

119060392.review: Mega Man 11 is the continuation of the original Mega Man series. It is an action platformer where you platform through stages, defeat the stages boss and with the weapon you obtained through the boss, you take out other bosses who are weak to that weapon. It also has a new mechanic called gears. You have two gears called power and speed gears which the first one enhances your attacks and the second one slows down time. Gear system is fun to use and adds a really unique aspect to the game without disrupting the original formula. Stages are really fun to go through , boss designs are well made and the core gameplay is top notch as always. It is a really good Mega Man game although it is much easier than the rest of the games in my opinion and takes around 3.5 to 4 hours to complete the main game. You also have challenges if you want more after finishing the game which is a really good addition. Overall it is a really enjoyable game that you can finish in a short period. I would recommend it to every Mega Man fan and new comers to the series since it is easier than the other games. Buy it on sale if you can.

118456370.review:
I don't know what some of these other reviewers are thinking with their comments. While this is a fun Mega Man title and very well animated, it is not a great Mega Man game. The main problem is that the game doesn't flow well from stage to stage. You can jump in on any level and beat the boss without using the skills you picked up along the way. There is no progressive development with your skills, in which you need to beat one boss in order to gain a skill that helps you beat another boss. I was destroying bosses with just my gun, and when I used the skills it annihilated them. Granted this wasn't on the hardest setting, but it still should have some thought development put into it. Second, the voice acting is absolutely horrible. HORRIBLE. Some of the worst voice acting I have ever heard in any game. Almost as if it was created for a 5 year old. And this ties into the story, because there is such a positive minded message focused with the whole double gear skill. Such as at the end of the game, Light has Auto use the Double Gear system to help fix the other robots, which would give a perfect opportunity to have Auto turn on Light and require Mega Man to beat him and destroy the Double Gear, but somehow the Double Gear is the savior of all humanity and robotity. Third, the music is weak af. Nothing like the good Mega Man titles. It doesn't come close to even attempting to compare to the good Mega Man music. And lastly, its so easy to gain points to buy skills... it would be nice if there was a little more grinding involved to be able to suit up with all your abilities, because once you get them you are nearly unstoppable.

But, like I said... the artwork and animation is amazing. So beautiful. Rich colors, great designs, beautiful bosses and weapons. A fun game overall! Though it is not worth $20-30. More like an $8 game to be honest.

Obligatory: My play time is inflated because I left it on for a while.

Okay. I have played a significant number of mega man (mega men?) games, not all, but most, and I have relished them. The balance between good level design, fun boss fights, and the occasional chillingly difficult section is everything I'm looking for. Hell, Mega Man level design is the measuring stick to which I hold most other games. 
That being said, you've played almost all of this before.
Sure, sure, sure. Mega Man as a series has gone back to the same well more than once, but in this case the "Double  Gear" system does little to hide that the levels are near carbon copies of other entries in the series. If you can get this for cheap, take a shot. Otherwise, I'd advise against it.

Just to hammer a few nails in the coffin, there's dodgy hit boxes on a few enemy attacks and you can exploit a bug to get infinite currency in the in-game shop. They made the the enemy boss loops much more predictable but much quicker to "encourage" you to use the double gear. I got through 90% of the game without it.

I do like some of the more interesting boss fights and their dual gear modes and I really enjoyed the ice level. But I'm sick and tired of fighting the yellow devil. Come up with something else.

117395596.review:
This is a refined version of the classic Mega Man formula.  There are some quality of life improvements that I wish I had back in the NES days.  The enemies and levels are exceptionally creative, in this one.  It's fun from beginning to end.  I didn't use the "Double Gear" system all that much, but it's a nifty thing, if you're into special abilities.  All of the boss weapons are fun and useful in more than one way.  The bosses are satisfying to fight.  The story is about what you'd expect from a Mega Man game; the game is fun without it, and the story (such as it is) just kind of exists in the background.  Since the actual gameplay is so fun, I don't see anything wrong with skipping all the cutscenes.

There are a number of optional "challenge" levels you can do, but they weren't to my liking; you might like them better, if you're the type of player who likes to play a game until you can do everything perfectly.

The one thing that I would consider a negative, albeit a small one, is that the main game is only about 4 hours long.  It's about what a classic NES Mega Man takes to play, so it isn't a big deal; but unless you can get the game for cheap, I would suggest waiting until whatever it costs is worth 4 hours of core gameplay.  In 1990, this game would have sold for $50 on a contemporary console, but today, in the current market, it's a "less than $10 game", IMHO.  It's a lot of fun, so don't let that deter you; just make sure you feel that you're getting your money's worth.  Of course, if you want to play all the challenges, and play on different difficulties, that would make it much more than a 4 hour game.  For me, one playthrough of the main game scratched the itch, so I don't feel the need to do all the optional stuff.  YMMV.

Overall, this is a fine addition to the Mega Man series--arguably one of the best--and I'm delighted that new Mega Man games are being made.  If it sounds like your kind of game, buy it.

It's a solid Mega Man title with almost everything you can expect from the series. Not really perfect, but it's fine for the most part. I'll list some of the points that come into mind for this one.
The good:
- Superhero(Hardest) mode is available right from the get go: It should be like this on every game on existance.
- Great controls in general: You won't have problems with them.
- Level and boss designs: Fun levels, fun bosses. The bosses designs are some of the best in the series.
- Art style(2.5D is well done in this game, which is rare).
- Voice acting: Not cringe, finally!
The BAD:
- Running animation: It's just bad and it will bother you for a while.
- Music: It's a big part of the series, but on this title the OST is just underwhelming for the most part. It has some bangers here and there tho(Stage Select,Blast,Fuse and Wily are the highlights for me).
- The double gear system: Really fun when the bosses use it, but such a bad mechanic for the player. I didn't feel like using it at all and the gameplay would be better without it even existing.
- The part system: I have mixed feelings for this one. Some are fine and I like them, others are just boring. The store is also lame and you can't buy more than one item at a time.
- Graphic settings: A 2018 title with resolution, AA and V-Sync on the options. I guess because it's Mega Man they decided to not give a fuck. However it's underwhelming even for a game like this.
- Extras: Just boring. Didn't feel like doing any of them. I finished the game and I'll just let it rust on my library.
Rating: A solid 7/10 for a solid title. A must play if you're into the franchise.

115121578.review: Ahh, Mega Man 11. This game is different from other Mega Man games because it is now an upgrade in graphics to the latest technology. It also follows the previous games, a little too closely at times, in terms of the playability factor. There are the same amount of villains and levels as basically any other Mega Man game, which I think by now, this roster needs to be expanded because the game can be completed in a relatively short amount of time. However, the levels are all unique and have different challenges, and the game is extremely creative in how it is planned out. There are no real flaws I can report in the game or bugs. It is extremely fun as usual, especially since it is brought up to date, and contrary to what people say in other reviews, the music is fun and some of it is a newer-sounding soundtrack, while some of the soundtrack is more classic-sounding Mega Man music for the old-schoolers. I appreciate the different difficulties added to the game and the gear system, however, I think much more needs to be added to really make this series shine more. Also, it has been many years since this game came out, and there is no sequel to Mega Man 11 yet, so I am not sure what the delays are because they should keep up the momentum and not let it become another game that only comes out once in awhile and lose popularity. It is obvious, from what I have read online, that the sales of the game did well for a later Mega Man game, and it sent the message to the creators that another follow-up to the Mega Man 11 game would be lucrative. However, with this game's series, it's time for a complete refresh and not just graphically because obviously that is where they have made the most improvements to the gameplay. The format should have other types of levels in the game to give more replay value because the challenges with leaderboards offered are very difficult with no option to add on parts to Mega Man. You also can only play as one character on this game. Considering the original creator of Mega Man is no longer producing this game, it was pretty close to its original material. I think they have the right team assembled, but now, let's take Mega Man to the next level and bring it back to blockbuster status. Take care.

114750672.review:
The game is not [i]bad.[/i] If you have money to spare and you're relatively new to the franchise, it may be worth picking up. Otherwise, I generally cannot recommend it.

This is the 11th game in the classic series. There was an 8-year gap between it and Mega Man 10. There are also three Mega Man subseries with sidescrolling action like the classic series (X, Zero, ZX) that haven't had anything since [b][i]2007[/i][/b]. They have had more than enough time to practically [i]perfect[/i] the simplified classic series formula, and they made it fall way too short.

#1: The level design is largely noninteractive and uninspired, and the robot master weapon selection is an accomplice to this. Stages have very few gimmicks to mix up the gameplay, and the gimmicks that [i]are[/i] there are mostly surface-level and shallow like wind or giant death walls chasing you. No bold takes at changing up control or movement like e.g. the shmup-like sections in Mega Man 8 (or 3 if you count the forced Rush Jet sections). You generally just walk from point A to B with really the only true obstacles to give you trouble being pits and spikes (which insta-kill you). There are no alternate routes, and there are really no ways to approach screens in different ways other than completely cheesing platforming challenges with Rush (or Pile Driver, the only robot master weapon that actually changes the platforming) or hitting out-of-reach enemies with weapons that have different ranges. Consider Mega Man 7 where weapons actually have effects on the surrounding stage like lighting trees on fire, powering devices, or freezing lava, oftentimes revealing alternate paths. Consider Mega Man 9 where Concrete Shot and Tornado Blow can interact with the stage like that [i]and[/i] help you with regular platforming, too, by giving you footholds or temporarily lowered gravity. All this game has is an aerial dash with Pile Driver and freezing Torch Man's stage's giant death walls. That's it.

#2: The game is pathetically short. Look, I'm not saying we need 69 robot masters and 420 castles, but this is [b][i]THE[/i][/b] shortest game in the classic series -- honestly, possibly in the entire [i][b]FRANCHISE[/b][/i]. Once you beat up the 8 robot masters, there are only really 2 Wily levels. In Wily 3, the section leading up to refights is [i]one[/i] screen. Finally, in Wily 4, the section leading up to the final boss is practically just an extremely slow and boring elevator ride (with the really weird decision to make it slowly throw you into spikes if you don't just guess that you're supposed to drop down the giant gaping void below you). Beyond just the lack of levels, there is extremely little replay value. Although they have their share of problems, Mega Man 6, 7, 8, and & Bass all have powerups and stage design that incentivize you to explore and/or replay levels -- experience alternate routes, find secrets, try [i]actually[/i] interesting and unique powerups that significantly change gameplay, etc. Heck, & Bass, 9, and 10 let you even play as different characters. This game has absolutely none of that. Even [i]Mega Man Powered Up[/i] the [i][b]PSP[/b][/i] remake of the original Mega Man is better about this...

#3: The shop system is unintuitive and annoying. There are many items you have to [i][b]UNLOCK[/b][/i] before you can buy them -- [i]every single playthrough,[/i] mind you -- and the unlock conditions range from arbitrary time-wasters to [i][b]incentives[/b][/i] to play badly. And of course, none of the conditions are actually told to you in-game. Want to upgrade Speed Gear? Just sit in one place and spam it on and off over and over first. Want to buy consumable Pierce Protectors that prevent one spike death each? Die to spikes [i][b]FIVE[/b][/i] times first. Absolutely unholy system. Seriously, never do this again.

#4: The special weapons are few and mediocre. Look, this weapon set is one of the most balanced in the classic series, but some of them feel [i][b]EXTREMELY[/b][/i] irritating to use because they [i][b]CONSTANTLY[/b][/i] halt your movement. I can understand why they did it for Tundra Storm (this game's screen-clearer) or Scramble Thunder (since it can help you shoot enemies below you before you land on them), but you [i][b]CANNOT[/b][/i] justify Acid Barrier or Chain Blast needing that crap. Speaking of Chain Blast, why does the [i]one[/i] special weapon that incentives you to spam many shots in quick succession have a [i][b]SHOT COOLDOWN?[/b][/i] Pile Driver is the only one to really impact [strike](haha, Impact Man)[/strike] platforming, and Bounce Ball is just completely lazy and chaotic -- just hit wherever the hell eventually if you're patient enough. [i][b]NONE[/b][/i] of the weapons have different functionality depending on how you continue to hold the fire button or press arrow keys post-shot -- with the only exception really being manually detonating Chain Blast. The only other way to vary up weapons' functionality is Power Gear, which upgrades them in typically linear and lazy ways; they generally just do more damage or shoot a few more of the same projectiles as before. By the way, don't forget Mega Man 5, 6, 7, 8, and 10 all have more weapons than the usual 8 you get from robot masters -- including Mega Man 4 if you count Balloon and Wire.

#5: The visuals and audio do [i][b]NOT[/b][/i] give good, responsive feedback compared to previous games. It is generally hard to tell when I have i-frames or bosses have i-frames. It's even hard to tell if minibosses are actually taking damage or if everything is just dinging off of them, especially with weapons like Blazing Torch or Scramble Thunder.

Now, I will certainly give props to improvements where due. Not having the game pause every time you pick up health or ammo is nice. The difficulty select is nice. Being able to access the shop during the Wily Castle is nice. And whenever it isn't impacting gameplay negatively (#5 above), the visuals are pretty nice. I appreciate the gear system for being [i]something[/i] new to the classic series, even if I think it's ultimately a bit shallow. But none of this counterbalances the fact that the game is short and bland. There are other sidescrolling platforming games with tighter design, more creativity, and more content -- including other classic series Mega Man games, both official and [i]unofficial[/i] (try Rockman 4 Minus Infinity). And they generally cost less than $30, too.

I hope Capcom continues to try to defibrillate the franchise, but this is was a weird start, especially after an 8 year break.

[spoiler]I hope nobody says there [i]wasn't[/i] an 8-year pause between Mega Man 10 and Mega Man 11 because of Mega Man X DiVE. It's a fuckin' [i]gacha[/i] game. I'd sooner count the goddamn WonderSwan games as being new entries and new content.[/spoiler]

109376201.review:
As a classic Mega Man fan, this is a fantastic translation from the tried and true 8-bit to the modern high-definition version! The awesome head-banging music, the sharp crisp graphics and anything that makes the classic Mega Man series great is done near-perfectly in this version. Although Megaman/Rockman himself has changed compared to his superior 8-bit self, it’s just enough differentiation without looking like the awkwardly large Mega Man 7 sprite. Meanwhile, the story itself also looks like one of the best coming from the Mega Man games (Not spoiling it here, but it’s really well thought out!).

The overall difficulty maintains what makes the Mega Man/Rockman series a great game: Although it will appear really challenging on the 1st few playthroughs, after that combined with memorizing the patterns it becomes a really fun romp in the park! It may take a while to get through the levels, even on Casual mode, but the overall experience is really satisfying after you complete it! If you’re new to the series and/or you’re not yet ready for the big challenge there’s Newcomer mode. It makes things a lot easier (The infamous insta-KO spikes simply giving you damage instead, for example.) so newcomers can get used to the game’s systems and mechanics, while the pros can have a chance to decompress and have a good time! Speaking of which, like Mega Man 9 you can collect screws (the in-game currency) to buy whatever items and upgrades that will make things easier for you to traverse the levels.

There is also a collection of challenges for those who want to look beyond the main game, replays and leaderboards included, and achievement hunters will have a nice time overall.

So far, the only major problem I see in this game is a huge jump in difficulty between the Newcomer and Casual difficulty. Otherwise, this is a great Mega Man installment to look into, along with 9, 5, 2 and, IMO, 1!




Hey, I can still recommend Mega Man 1, even when I’m one of those oddballs who thought it was a cakewalk!! XD

107702519.review:
Wow! It's Mega Man, modernized. The stages look great, the graphics are colorful, the music is super catchy, every weapon is a delight to use, the bosses are interesting, and now you actually have a compelling reason to use the boss weapons in-stage. 

The Double Gear system is also fun and intuitive. You can temporarily increase your power or your speed (or both!) at the expense of burning out afterward if you overload. Note that the bosses have this system too. Things are a lot more strategic this time around. It's a definite improvement on the old Mega Man formula.

However, if that isn't your bag, you can technically still play it safe by just stocking up on E-tanks and spamming everyone to death. The game does let you do that if that's all you want. The "Superhero mode" (hard mode) is also a little broken in that you end up with more bolts (currency) than you know what to do with, which ends up making the game easier due to your ability to max out all your tanks and equipment each stage. Some may see all these "easy-making" workarounds as a plus, while others may see it as a flaw in trying to be too accommodating -- an unwillingness to enforce a particular style of gameplay/difficulty.

For you achievement hunters out there, this will take maybe 4+ playthroughs. I did a Normal-mode run for most of the game-related achievements, a Casual-mode run for the no-item + buster-only achievements, a Superhero-mode run, and a Normal-mode sub-60 speedrun. At least one of these runs needs to have no game-overs if you want to snag that achievement too. There are also extra challenges for earning medals, including a rather difficult 30-stage gauntlet (Dr. Light's Trial).

I enjoyed this game a lot, and it inspires a lot of confidence in the future of the series. This is a must-play for any fan of Mega Man in general.

101466528.review:
They say timing is everything, and Mega Man 11 couldn't have been timed better. It came after a long drought of games in the series, several cases of what felt like Capcom backstabbing fans with cancelations, all culminating with Inafune leaving the company in disgust and teasing fans with the soon-to-be PR train wreck known as Mighty No. 9. In that context, plus the fact that the previous two entries were 8-bit throwbacks, it's understandable why people were hyped when this was announced. Everything pointed to it being a true return to form, and bringing the classic series up to speed with modern technology. Does it live up to that hype though?

This game finally breaks the trend of Wily totally not being the villain at the start and leaves him as the unquestionable perpetrator from the beginning. Furthermore, it actually touches on the series backstory a bit: it begins with a flashback to Wily and Light's younger years as colleagues and reveals the straw that breaks the camel's back that caused Wily to swear off their partnership. Further, the piece of this backstory serves as the stepping stone for the most major change in gameplay, which I'll get to in a minute. The game is also fully voice acted too, and thankfully it's quite competently done in contrast to previous English voice acting in this series.

Mega Man 11 does the same formula you know at this point: eight robot master stages, each gives you a new weapon that another is weak to, and then the Wily castle. The biggest thing you will notice right away though is the brand new visual overhaul. After two 8-bit throwbacks, it's refreshing to see a modernization again. The game also brings back the charged Mega Buster and sliding, two things notably absent from 9 and 10, so that is also welcome.

Regarding the major change I mentioned earlier, that comes in the form of the Double Gear system. In addition the usual utilities you begin with, this ability lets you either slow down time or make your weapons more powerful for a limited time frame. If you let either run too long though, it will overheat and you will need to let it fully recharge before using it again. The two abilities share the same meter. Personally, I found the slow down mechanic to be a real life saver, but the power mechanic I thought was a bit redundant. The slow down mechanic already lets you tear through enemies with much less effort with just the Mega Buster, so I didn't see much need to use the power gear. It does give the robot master weapons a secondary more powerful ability though, for what that is worth.

The game also has a few other nice quality of life improvements, but one of the best ones in my opinion was that Rush Coil and Rush Jet are now called with specific buttons instead of having to switch to them, which was super convenient. As with the last several games, you also have a shop system that allows you to buy extra lives and energy tanks between levels, as well as purchase upgrades such as automatically charging your buster or reducing damage knock back. Best of all, you get the opportunity to try every weapon you get right after you receive it without having to worry about draining energy, which I can't believe none of the other games thought to do this before.

Unfortunately, the game hangs on to other old tropes a little too hard. Namely, there is still a lives system in this game. Why? There are so many better and more fair ways to make the game challenging than this. I wouldn't have minded as much, except one, they still aren't reset to 3 if you finish a level with less than that (effectively meaning you'll need to game over before trying the next level), and two, the levels in this game are way too dang long. They're long enough that many have two checkpoints instead of just one that the past games had. Further, they often tend to have at least one cheap area that requires trial and error to effectively get past, like a jump totally surrounded in spikes.

All that said, when the game is good, it's a lot of fun. The new gear system adds a lot of unexpected depth to the game and the levels are generally designed well. The weapon roster is also quite good and balanced; most weapons feel like an extension on your utilities rather than being meant to replace your Mega Buster, which is exactly as it should be. And again, the modernized look is so refreshing to see again; 7 and 8 were the last taste of that we got, and I felt there was so much more to do with taking the franchise into the modern day, so I am quite glad we did get to see it.

All around, Mega Man 11 is pretty decent. It doesn't knock it out of the park or anything, but you will enjoy it if you're a fan of the series. That said, its current asking price is $30, which isn't worth it for how much content there is. Wait for it to go on sale and then consider if it sounds worth it to you.

98130078.review:
**  TL,DR: me gusta.  **

I've been a huge fan of Mega Man since the NES era so I had high expectations for this game... and it didn't disappoint.

The graphics and overall aesthetic looks great. I used to think that 8-bit graphics was the only way to do Mega Man justice, but this game feels and looks like the perfect evolution to "modern" graphics. It doesn't have that annoying cartoon feel (complete with child voice acting) like Mega Man 8 did. The 2.5D is perfect. We saw what happened when they tried to switch to 3D platforming with a certain infamous "X" game years ago, so I'm glad they didn't try to go that route again. Unfortunately, the music is not up to Mega Man standards, but then again, the bar was set pretty high by previous Mega Man games so it didn't really bother me.

Play control is nice and tight, as it should be for any platformer. I recommend using an 8BitDo controller because they have a D-pad that perfectly recreates that of an old NES/SNES controller which is way better than the D-pad you get nowadays on controllers, imo.

The "Double Gear" system introduced in this game is a cool idea that allows you to temporarily increase your weapon power or slow down time and react quicker. Like all Mega Man games, the difficulty varies quite a bit based on the order you do the stages and how you use the weapons. Speed Gear is a huge benefit when used in the right situations, and understanding how/when to use various other weapons makes a big difference too. For example: you can use Tundra Man's weapon to freeze the firewall that chases you in Torch Man's stage). Not knowing the best order to do the stages and how/when to take advantage of Speed Gear can make the game seem much more difficult than it actually is for newcomers. Also, the item shop makes a world of difference. There's also 4 different difficulty modes.

Other than the music, my only gripe about the game is that it's a little too short. The Wily fortress in this one only has 2 full stages before the robot master rematches. The game does have an extensive challenge mode if you're into that, but I wish the base game was a little longer. Gone are the days of having 2 fortresses with 3-4 stages each, sadly. Plus there no items to collect in each stage (the items are all in the shop), so you don't have a reason to go back to stages you've already beaten.

...Also, it's way past time they retired Yellow Devil. It's become one of the biggest Mega Man cliches.

PROS:
Graphics look great
Play control is tight
Speed Gear is very useful and innovative (for a Mega Man game, at least)
Well balanced difficulty for experienced Mega Man players
Extensive item shop that makes it easier for new Mega Man players

CONS:
Music doesn't live up to Mega Man standards
The base game is a little short
They still haven't used my "Buttplug Man" idea

I gave this game a solid two hours before I called it quits.

This game's difficulty is highly reminiscent of games from the 80's and 90's; Nintendo hard, as it were.

Every level is a brutal gauntlet that will send your ass way back to either the start, middle, or before the last boss fight.  Now, I'm used to this in Mega Man games, but it almost feels like they notched up the difficulty here.  It could be because I didn't utilize the double gear system much, but I don't really like it tbh.

The double gear system is a system that either increases your speed or damage when you're using it.  It can cause you to overheat and sustain a handicap for a while if you abuse it.

I personally prefer to play without it since it seems to slow the pacing of the game down, but without it the game is more difficult.  It also doesn't help that I much prefer the play style to the X and Zero series and it's no wonder I'm not a fan of this.

If you love classic Mega Man, I'm sure you'll find much here to enjoy.  For me, it's a hard pass.

As far as being a good PC port; It ran buttery smooth with no issues on my end.  Not many graphical options to play with, but with a game like this, does it really matter?  Full controller support right from the get go and no need to optimize anything.  This is a technically decent PC port, if nothing else.
