96729821.review:
System and Setup:

Windows 10 64bit
Intel Core i9 10900K
NVIDIA GeForce RTX 2080 SUPER
LG 27inch 1440p 144hz monitor 27GN850-B

The game ran at 1440p, 60fps without any notable issues.

Pros:

+ The Double Gear System succeeds at adding a new twist to the game, allowing players to either play it safe by slowing down time, or double down by buffing your attacks. Players with enough skill can clear the game without ever using it.
+ The robot master designs are good, not as simple as the older games in the series but still less detailed than 8 and Megaman & Bass' designs. Mega Man himself is given a subtle redesign, taller than the 8-bit design, shorter than 32-bit design and more in line with his Smash Bros. look.
+ Putting Rush on Y and B and bringing over X7 and X8's right stick weapon change makes it easier to avoid having to pause the game to switch abilities.
+ The robot master designs are good, successfully finding a middle ground between the simplistic designs of the NES era and the complicated designs of 8 and Megaman & Bass.
+ All of the weapons are distinct and useful in different situations, ecouraging you to use them instead of just relying on the charged buster shot.

YMMV:

/ The Wily Castle is much shorter than other games in the series have been. For one, there's only one castle in this game and it only has two real stages before sending you into the boss rush and final confrontation with Wily. In exchange, you get robot master stages that are much longer than they would be in other games.
/ The voice acting is good. On the upside that means you don't have to sit through terrible cutscenes like in Mega Man 8. On the downside, that means you have no more terrible cutscenes to laugh at like in Mega Man 8.

Cons:

- The soundtrack is underwhelming and unmemorable. Mega Man games are often remembered for their music, and unfortunately the ball was dropped here.

Time to beat: 

It took me four hours to beat the game's main mode on the first playthrough. I imagine I'd be able to do it in less than three now that I know what's coming.

Conclusion:

Although it isn't as perfect a game as I wish it could've been, Mega Man 11 is a successful entry into the franchise and worthy of any fan to play.

An easy recommendation.

96663641.review:
Mega Man 11 is an amazing love letter to the Classic series' past.

I highly recommend that you play all 11 of the previous mainline games before this one (including Mega Man and Bass) because there are so many old mechanics and enemies that return. It preserves the same stage progression, weapon system and high-challenge platforming that the series is known for. Stages will feel long at first compared to earlier entries, but it eventually makes sense and each stage is very rewarding. Mega Man 11 has some of the best and most useful special weapons in the entire Classic series, and I found myself using them all constantly instead of just the Mega Buster.

The only thing it doesn't preserve is all of the Classic series side characters. Proto Man, Bass, Treble, Reggae and Tango are all absent here. Capcom wanted to introduce this series to a new audience after so many years without a sequel, so they kept the character list limited to the Dr. Light family. I honestly applaud them for at least titling the game Mega Man 11 instead of ditching the numbering sytem entirely. 

Whether or not we see another 8+ year gap in between this game and Mega Man 12 remains to be seen. This game sold well for Mega Man standards and is currently the third best selling game in the entire series, including spin-offs. What we do know is that this game is a perfect foundation for another modern Mega Man game, and I would love to see one just like this. I know that the industry has changed and pumping out sequels that are very similar to each other wouldn't work anymore. Mega Man 11 through Mega Man 16 in the same vein as Mega Man 1 through 6, all being based on the same foundation with incredibly similar structure, is never going to happen. And that honestly makes me sad. The Double Gear System mechanic in this game could easily be replaced by a similar gimmick in Mega Man 12 and that would make the game different enough for me to purchase it. My favorite part about these games is the robot masters and the Wily Castle bosses. These characters give each of the Classic Mega Man games it's identity. Even though they all follow that same structure, they all feel different to me because of the characters and boss characters.

Capcom doesn't have to reinvent the wheel for Mega Man 12. This game is proof of that. Let's hope they don't turn it into a gacha game for your phone like they did with Mega Man X.

92356194.review:
This review isn't boosted by the hype related to Mega Man's comeback.

I usually review games and focus more on the price point, which is in our case 30€, so what do we get for that ? :

A story mode containing the classic line of going through 8 bosses and then a wily castle, new gameplay mechanics, the ability to switch between english and japanese VA, new visuals and soundtracks which I really loved and digged, and finally an extra mode that contains a gallery and a challenge mode filled with 5 (blind) hours of content it's sad that the story feels a bit independent from the past games, or the future canon games, as it references pretty much nothing from these.

 For a first blind playthrough, it took me 7 hours to finish the game, it should take you less or more, but the level design is super that it made me love every single stage, the soundtracks are matching, the difficulty from the old games does carry over : you still get these hard enemy placements and frustrating platforming which does add to the beauty of the game, i would say the game only got modernized aesthetically which is a big plus in my book, speaking of modernized, you're not forced into this situation as you can pick one of the offered difficulty modes, in contrast to how other games from other franchises made their comebacks with a setting that makes casuals feel welcomed but also forces it so old players would hate it.


I liked how they made the weapons useful for various situations, unlike the weapons in some of the old games. still, on a first playthrough i had the feeling that this game also suffered from the same weapons balance problem that came from Mega Man 8, where every or most of the weapons deal some crazy damage that makes the platforming even easier, i can't confirm this as i don't have a source.
the new gameplay mechanic is not that gimmicky in my opinion and i barely used it, with power gear i could speedrun bosses swiftly, the speed gear however is intended to be used for platforming, story wise it should make you move faster, right ? well it actually doesn't, as by default and unless upgraded, the speed gear makes everything slow, including you. I liked however how they made them an element that cannot be abused much and gave them a cooldown, but still, i could just toggle the power gear off and on everytime i wanted to shoot since most of the time i just kept dodging so i would put this as a grey opinion.

The Challenge mode, as said before, is filled with about 5 hours of content, as you progress in the story mode, you will also gain the special weapons and be able to use them in the challenge mode, this makes almost 70% of the challenges easy to go through, although i haven't unlocked everything, i really wished they added a second version of the challenges where you're locked out of the weapons, especially against the bosses. Still, it's a fun mode.

Design-wise this game is far superior than the rest of the franchise when it comes to the additions of quality of life options, such as the ability of loading your save file in the middle of a progress, which is super useful if you are going for a no death run achievement, and the new ability to select special weapons from the right stick is super RAD!

The soundtrack is memorable, for the most part. one thing i hated is that the wily castle had only one soundtrack as i got used to playing the level from the old games with a different soundtrack in each 1 or 2 levels.

Finally, do i recommend this game ? absolutely yes to everyone, but the full price doesn't justify the amount of content that you get. i bought it for the sale price so i'm okay with it. 10/10

+ I love the graphics and the design
+ it feels really smooth (for the Megaman series that is ... the Down + Jump to slide feels still really klunky compared to dashing in the X or Zero series)
+ the bosses are innovative and don't feel all the same
+ I also really like the special weapons in this game

- the only difficult enemy to beat in the whole game is the clock -.- if you want to get all medals and achievements 90% of your playtime will be battling against time which in my opinion is the most unfun and frustrating thing ever and a lot of the challenges feel really similar in this regard (time attack, collecting balloons/medals, playthrough in less than 60 min).
- the mechanics for getting through the balloon paths in bounceman's stage are an absolute joke ... what a waste of lifetime trying to get through those. Also makes all time attacks and alikes for this stage even more frustrating when you can't beat it simply because you're stuck at one of those
- there is an item in the shop which is only unlockable when you log in on a saturday .... lol? what? why? that's just stupid design
- the two most powerful items in the game are unlocked post game ("NG+"), which would be fine, it's just that there is nothing to go for with them. The hardest achievements have to be done on the first playthrough or are in challenge mode, for which these upgrades are not available so there really isn't much to do with them. Instead of all those (in my opinion mainly unnecessary) time attack challenges I think they should really really really have made some kinda NG+ "challenge" or whatever where these upgrades actually show some value

I think the game itself is fun, but they ruin the player experience with too much stuff that they put in which is not really fun to play ... there's always gonna be a speedrun/no damage run community for these kinda games but I really think any game should be designed so casual players can get 100% if they try hard enough without devoting half of their lifes to it. And like I said these kinda challenges make ~90% of your playtime if you want to go for 100% and are really frustrating by design, since it's basically always screw up once -> okay restart from scratch, plus they mostly feel pretty similar... I personally also think it is really bad design if the hardest challenge is not some boss enemy or stage within the game but (BY FAR!) beating some timelimits

Really great Mega Man game. Despite its looks it's not that much easier than the older games. The game has a gimmick that involves slowing down time with a gauge. I thought it was stupid at first but it actually compliments the gameplay really well and doesn't make it too easy. It actually feels like a core of the gameplay and not a forced gimmick. As you play you'll realize where using it makes the most sense. And since it refills overtime you can't rely on it all the time so you're forced to use it only when you need it.

The only thing that's kinda subpar is the music but that's because the previous games have such great music and it's a high standard to live up to. Music is still decent regardless but they shoudl had chiptune versions of each song as an option. 

Boss battles are really creative and fresh compared to previous titles and the way difficulty is done feels extremely satisfying. When you get hurt or die it's usually your fault and you learn right away since the game does a good job of indicating what hurts you and exactly how enemies attack.

If you liked any of the previous MM games definitely give this one a try. Hoping the success of this game makes Capcom do a Mega Man X9.

89963304.review:
As a lifelong Mega Man fan, this isn't amazing, but it's worth playing if you're a fan or you just want to support future Mega Man releases. If you're going to buy it, I'd recommend getting it on sale.

Although all the elements of a classic Mega Man game are here, I felt it missed the mark. I got it on release and after a few stages put it down and didn't pick it back up until recently (when I bought it on Switch). There is a story, which is nice, but it doesn't draw you in, and the game is more frustrating than previous entries. 

The main flaw I had was the level design. It works like classic Mega Man games, where it shows you what you're in for, then slowly ramps it up, which is great. Unfortunately, levels seem to be longer than previous entries which I found more of an irritation than a benefit. The classic Mega Man difficulty is here, but so are several cheap death areas. With the lengthened levels, checkpoints aren't located in great places and you'll find yourself having to grind out longer areas of a stages several times before getting to the part that kills you. With certain levels, I found myself more frustrated than challenged. 

The other issue I had was the shop. I feel like the game was balanced around the shop rather than the shop being an added feature you can ignore. Enemies appear to drop less items and instead drop more screws (shop currency). If you need some health, it's rare you'll find it by killing an enemy, instead you'll need to rely on Energy Tanks. Of which you can hold 9. And cost almost nothing compared to the screws that drop. Same thing goes with life and weapon energy. I tried to avoid the shop at first, because I felt it made the game too easy, but without Energy Tanks, I literally couldn't refill my life. 

Then we have the Double Gear System. It's a neat concept, and I like that the bosses have it, but it kind of ruined the Mega Man feel for me. They're basically cheat codes you can activate mid-game. Boss too tough? Slow it down. Lava flow chasing you? Slow it down. Too many enemies? Slow it down. I tried my best not to use it because it felt way too powerful. In a perfect world, I feel like you should get it only after defeating all the robot masters. That way you can use it against Wily and see its affects in the boss rush, unfortunately, that wasn't the case. 

Although I did like the graphics, I felt Mega Man's sprite was terrible. I much prefer the sprites from 7 or 8. I also can't remember a single song from this game. Not even the intro became stuck in my head. If you leave a Mega Man game without humming a tune, something is wrong. 

Overall, I'm happy I played it, but probably won't touch it again and instead stick with any other entries.

89905606.review:
[h1]Mega Man 11[/h1]
[i]Rock em, sock em[/i]

[h1]Review[/h1]
After an eight year absence, I am happy to report that [b]Mega Man 11[/b] succeeds, but there are a few caveats. Let's be honest: it wouldn't take much for [b]Mega Man 11[/b] to not succeed in the eyes of the fans when you are springboarding off 2003's lacklustre, dead-in-it's tracks [b]Mega Man X7[/b] (which tried to transition the series into 3D with disastrous results), which only ended up taking the franchise to new levels of low that nearly saw the blue bomber tumble into notoriety with fans himself. The follow-up, [b]Mega Man X8[/b], didn't do much to elevate the franchise out of the muck within which it had found itself, with X8 never rising above mediocre. Many of us fans thought Mega Man was on his way to the retirement village to be sunsetted by Capcom after the throwback [b]Mega Man 10[/b] was released in 2010 feeling like a cash-in. The years long radio silence after that only further made it seem like Capcom had no clear path forward for the blue bomber and  fans started to wonder whether the franchise was finally on life support.

I will admit, as a huge fan of the late eighties originals of which [b]Mega Man 2[/b] is the high point, the return announcement in 2017 did catch me off guard. With creator Keiji Inafune now having moved on from Capcom, how could Capcom ever do without Inafune guiding the series back to life? Although we would soon all learn that Inafune's best days were probably behind him too after [b]Mighty No. 9[/b] failed to emerge successfully from under the shackles of the [b]Mega Man[/b] franchise, ending up an inferior product in almost every conceivable way from from mascot, to robot bosses, to world, and finally extended to the villain. The next question was with Inafune gone, could Capcom ever make the blue bomber relevant again?

Sadly, no as it seems like the days of Mega Man's relevance have long passed and are now assigned to history for keeping. When we first met him in 1987, platformers were the rock star's of gaming. They sold systems by virtue of the mascot alone  Now you would be lucky to find a big publisher willing to fund one outside of Nintendo. While the genre did have a bit of a resurgence in the early noughties when they went 3D and became gobbledegook collectathons, its mostly fallen to indie studios to keep the genre alive and quite frankly they have been doing a sterling job. Just look at some of the crazy and wonderful things with the genre they have been doing ([b]Super Meat Boy[/b] and [b]Celeste[/b] are classic examples of this). 

In many ways it kind of feels like the game succeeds by virtue of simply existing, especially for us fans starved of his presence but Capcom does a fairly good job of taking the series and modernising some of its mechanics but that is where it stops because the rest of the formula remains untouched from the original game - a blueprint that has been subsequently adhered to rigidly throughout the long running series. This legacy design that the series keeps on insisting including is now starting to feel more than a little archaic, ensuring there are very little to no surprises with each new release. It's at the point now where its become the franchises Achilles heel. You won't find any platforming moments of brilliance here, like the kinds of stuff on display in [b]Celeste[/b] or [b]Hollow Knight[/b]. It plays it very safe and is clearly made for long standing fans of the series, as if Capcom knew it was treading on thin ice with them.

If you were never much of a fan of the series, then [b]Mega Man 11[/b] is going to do little, if anything, to turn that around. Another thing I must mention is that it is also insanely hard, and that is probably going to drive a lot of people away. I had to drop it from normal difficulty (which is advised for mainstays of the series which I consider myself) to easy mode and I still struggled like mad to make headway with it. The first three Mega Man games are considered to be amongst the hardest games ever created, yet I could clear [b]Mega Man 1/2[/b] and [b]Mega Man 3[/b] in a single sitting back in the day while typing text messages to my dentist and doing tax calculations for my tax return. Yet here I couldn't even get through a single level of repeated trying in the five or so hours I banged my head against the normal difficulty before resigning myself to the fact that I must now officially be an old fart who has to play on baby settings.

As a fan I appreciate that Capcom has brought [b]Mega Man[/b] back from the dead and I appreciate the graphical update to modern HD graphics. Mega Man has never looked more clearer although I would love to see the series return back to its pixel roots, BUT when I say pixel, I am speaking along the lines of the gorgeous indie platform Kings and Queens of our current era ([b]Celeste[/b], [b]Blasphemous[/b] or even better yet [b]Children of Morta[/b] which has these incredibly highly detailed pixel counts that look utterly gorgeous) and not the 8-bit revival of [b]Mega Man 10[/b]. 

The reality here is that [b]Mega Man 11[/b] is not the return to form sequel many would have you believe. It's enjoyable but it's also not enjoyable to play in equal measure and is not one of his better adventures. I also found the eight Dr. Wily robots you need to defeat a little underwhelming from a mechanics and design standpoint. If Capcom is to continue [b]Mega Man[/b]'s adventures into the future, then I certainly hope they look into the history of the most celebrated and beloved platformers of our modern era that have all, almost exclusively, sprung from the indie scene because that is where [b]Mega Man[/b]'s true innovation and salvation lies. There is no point in trying to revive his best days. Let history keep record of those.

85057534.review:
After so many modern disappointments (Looking at you, Mighty No 9), this was a refreshing return to Classic Megaman à la MM4. The art is updated but doesn't feel gimmicky; it's true to what you loved about that era of MM. Although I love MM 2 and respect the way 9 and 10 threw back to the first 2 games in the franchise, Eleven is doing something different. If you like being able to charge the Megabuster and slide, this is the game for you! 

Let's face it, if you love Megaman, you are not that into novelty. The appeal of the game is about the comfort of familiar enemies and style of play. "Oh. Wily's at it again!"  Eight bosses, a skull castle and a boss rush and probably a "Oh-you-defeated-me--NOT!" fakeout and you're done. The franchise at its best is about conservative refinement over time. There is also something delightful about seeing familiar enemies like the Bubble Bats/ Battons, the beloved Metalls--practically the series' mascot--(and many, many others) with a fresh coat of pixels. 

As one review points out, the first screen of every level provides an especially atmospheric introduction to the stage. I would add that this is carried through to boss and mini-boss arenas, with backgrounds that give the 2D arena a sense of depth and place. This reminds me of some of the great background art in MMX, which I remember as being really exciting at the time. Although the explosion effects are a bit amped up in 11, I need to stress that the game just doesn't feel like the X series--without dashes and wall-gripping, your player doesn't move through levels the same way-- and I appreciate the distinction.

This makes the gear system is an interesting twist. I think it adds to the game in a way that is fun and feels natural. Because it's baked into the storyline so thoroughly, it feels like it might be unique to this game, but I would be happy to play more games that take advantage of it. 

My only real complaint is that the game does lag a bit on my system, which makes me joke that I'm in "Speed Gear" more of the time than I'd expected. Honestly, if you hate the gear system, you can play the entire game without it. My first playthrough only utilized it a couple of times, and I actually beat the game before I realized I could how to activate Double-Gear. It's been fun to use it on replays. I really appreciate how the game feels challenging, but the power-ups and difficulty levels make it appropriate for a wide range of players to enjoy. 

Boss designs are fun and just varied enough from the other games. The sprites for MM are rendered with more complexity (more keyframes) and more variation than a simple recolor. In the past, the games have struggled to figure out how to deal with Items/Rush and I feel like they have come home now by assigning him dedicated buttons. Yes, I do accidentally activate Rush from time to time, but this is a minor inconvenience compared to digging through a menu. The game also uses the right joy stick to let you quickly swap weapons (center-press to quickly get back to the Megabuster). If you liked using the bumpers to quick-swap weapons in the X-series, you will quickly get into this.  

I would go so far as to say that this is has replaced MM2 as my favorite classic MM game.

Megaman 11 absolutely blew me away EXCEPT for the really just abysmal music. Before I go on and gush about the gameplay, I HAVE to make it clear that the music in this game is just such an unbelievably egregious misstep for a Megaman game that it's hard to believe none of the developers realized that "Hey..this doesn't really sound like, or anywhere near on par with the Megaman series musical legacy, does it?" So yeah, in terms of what I've come to love about the franchise: looks, gameplay, and music, Megaman 11 is really missing a third of the pie right off the bat.

OK, let's ignore that unbelievably ridiculous oversight and get to the gameplay! It is AMAZING. Megaman games tend to shine more and more as you continue to play and Megaman 11 is a perfect example of this. As I became more experienced with the general movement and unique tools this game offers, the masterful level design really started to become apparent. It's almost difficult to describe to anyone who hasn't played it, but areas that may have first appeared tricky or time-consuming begin to reveal themselves as crazy-well thought out streamlined areas with multiple different solutions depending on your strategy/weapons. This has been a hallmark of the series since it began and is absolutely present here. One of the most exciting aspects of this game is the double-gear system; no, not the idea that you can use it, but that idea you can not use it. I had never considered that this gimmicky feeling system could be the key to level designs that easily rival the classic releases in-terms of difficulty, but playing through this game without using the double-gear system is an amazing experience that doesn't pull any punches. It's hard to overstate how awesomely difficult this game is to play through without use of double-gear and it really highlights the already very impressive level design all the more when it works just as well without using the main advertised gimmick. It ends up being a perfect way to keep the difficulty fans like myself want while also allowing newer players to jump in and have fun firing gigantic mega-buster blasts ('cause who doesn't want to do that?!).

While the graphics aren't quite as colorful as I'd like them, the designs of enemies and other characters are so on-point that I actually have some new favorite adorable enemies and found myself not noticing most of the issues I initially had on first reveal. In general, the graphics definitely hold up and didn't end up detracting from my experience.

To sum things up, if it weren't for the incredibly lackluster music, I'd be giving this game a 9 or 10 out of 10, but even with one of the most disappointing soundtracks in the series, I still found myself absolutely loving playing through this game and was always excited to jump back in and play levels again and again...and again and-etc. Just, please...improve the music!

79491842.review:
This is a fantastic refresh of the Mega Man franchise from the NES days. I really enjoy the updated visuals and solid "classic" Mega Man gameplay. It took a minute to my controller-button reflexes back after 25 or so years, but I got there eventually! Normal difficulty was a nice challenge for me, having not played any of these games in so long. Being able to buy and stock up power ups definitely made it a lot easier. Bosses are fun and have just enough of a backstory to stay interesting. I appreciate the fact that Tundra Man was into figure skating. Nice!

Replaying all the bosses in Wily's Fortress did not disappoint.

Gear system was interesting. It was not a core part of my play style, but it definitely came in handy in specific circumstances, e.g. advancing death wall segments. If you care to, this game can be as easy or hard as you want it to be. I think there's something here for everyone who enjoyed a Mega Man back in the '90s. I can also see this being a fun platformer for those new to the series.

Voice acting was a nice "modern" inclusion. I set the audio to Japanese and subtitles to English. I prefer to play games with voices in their "native" language.

I got this game on sale, but regular price is not so bad. I paid fifty bux for Mega Man 6 for the NES in 1994. Adjusting for inflation, that's about eighty-eight bux today. There's some replayability here if you go for the challenges and/or try to rack up the Steam achievements.

79395071.review:
Oh God Yes, as far as Megaman goes this is amazing, it's got it all
-Awesome level and Enemy designs, that still subtly teach you everything through gameplay. it's Nuts!
-Awesome semi OP abilities, ok Burning Torch is ridiculous ;D
-And to top we got the double gear system which just adds some great complexity that enhances not only the gameplay but even feeds into the narrative. It's great, even bosses have access to this system. I love it. 

[b] Nitpicks [/b]
As ridiculously polished and refined the Megaman formula is at this point there are definitely nitpicks. Artifacts of by gone eras that still haunt the Megaman games that I feel like we can leave behind. 
Blasphemous I know, but hear me out. 

-Respawning enemies? In 2020!?
In the old days this made some amount of sense as memory size was limited and the whole stage was never loaded in one go. So in side scrolling sections you could always respawn enemies endlessly as long as you allowed the enemy trigger to reenter the screen over and over again.
Why is this still a thing?! ;D
I feel like Capcom is just raking in the nostalgia with this one. 

-Limit jumps, jumps that require very few pixels of error.
 When a Gap is almost exactly as long as Megaman's jump, while enemies are abound mind you. That can just get frustrating.... but what if this was a jump over a deathdrop.... OR A PIT OF SPIKES??!!?
That's really classic Megaman at its worst. I hate it, I hate dying to it, I hate restarting the whole blasting stage because of it. Aaahhhh!!
At least there's a store now that gives you a bird to save you and that saves you when you fall into spikes.... tho most of the time the bird drops me into the abyss anyway.... like 3 times in a row until i'm out of birds.... just kill me now.... ;D

-While we're on the subject... FUCKING SPIKES!
Is this really necessary? One hit kill to spikes? I mean since Megaman 1 on the gameboy we all purposely jumped into an enemy just go get a damage boost to walk past the spikes right?
If you tell me you never done that You're lying mister ;D
From a Game Design Standpoint, this is a bug that needs fixing imho. 

-The whole continue situation is wonky... I can't quite remember where it came from. 
In MM11 you always start with 5 lives. But when you beat a stage with 1 life left you can start the next stage with... that remaining 1 life. Then you can kick your butt down a cliff to get your 5 lives that you deserve, comawn ;D 
I really don't understand this one, just give us our lives man. 

-Another thought I have, but this gets really into changing a core aspect of the Megaman formula. 
What if... enemies and projectiles could NOT pass through walls...... 
What do you guys think? Too crazy?
I think this would make less exploits possible, cause literally no enemy is out of fire range with these transdimensional walls everywhere that allow everything to pass through. 
This would allow for new kinds of enemy and level design. I would dig it. 

But ye, Awesome Game. A tad short maybe, but there's challenges too so. You can spend a lot of hours with this.

78448915.review:
One of the best Mega Man games. A masterfully crafted, gorgeous gameplay experience from start to finish that manages to be original by introducing the new "Double Gear" speed/power mechanic while still remaining true to the series. Impressive design, direction, and presentation with great voice acting, a ton of character, wonderful bosses, and some of the most diverse and well-rounded weapons in the series. Just a solid entry to the series all around and a great action platformer. Lastly, the game introduces a new quick-select option for weapons and it really ups the ante for speedruns while making blasting through levels feel smooth and organic no matter how aggressively someone is playing.

If you're a Mega Man veteran, Superhero difficulty feels great and the standard difficulty is on par with that of other games in the series. There are more casual-friendly difficulties too, making the game a lot more approachable to newcomers than previous iterations. The game also includes a wide array of fun optional challenges much like those in the Legacy Collections. This includes replay sharing, making the leaderboards actually meaningful (and also educational when trying to improve). 

In terms of the technical side of things, the game is well optimized. Never had any frame drops at 4k with everything maxed. Very smooth. Never encountered any bugs but the new mechanic does have a quirk to it where depending on how/when we activate the gears, we may be unable to jump for a few frames. Mildly annoying at first until realizing what's happening, then it just becomes an understandable game rule. 

This is a must have for Mega Man fans. Action platformer fans should strongly consider this. This is also likely the best game for players to start on if they're completely new to the series. If you're the kind of person who appreciates Mega Man for its gameplay, it's worth it at full price. If you're the kind of person who's done with a game after they beat it on any difficulty, you may want to wait for a sale as much of the value comes from replaying/mastering the game and doing the achievements and challenges.

78156281.review:
Our fav 8-Bit game is back into action with new and better visuals. Some new mechanics were added to the game, which enhances the gameplay, making it more fun. Even with all the alterations, the game still feels the same as its predecessors. Even the cinematics have the same vibe as of the old game, but it’s definitely an improvement. The showcase of the double gear mechanism was a risky transit, as it might have influenced the former mega man players that have built muscle memory, but surprisingly it doesn’t ruin the fun and appends more to it. This game will act as a foundation for new mega man games because of the extension of new controls.

[h1][b]Gameplay:[/b][/h1]
Gameplay starts with a great cinematic, which will establish a connection between you and the game’s story. There are no extra options to choose from, either play the game or just quit. You will be given nine stages to clear, with your preferred difficulty. Don’t worry if this is your first mega man game as there’s an option to play with infinite lives. But that doesn’t signify that it will be super easy as there still will be a hurdle because unlimited lives only respawn you on a checkpoint, which implies, you still have to clear it. You can choose any stage clearance order as there is no restriction. Every completed level will give you an enemy’s weapon that you can switch anytime at any level. With all the old controls of jump, fire, and slide, it also adds a new concept of the double gear system, which gives you the option to slow time or fire multiple shots. You might think slowing time might ruin the challenge, but actually, it doesn’t. The game is still challenging and do-able at the same time. To truly experience a challenge, you can play with the default number of lives or can use “extra powers” that are available in the shop. All mega man lovers will enjoy this one.

[h1][b]Graphics:[/b][/h1]
Even shifting to a 2.5D game, brilliant work done in keeping the touch of its predecessors. The graphics look wondrous. The colors are vibrant and balance the entire scene significantly. You will observe a lot of detailing and additional elements like falling off a crane, underwater propulsions during the levels. Your character won’t get saturated with the background view, as it's intelligently made. There are no options available to change graphic settings, making everyone see the equivalent quality of design. The game runs smoothly on low rigs, making it popular among gamers. Converting an 8-Bit game is pretty tricky because you might lose the intensity the game had before, but mega man is an exception, as the game has only improved in this aspect.

[h1][b]Main Pros and Cons:[/b][/h1]

[b]Pros-[/b]
[list]
    [*]Challenging and do-able
    [*]Great visuals
    [*]Easy to learn controls
    [*]Double gear mechanism added to game
    [*]Affordable price even being a licensed product
    [*]Wide range of age playability 
[/list]

[b]Cons-[/b]
[list]
    [*]Short story
    [*]Problems with save data
    [*]Hidden areas are removed, which was a fun aspect in old series
    [*]Shop seems pointless 
    [*]Bosses are not challenging
[/list]

76795536.review:
A long running and beloved franchise by many fans, Mega Man 11 is a revival of the once discarded series by Capcom. Years after 10, it was an astonishing surprise that the new entry would mark a return to the modern day. And what a return the game is. Mega Man 11 is a masterclass in gameplay and mechanics in it's respective classic series.

The overall feel of the game is just like how it is like its predecessors: tight and responsive. Jumping, shooting, and sliding all feel incredible and do not suffer any sort of input delay whatsoever.

Weapons: A largely contested discussion for many players, all the weapons have a vast amount of utility in the stages and not be restricted to use as robot master weaknesses. Scramble Thunder is a reliable ground-hunting weapon that can destroy. Block Dropper can hit enemies from a distance and anything from above. No matter the situation, there are multiple answers to a problem that gives Mega Man 11 that love and care which makes every new playthrough different.

Double Gear System: The Double Gear System is 11's special gimmick that allows the player a choice decision of the Power Gear and the Speed Gear. While the game encourages players to make use of the Double Gear, these are not required to complete the game as all the stages are completely possible without them. Undeniably though, the utility of the gears boosts Mega Man's potential greatly. Power Gear gives extra power, boosting weapons; Speed Gear slows down Mega Man and his environment. A special item from the shop in the game can even prevent Mega Man from slowing himself down.

Difficulty: It goes without saying that 11 is a hard game and may require 2 hours to complete for a new player. Checkpoints are sparse throughout the stages and because this game has a life system, getting a game over is punishing, pushing a player back to the start. The sparse checkpoints apply towards Normal and Superhero mode, but Newcomer and Casual gives a casual player more checkpoints. Even with checkpoints, quick observation and strong patience is greatly advised to make it through this game.

My honest opinion: love it!

75932994.review:
The blue bomber is back in action, better than ever!

After it's journey back to the retro 8-bit days with 9 and 10, Mega Man 11 offers a refreshing new look both in visuals and gameplay mechanics. Aside from classic buster charge and slide, Mega Man acquired the Double Gear System, which allows for a more flexible approach not only to navigating the stages but to combat as well.

Music is as good as expected, with a couple of really catchy and memorable tunes. It even has voice acting now! Of the good kind! (at least that's the case in Japanese...)

Special mention to a new feature: you can now cycle through your boss abilities just by moving the right-stick! How is it that this simple thing wasn't...well... a thing since the dualshock era?! It's really useful!

Mega Man fan or not, if you like action platforming you NEED to play this game. You will not regret it.

74479330.review:
Mega Man 11 is a great game. It's not the best Mega Man game ever (especially when you start to consider the X, ZX, and Zero series) but it is worth the price by far. It's a return to form for the Blue Bomber, with tight controls and excellent platforming. The level design is strong, the visuals are great, the music is good too. Where it falls flat is not in poor design, it's simply that the older games were just stronger performers, for the most part. The music is good, but not nearly as good as, say, Mega Man 2. The game lacks Mega Man X's verticality and speed, but if I were to just compare it to the mainline Mega Man series, then the game is good, but not stand-out from the originals. The Double Gear system, which is new to the series, is fun, but not really game-changing. I found myself forgetting I had it as an option for much of the game, and when I did start to regularly incorporate it, I found myself relying almost exclusively on the Speed gear, using the Power Gear in a few select scenarios. 

All that being said, it is very much a Mega Man game. Not a spin-off, not a spiritual successor, and not some cheap cash-grab with Mega's face plastered on it. If you enjoyed the old Mega Man games, you'll enjoy this too and I would highly recommend getting this entry. If you've never played a Mega Man game before, this game might be a great place to start, with it's modernized gameplay (like the power select wheel) and it's adjustable difficulty options. A great game at a fair price.

72139647.review:
This game is really well done for the most part. The only real complaint I have is with the menus; the navigation could have been much better. The most noticeable flaw is that there is no direct exiting the game. If you are in a level and want to quit, you have to first exit the level before quitting the game. Even in the stage select, you are going to have to exit to the main screen before quitting. It might seem petty, but this is pretty poor design and gets annoying fast.

As for the actual game, it's a blast. I know people have said that it's easy, but you can really make it as challenging as you want by choosing not to use the purchasable upgrades, trying to finish bosses "out of order", etc.

Some of the music could be better and I don't care for the style of voice acting, but those are personal preferences. The voices can thankfully be turned off so you don't have to listen to the gear activation lines if you don't want to.

As for the gears, they are a cool addition to the series. The slow gear quickly becomes an important aspect on some of the more challenging levels.

Overall, totally worthy addition to the Mega Man series. 7/10.

71924415.review:
Mega Man 11 is a game made with obvious talent that is held back for the sake of tradition. It is a Mega Man game in the truest sense, plucked straight out of the nineties. The controls and level environments have aged pretty well, but the atrocious difficulty spikes, annoying enemy designs, unsatisfying rock-paper-scissors boss weakness system and clunky UI have not. The music is well-composed but limited in its variability and duration, presumably just because that's how the old games were. All of these things combine into a noticeably dated experience with cheap, artificial difficulty where most of the game is dedicated to avoiding gameplay as much as possible. If you are a huge classic Mega Man fan, pick it up, as it fits right in with the rest of the series with very little changed. Otherwise, I would avoid it and pick one of the many superior modern platformers. 

4/10

71917056.review:
After the success of the Mega Man Legacy Collection, and the failure of Mighty Number 9, a team at Capcom, led by some of the team who worked on Mega Man 7, decided to take a crack at developing a new Mega Man title. The team played every single Mega Man title prior to developing the game, including Mega Man X6 and X7. The cancelled Mega Man games in the early 2010s were due to Inafune leaving the company, and not out of spite, but because they felt they couldn't make any games without him. And Bad Box Art Mega Man in Tekken X Street Fighter? He was supposed to be just a funny inclusion - he was in development before all the games were cancelled. Bad timing. Why do I bring all this up? Just to dispel any rumors or speculation you may have heard over the years. 

Did the team succeed without Inafune? I think so. Mega Man 11 is your standard classic Mega Man game; 8 robot masters, you get a new weapon after beating a stage, etc. What it adds this time to differentiate itself from the previous entries, aside from the new visual style, is the double gear system. Despite the game's marketing, the double gear system is not made to appeal to newcommers, it was made to push what the designers could throw at the player. I could sort of compare the system to the chainsaw in Doom Eternal, you can beat the game without using it, but you are seriously handicapping yourself. 

The game is hard no doubt, but not as hard as Mega Man 9 (edit: doesn't mean I don't love Mega Man 9 though) or Mega Man and Bass thankfully. I suggest you start on Casual for your first playthrough regardless if you're new or not. Normal is doable, but it can be a bit frustrating since they've reduced the number of checkpoints per stage on that difficulty. I understand increasing damage taken and less starting lives. Checkpoints; why? And in about half the stages in the game, there is at least one obstacle that makes me grit my teeth like the last section in Tundra Man's stage or the "V" spike formation in Acid Man's. Luckily, the shop from Mega Man 7 returns so you can stock up on items and new perks between stages to make your game much easier. Be sure to use your gears and special weapons as well. 

tl;dr - a solid entry in the Mega Man series. Hard, but doable as long as you use the gears and benefits offered. Don't think it's the best place to jump in for newcomers.

71913784.review: Fun. Formulaic, but fun. It's classic Mega Man that fans have to come to expect and love. After 10 mainline games and way too many spin-offs what new things does the Blue Bomber bring to the table? Frankly, not a lot. The biggest innovation (and selling point) is the "Double Gear" system. Essentially, it's a power-up which allows for Mega Man to either slow down time or increase the power on his weapons. However, if your health is low enough you can combine the gears together (yay...) While I did find this addition to be useful (mainly, the time gear); I think that it overall subtracted from the experience. It makes the game too easy and predictable. The difficulty of entire platforming segments is completely negated when you just slow down time and pass all the enemies. Bosses suffer from the gears as well. Each boss has their standard form, but will morph using the gears during battle. Most of the time they become incredibly fast which forces you to just slow down time. This leads to very similar-feeling boss fights. If you do happen to have problems with a boss, the shop is readily stocked with E-Tanks, W-Tanks, extra lives, etc. Because of this, the challenge in the game resides solely in the levels. Be forewarned, that the levels in this game are extremely long. Other reviewers have mentioned this and it is very much true. I feel like I could complete 2-3 levels from the NES games before I beat one level in Mega Man 11. They also got stingy with the checkpoints for some reason. I could go on and on about things that I didn't like such as the synth-heavy soundtrack (but that might be due to the fact that I'm spoiled by the Mega Man X OSTs). There were also a bunch of minor nitpicks I had with the game (voice acting, lip-syncing). Despite this, the formula just works. The power-ups are fun and the game is short enough to complete in one sitting; although I wouldn't recommend it. If you're a Mega-Man veteran, I'd say it's worth a purchase during a Steam Sale. However, if you've never played a game in the series before, there's far, far better titles out there. 6.5/10.

71065082.review:
And MegaMan returns wonderfully as ever, this is a good approach after being death for a long time, with some doubts about it and the reception it went pretty well, even though it's not the best game still a good return.

First of all, finally we have a nice presentation and graphics, after being stuck with pixelart from NES, this is something fresh that we needed before, but still having some issues, some animations are pretty wierd and stiff likes MegaMan run animation, but only a few ones have this issue. Other problem is some times the contrast of color is too high in the background in some moments but you can still see the diference between MegaMan, the platforms, enemies and background which is great, altough some times you can still confuse with that.

Then there is the soundtrack ... which is not bad enough, but the instrumentalization used here is not very complex and makes the most of the soundtrack is not remarkable ... except for the theme of FuseMan, which is an incredible theme that it is very dynamic for the type of level it is.

The gameplay is very good, the controls are nice and even better than before, the physics is similar but slightly changed, like the little boost you gained in the previous game when you fell from a long distance was removed, which can cause some problems to calculate the jumps. Having dedicated buttons for Rush is very intuitive, it caused a lot of trouble switching between them, and having a quick switch between weapons goes a long way to having a better reaction speed. Then there is the theme game design, somewhat disappointing is that the exploration parts and alternate routes are not shown here, making it less replayable, no collectibles, instead we have more items in the store that can be unlocked for your buy in different ways, it's not that bad, but it makes the challenge a little easy and less immersive with the player when they are easy to unlock, then farm. After that, there are the mechanics of the levels, most of them are very unique, and yes, they can be a bit tedious, but the game teaches you how this mechanic works without dying the first time you see it. ... and then, sometimes you are just BounceMan, as far as the position of the enemies are well done, although sometimes they are very redundant but without getting to the point of being tedious. And for the last, the difficulty, the game allows you to choose the difficulty, it helps new players to understand the basics of the game if you are a new player or a hardcore experience if you want a challenge, the game balances a In this way, The easiest is the best defense, but the currency of the game (in this case, the screws) has less possibilities of being thrown by the enemies, while the most difficult is the opposite.


It's one of the good games from the classic MegaMan, it gives you a fresh new experience that makes you feel like the other old MegaMan that existed in the past, even if it's too far to be the best of all.

Pros:
>It's megaman/rockman.  You KNOW those controls are tight.
>Multiple difficulty settings ranging from "I literally don't know what a controller is" to "I wind down from work by dying a lot in video games."  The game is extremely accessible.
>All of the weapons are useful
>The double gear system is a great, natural-feeling extension of mega/rock's moveset.  It doesn't feel tacked-on.
 
Cons: 
>By megaman standards, these stages are LONG.  The stages of most other MM games would end by the midbosses of these stages.
>The double-gear system is almost required in certain segments if you don't have literally superhuman reflexes, so purists might have trouble with the game. 
>Super personal hot take: The idea behind bounce man's stage is great, but some of the jumps are frustrating

Overall:
The game is a great addition to the magaman/rockman mainline series.  The double-gear system keeps things fresh and doesn't overstay its welcome, but purists who are slow on the uptake may find themselves frustrated with hard-to-dodge boss patterns and difficult platforming.

69023332.review:
Why It Rocks:
1- Outstanding modern 2.5D graphic style from the previous installments of the classic series instead of the retro, 8-bit style that has been overused in the series.

2- It is significantly more story driven than previous Mega Man games, going into the backstory behind why Light and Willy became enemies.

3- The new Double Gear System allows you to either move really fast or greatly increase your attack power; at the same time this mechanic can't be overused due to a very strict timer so the player can't abuse it.

4- Unlike Mega Man 9 and Mega Man 10, sliding and charging mechanics have returned.

5- Though not entirely gone, instant-kill death traps and cheap jumps are significantly less common than in previous games so the game relies less on fake difficulty.

6- For newcomers, lower difficulties place checkpoints more frequently and start the player with more lives which makes the game a lot less punishing for inexperienced players. In regular difficulties for more experienced players however, the game is as challenging as the other Mega Man games.

7- The ending takes a rather fun jab at the fact that Dr. Wily always begs for forgiveness every time he is defeated.

Something that I really HATED:
1- Both Proto Man and Bass don't appear in this game for some reason, not even as DLC.

2- There are still some cheap deaths occasionally, i.e. there are some places that trick you into falling to your doom.

3- Underwhelming Wily Fortress. It only has two proper stages, a boss rush without a Wily boss, and a very short fourth stage that leads to the Wily Machine 11.

I want to start by saying I love the Megaman franchise. However, the level design of this game is atrocious. Every stage is a repetition of cruelly placed pits, spikes, or combinations of enemies that making platforming feel awful/rage-inducing. The checkpoints are spaced so far apart that even if you succeed at a very difficult portion of a stage, you'll probably have to play it numerous times. Less than half of the E tanks or extra lives are worth trying to get because you'll probably lose more than that getting it. Just buy everything you need from the store.

The special items are designed for mass purchasing so you don't actually die from pits or spikes. So playing each stage is a slog that feels really unpleasant. Nevermind that if you are hit by an enemy, you'll probably die due to the long stun timer. If you liked the smooth movement and finesse from the X or Z games, this has none of that.

67840488.review:
5/10 Terrible. Purely cheaply designed and aggravation inducing levels, mitigated by the ability to save currency and hoard up usable help items, combined with a new double gear system you have to use to survive. Previous skill/memory reliant Megaman is gone, replaced by this cheap hit fest that they knowingly designed as a cheap hit fest which is why they put in an ample amount of tools to help with the hair pulling aggravation factor.

It starts out with a boring 5 minute long opening sequence that is so hokey and Leave-It-To-Beaverish that it's like something from the Saturday morning Megaman cartoon. There's another really long cutscene halfway through the game that I just ended up skipping.

Unlike past Megaman's which have some of the best game music of all time, the music here is as generic and unmemorable as it gets. It sounds like stock music that comes as a free template in a music maker program.

I've played all Megaman games (at least 1-11. the X series, and some others) and from what I can remember none of them even come close to having as cheap of levels and instant deaths as this game does. Constant areas designed to purposely cause relentless aggravation until you just basically use the built in help system they added because they knew exactly how aggravating they were making this game. Well the X series on SNES was a nightmare too. This game is so aggravating that they added currency and the ability to buy items to help you in each level. You can buy a stockpile of extra lives, health tanks, shoes that you can use 3 times a level to not die in one hit from spikes, a robot item that pulls you out of death pits and lets you keep going up to 3 times per level, a shield that lets you take half dmg in the current level until you either die or beat it, and a bunch of permanent upgrades you can install. So either you are a masochist and do the game without any of these things, or buy them and then it's way too easy.

Either way, you still have a new double gear system where you can press LB to increase firepower or RB to slow down everything around you. Again, you can either do parts like on the fire stage where you are running to the right away from a wall of one-hit death flame following you, where you are only ever 2 seconds ahead of it at most, or you slow down time and it becomes a cake walk.

The bosses are no different. Even with the right blaster attachment to do max dmg to a certain boss, all of them have pretty much almost totally un-dodgeable attack patterns. Like Rockman for instance. He turns into a big rock golem robot, backs you against a wall, slaps his entire hand down in the only space you have to stand, so you just take a hit. I will be damned if I know how to dodge that and many other boss attacks so instead I just use my stored up items to keep replenishing my life bar and using the gear system, while switching around to find which gun attachment is the bosses weakness. Piece of cake then.

For a further slap in the fucking face, the Dr. Wily fight is insultingly easy. I could've done it without any extra powerups or health items, and I'm not kidding that if I fought him a second time I probably could beat him with my eyes closed.

5/10 $7 wasted. They could've came up with something better than this game's misplaced gimmicks and horribly misplaced forced hits and deaths because of their a--holeish enemy and trap placement.

66850679.review:
I hate to give Megaman a bad review as its been a long time since I've played a Megaman game. But I just didn't enjoy this as much as I thought I would. It isn't a bad game, just an uninspired one. The game feels dated and although I personally didn't play on the higher difficulties I did play through the whole game.

Lets note, this isn't a bad game. Its not a great game either. Its just okay. But Okay for a $30 game isn't worth it for me personally when I have so many other games I could buy that offer far greater enjoyment at a lower price.

Lets go through some of my personal gripes about the game. I didn't care for the English voice actor for Megaman, or any of the characters really. I ended up switching to Japanese because I didn't care for them, which helped a bit but the voice acting in either wasn't great. Some of the powerups were finicky and the Gear system I feel added nothing to the game in terms of gameplay. Yeah, it changed stuff up a little bit but it really didn't evolve the fight's in any meaningful way. I used it sparingly even though I could have used it more just because it didn't feel good to use.

The levels themselves were typical Megaman. Which is perfectly fine, but I found myself more frustrated as an enemy would hit stun me off a cliff. This is likely due to my own skill, but it didn't make me want to keep playing the game.

The parts system wasn't all that interesting either. Mostly seeming to be just a straight upgrade and not giving me real choices on what to choose. I didn't feel like it really added much to the experience.

The bonus challenges are fine, but this seems to be more for the Hardcore Megaman fans than someone like myself. Megaman 11 didn't capture me enough to want to play them. And the overall lack of other content to consume this game will likely sit in my steam library never to be touched again.

I'm not saying this is a bad game. its not. If you love Megaman, you'll love this game. If you're more Casual like me I'd suggest waiting for it to go on sale.

Just finished this one, and I have to say I'm very disappointed in the amount of content in this game. It's enjoyable, but for the price tag, falls short of what I expected. I'm a long time fan of the MegaManX series and this one doesn't even touch those - there's simply so little content. There are literally zero secrets in this game as far as I can tell. No way to alter your environment whatsoever. It was somewhat fun and a bit of a challenge, for ~4 hours of total gameplay. For the price, I would call this game a ripoff. Also the voice acting and dialog is all terrible.

MegaMan purists will probably respond that this game was as promised in that it's the exact same format as the classic games, which it is - but in a prettier package. The lack of any sense of accomplishment and the child-like simplicity has let me down, though.

65946438.review:
It is super solid. The option to play with Japanese voices makes the game extremely playable. I do wish there was an option to turn the text to a more accurate version of the Japanese audio, but I know that's fairly impossible for video games to pull off, so I can't really count that as a negative. I also wish there was an option to have subtitles for every bit of dialog spoken during gameplay, and maybe even sound effects, for the hearing impaired, ya'know? Like how Valve does it in their games.

The designs are great, the gameplay feels great. It's just the right amount of difficulty, plus you can chose what difficulty you want to play at. It's short, but that makes it replayable. I feel like I could pick this up again tomorrow and play it at a higher difficulty.

This could easily be someone's favorite Megaman game. It does have a semi-budgety feel compared to Resident Evil 2 Remake, but I consider that to be one of its strengths. It's budgety design adds to the gameplay and it's uncompromising in its fun.

I think this is a great step for Capcom, and for the game industry in general. The real audio rules supreme, none of that dubbed garbage.

65703528.review:
Solid addition to the series, and such a natural transition to 3D. Still rides the nostalgia waves of 9 and 10 without betraying the series' feel, *and* while entirely freshening up the formula with the double gear system.

TBH, mixed feelings about the DG system. Controller setup was awkward trying to bounce between those two powers, and the acquired boss powers, all while trying to do careful bullet-hell stye timed jumps to avoid certain death. The level design of 11 provides some incredibly difficult challenges (hello Wily stage 1 and all the fall deaths*), *but* it also provides extra lives and life-saving items like no other MM game before it. Meaning you enter -- at least after the first handful -- every single stage with upwards of 9 lives, 9 energy tanks, and 9 weapons tanks. Auto's store returns, and earning bolts to spend is easier than ever before. It honestly felt like I was on easy mode or something with how much money they throw at you, and how many zeros are on your bolt bank despite everything in the shop being dirt cheap.

Went on a bit of a tangent there, but gosh dang the store and plethora of cash felt weird.

The story's bonkers. I mean, it's Mega Man, so the story's always a shallow excuse to play, and mostly just there for kicks, but, like...Dr. Light gets called out by Wily for plagiarizing his work at one point, and...I mean, he totally does. And then he does it more. And again. And the game ends on a big laugh with him absolutely stealing the hell out of Wily's work for his personal benefit. It's kinda messed up, if you think about it. But this is Mega Man, so why bother.

65606382.review:
Dr. Wily is back and up to his old tricks again. Luckily, Mega Man is more than ready for the job. Not only is this the first official classic Mega Man game since 2010, but it’s also the first without Keiji Inafune at the helm. So, how does it fare? Let’s dive right in. This is Mega Man 11.

[h1]The Good[/h1][i]The graphics and presentation are amazing.[/i]

The area that stuck to me the most for Mega Man 11 has to be the presentation of the game. The visual design of the stages, as well as the background, are very well done, while the enemies and robot masters are designed well that they don’t stand out from the presentation.

The special weapons change that Mega Man gets was a nice change up, considering that the previous games in the series only gave him a colour swap. There aren’t too many cutscenes in the game, but for the ones that are here, they’re all presented very well, although I don’t exactly understand why there’s a chicken leg cooking in Dr. Light’s laboratory.


[h1]The Bad[/h1][i]Where’s Proto Man?[/i]

One thing I couldn’t help but notice missing from the game was Proto Man. There was no mention of him in any of the cutscenes, no interactions possible in the game, and I’ve searched hard for hidden areas that he might’ve be hiding in, similar to how he was hidden in Mega Man 7.

Proto Man can be looked at as an often-forgotten character, but it’s still a bummer that he’s not anywhere to be found. This would be his first absence the main series since his debut in Mega Man 3.


[h1]The Ugly[/h1][i]Double Gear feature nice, but have some complaints.[/i]

New to Mega Man 11 is the Double Gear system, a device which can either power up your Mega Buster with the Power Gear, or slow down time to maneuver through difficult situations with the Speed Gear. Overall, it’s a welcome feature, but I do have some “nitpicking” issues with them.

The first is that when you use the Speed Gear for the first time, it slows down everything, including Mega Man. This can be fixed with a part you can purchase later on. The second is when you use the Power Gear with the enemy special weapons. The combination makes the attacks perform a stronger variation of the basic attack. Something that the Mega Man X series first introduced. It just bothers me that the developers decided to go with this option, considering the X series is supposed to be after.


My final take for Mega Man 11 is that it’s a great game. The negatives that I’ve noted in this review are more personal nitpicks more than anything else. If you were interested in getting this game, you should definitely consider it.

[h1]Developers (Headquarters)[/h1]
[list]
    [*]Capcom (Osaka, Japan)
[/list]

Oh man... it sucks to have to say this, but this is [b]really[/b] disappointing.
 
It's either too hard or too easy depending on the setting you choose (meaning that 'newcomer' is too easy and the other 3 are bullsh*t), except that it is also [b]both[/b] too hard [i]and[/i] too easy at times, seeing as bosses can be [b]HARD cheesed[/b] with the Pile Driver attack + Speed Gear, but getting to them requires going through way too long levels shock full of [b]instakills[/b] (which are just straightly thrown out the windows in the first difficulty, since you're [i][b]PERMANENTLY IMMUNE[/b][/i] to them, so they won't even damage you). 

From enemies [b]appearing out of the blue to throw you into a hole[/b] and make you replay an entire section (or stage) all over to jumps that sometimes need to be pixel-perfect, Megaman XI made me wanna shove something far up my [i]@$$[/i] way harder than any other game has ever. This is not 'The Dark Souls of platformers' nor is it 'as hard as Cuphead', it's just full of annoying things and bad decisions that makes it look like it was developed by a small indie studio.

Having said that, if you [b]REALLY[/b] like Megaman, buy it on sale and play it on the easiest setting to avoid having the hardest rage outburst of your life. It blows my mind how they were able to maul this franchise like this...

63514316.review:
Inti Creates, eat your heart out. THIS is how you revive a character. You don't strip them of features that made them great, you evolve and expand upon what they can do while still retaining what made the gameplay so darn good in past titles. Also, notice how much more lenient the game is with instant death obstacles! It's nowhere near as bad as 9 and 10 were with them. The weapons are way more fun to use, too! I can't think of one I don't like, and the Double Gear System is phenomenal!

It's also worth noting that you can, in fact, continue a series without just placing constant nostalgia bait throughout. Rather than going for the approach of "Hey, it's this thing from that game! Please clap." every few stages (if not most stages), you can try something like, I dunno, INNOVATING. The Double Gear system is a fantastic innovation and lends itself seamlessly to the game feel and flow of Mega Man. You can slow actions down for more leniancy for mistakes or tough moments, you can power your Buster AND Special Weapons up for added effects and improved power. This new system is easy to grasp and get into using and comes with the added bonus of being a fresh new toy to play with without sacrificing anything that worked previously. It's just a solid, good addition to something that already worked. Fancy that.

Honestly, 11 almost beats out 6 and 7 as my favorites of the Classic Mega Man games! The game not only proves itself to be strong enough to stand on its own, it's also just darn fun to replay over and over again! It captures what makes Mega Man so addictive and enjoyable the whole way through, and while the Wily Stages don't have as much meat on them as they used to, 11's stage design is so strong that it really doesn't matter if the game is shorter than the other titles. Without a doubt, one of my new favorite games in the franchise. Mega Man 11 isn't just a great Mega Man game, it's a brilliant return to form that anyone who loves platformers is bound to have a great time with. A must-have game for your library!

Mega Meh. It's not a bad game but not good either. And it's far from being a decent installment for such a classic franchise as Mega Man. The graphics aren't exactly ugly but they're pretty sloppy when compared to the superb pixel art that Mega Man always used to have across the years. The challenge and gameplay mechanics are OK, the game is a breeze when compared to any other installment and the uninspired double gear device is only useful at speed mode, LOL. The shop is a chore, there aren't interesting items or parts to be acquired and the voices are really annoying when you're buying the same item over and over again like extra lives or energy tanks, LOL. The achievements are unusual and kind of strange, some of them concerning how you do in your "first play" through the game, WTH? The music is bland, forgettable and generic, just to think about how Mega Man soundtracks used to be a huge influence to listeners and composers as people still record renditions of timeless Mega Man hits all over the internet. And the poor soundtrack was the most disappointing game feature to me.

The Mega Man series inspired a whole generation of gamers and developers once but now it's sad to realize that the creator has the same strength - or even lower - than his creatures.

61457214.review: It's been so long since we've had a new Mega Man game, and this was well worth the wait!  I'm so glad that Capcom didn't take the easy route and just throw another 8-bit nostalgic cash grab at us; I still would've bought it, but it's great that they're willing to try new things.  They still did a great job of keeping enough of the old, though, so it's still Mega Man, but it's quite fresh.  The main new mechanic is the Double Gear system, which allows you... well... it's basically Devil Trigger, but you choose between power and speed.  With the power boost, you can use charged up versions of your weapons, a la Mega Man X; and with the speed boost, you move in bullet time.  It's implemented very well, but for longtime fans, like myself, you have to train yourself to actually use it, or the Wily castle stages are going to kick your teeth out, even if you made it through all of the robot master stages oldschool.  I don't really want to say much else, but I fully approve of this new Mega Man, and am excited to see what comes next!

61339163.review:
Mega Man's return after a long hiatus is a good, solid return, but lacking visibly in important areas. The gameplay is reasonably tuned around the new Double Gear system, but challenges in the levels can feel entirely dependent upon the system rather than being built to be enhanced by its use. The music features some phenomenal tracks and the graphics got a face lift, but the graphics also serve to hamper platforming in some instances, particularly when precision is involved, as the window seems unreasonably tight and obscure in some instances. 

The story is also really nothing to write home about, but then who's playing a classic Mega Man for a story that's been beaten into the ground time and time again, with the same, tired old villain? It would be nice to see a new direction for a Mega Man story for once, one that sticks to it this time, instead of a last minute Wily reveal. The additional challenges post game completion make for some nice time wasters, but earning the gold medals requires a heavy amount of dedication with the sole reward being an achievement, I think, and satisfaction of a "job well done", no other in-game benefits or other cool in-game rewards for it, really.

This game overall scores an 8/10 from me. A good Mega Man installment to come back on, but nothing too groundbreaking or breathtaking. Here's to hoping it signals a return to form, and we see another Mega Man installment come forward that is nothing but gold.

61176880.review:
It's okay. But if you want an improvement over Mighty No 9 because "It had bad design" or whatever, don't look here. It shares some problems, it fixes some problems, and it creates some new problems. But people who fixate on the negatives are pathetic. (This is a joke. I am aware of the slight hypocrisy, considering the ordering in my review, but I'm not that guy who compares the animation quality of a random npc interaction to a major cutscene in Pokemon)

This game does cover some areas just as well as (or even better than) Mighty No 9, (Which I do love, spare me the "You are an idiot for having an opinion" comments) some parts make me think: "How could that possibly have ever been a good idea?" Things such as:
[list]
[*]Difficult menu navigation.
[*]Imprecise controls.
[*]Sections relying too much on the speed gear.
[*]Enemies that blend in with other stage mechanics. (Unintentionally.)
[*]Being pushed into insta-death traps by standing still on a platform. (When it looks like you should be fine- The player might not even know what they did wrong.
[*]Falling into insta-death traps during a screen transition.
[*]Mega Man's look does change with new weapons, but only to look like the corresponding boss-Not as though he's actually having his body change to accommodate the new power.
[*]Powers don't seem as though they would change the way you play too much-contrast M#9's powers that totally changed the way the player had to move and position themselves.
[/list]
However, this game does manage to do some good things as well.
[list]
[*]Good soundtrack
[*]Giving players a way to modulate their experience and difficulty with "parts"
[*]Stages have repeating mechanics spread out, and it's hard to get tired of any particular part of a stage
[*]Character design is a good blending of classic concepts and Mega Man's new image thanks to Smash.
[*]Various Anti-Frustration features.
[*]Fairly opaque development allows for a professional release.
[/list]
Overall, I kinda feel "meh" about the game. It's a good way to blend modern development and standards with a classic formula without alienating a younger audience.

The Blue Bomber is back with another adventure to save the world from the clutches of Dr. Wily! Lots of familiar faces return, such as Roll, Auto, Dr. Light, and most of the rest of the crew, while a new host of 8 Robot Masters are introduced with neat, unique weapons and top-notch fights. Some stages are more problematic than fun (Torch/Bounce Man) but your mileage may vary.
The introduction of the Double Gear System gives a lot of flexibility and strategical situations where they can be useful. Button config on it though can trip up veteran players due to them being on old "weapon switch" buttons. The story is basic but cohesive and delves into the history of everything a bit. The shop is also back with a bolt system and lots of incredibly useful upgrade parts to equip. The voicing is fantastic and the controls are tight, as they should be. The numerous difficulties provide adequate challenge on for everyone.
While it isn't the best in the series, it's easily up with the best. Highly recommended.
