60719131.review:
Before playing this game, I always thought I'd play the original Mega man games to see what all the fuss was about. After playing this game, that's not going to happen because I really didn't like my time playing this game -_-. The biggest problem with this game is that it's either too difficult or too easy, with very little in-between. 

In regards to the game being too easy, there's a shop where you can buy items. This is how you're going to get ALL your items, because this isn't a Metroidvania where you can explore for stuff. Through the shop, you can get 9 lives, 9 full hp refills, and 9 full weapon refills. 9 full hp refills is more than enough to beat any boss in the game, including the final boss. This seriously destroys any difficulty this game may have through combat. 

I thought I would mitigate this by not using the shop for lives or health refills and only use it to buy passive upgrades. Unfortunately, that's where the "too difficult" aspect comes in. This game is designed like old school games, which means that if you lose all your lives, you have to start the stage from the very beginning. Without buying lives from the shop, you only get 2 lives every time you die…… and that's not a lot. By the time you get to the boss of each stage, you'll likely only have 0 or 1 life left. I didn't use the shop for the 1st 2 bosses that I fought, and both times I died with no lives and had to start from the beginning of the entire stage. This pissed me off so much.

Another thing that pissed me off was the platforming. There are so many god damn instant death platforming scenarios in this game. Like holy shit. I get that in the past, when you fell into a pit or touched spikes you instantly died, but does that mean every single god damn game in the future has to be like this? There are very few checkpoints in this game, so when you die you're losing a lot of progress.  What's worse is that in a lot of platforming sections, you're expected to succeed by trial and error. Unless you have crazy good reflexes, you're going to die by an enemy or a bullet that you didn't know was going to be there. To compare to Dark Souls, by mastering combat you master ALL combat (regular enemies at least). In Mega Man, mastering platforming means mastering platforming in ONE section, because the next section could have totally different bullshit.

Now, you can mitigate the above by playing on a lower difficulty level. I finished the game on Normal, but I could've chosen Casual or Newcomer. Newcomer has infinite lives, pits don't result in deaths, and spikes don't 1 shot you. While that would fix what pissed me off in the game, it still wouldn't make the game incredibly fun (and would make the game TOO easy). That's because Mega Man seems to be about overcoming your weaknesses, not testing your strengths. 

To elaborate, you can't do much as Mega Man. You can run around, shoot horizontally, charge your shot, slide, and that's it. You can't double-jump, dash, or shoot in different directions. Hell you can't even crouch. A lot of the enemies are designed to exploit these weaknesses. For example, some enemies are difficult because they're really small and your shot can't reach them while standing. Other enemies are difficult (including the final boss) because they're really high up in the air and you can't reach them by jumping. That's what your special powers are for. After defeating 1 of the 8 standard bosses, you get a special ability. These abilities range from shooting in a different direction to giving you a shield. Shooting in a different direction is very useful in this game because of how limited Mega Man's moveset is, and therefore they are crucial for getting through a lot of the platforming sections in this game.

However, more recent 2D platforming games have you playing as characters who are far more fun to play as. In Hollow Knight, you can attack up and down as a given. In Ori and the Blind Forest, you can get a triple jump and can move pretty much wherever the hell you want. In Sundered, you get an omni-directional dash that you can use 8 times in a row. Compared to these games, I can't get excited over an ability that Mega Man gets that allows him to attack diagonally up -_-. That's what I mean by Mega Man is about overcoming your weaknesses (since Mega Man has a very limited moveset, so the enemies and level design is also fairly underwhelming), not testing your strengths (like other more recent 2D platformers who have a much more interesting and fun moveset and therefore the enemies and level design are much more fun to overcome).

Fundamentally, that's the real reason I don't like this game. Yes, the lives system is a pain in the ass and the instant death platforming sections are frustrating. But at its core, Mega Man is simply not a fun character to play as compared to more recent games.

60712379.review:
It's great to see our blue boi come back anew after starring in all those legacy collections. New elements such as quickswapping powers and the OP power gear make for a faster-paced, button-gymnastics installment. Speed gear provides welcome assistance in high-precision scenarios and the well-voiced story is a nice touch that sets more context to characters than jump 'n' shoot.

MM11 shows how modern platformers have seemingly spoiled me. Even the few classic Mega Man games I've played came with the privilege of savestates. Conversely, Mega Man 11 stays more committed to its legacy. Restarting a stage after losing all your lives is an acceptably retro inclusion. However, climbing through a lengthy level to challenge an unfamiliar boss capable of quickly demolishing your remaining attempts is rather cruel. This also makes practicing fights without knowing the cheese a terrifying obstacle. It seems that, unless you're a true MM veteran, you're likely going to find yourself repeating each level often just to get a few shots at the boss. Imagine, while playing a musical instrument, only being able to practice a difficult measure by playing from the start of the song up to that point.

Thankfully, the game's 'newcomer' difficulty is available to alleviate the threat of insta-kill obstacles and limited continues. It might honestly make MM11 a tad too simple with bosses becoming pretty fragile, but it's a nice gesture with a friendly title for an audience who might've not understood what they were getting into. Later switching to a newcomer file helped me appreciate the game during a period where I didn’t need my time off to be another demanding challenge.

57073230.review:
As a huge Mega Man fan. This one is in my opinion the best of them all. I'm glad this game decided to bring the franchise forward, rather than being held back by 8 bit visuals and old-school design like 9 and 10. That doesn't mean it's entirely modern in its design however, as game overs send you back to the beginning of a level rather than at mid-points like in 8. Seeing as the levels are very long in this game, I would really not have minded such a feature. Other than that and a weak soundtrack by MM standards, I can't name any flaws.

The highlights of the game are the robot masters, with battles like Torch Man really testing your reflexes and precision in a way that never feels unfair. Adding to that is a new limited time-slowdown mechanic that allows you to slow the battle down every time an enemy launches an attack, meaning that the next time they try it on you you absolutely know how to dodge it provided you are skilled enough.

There is so much care taken with the challenge of the game that really grabbed my attention. As just one example, Impact Man, like many masters before him, shakes the ground when he lands, causing you to be stunned in place. However, you will always still have a chance to evade his next attack, it's only harder to do so after being stunned.

It's also nice to finally see a Mega Man game with modern high definition graphics. We can only hope possible future installments follow suit in merging the traditional MM experience with modern improvements.

The bosses also have these powers making them more interesting to fight. The level design includes gimmicks appropriate to the robot master (an example of an inappropriate gimmick would be Hard Man's chomper platforms).
If you have not played a Mega Man game yet, then I suggest buying the Mega Man Legacy collection (and playing Make a Good Mega Man level games) before playing this game.

54935494.review:
MM11 is legitimately great. 9 and 10 weren't bad but they got way too carried away with "Oh my nostalgia for MM2" when they could've either progressed the series forward or kept the mechanics that made the later games superior to 1 and 2. 11 doesn't even go for a throwback feel which I respect so much in an age where everybody is going for franchise throwbacks and references. 11 just feels like another MM and that's one of the reasons it's so good. It adds the new Double Gear that can make the game feel way more fun at parts. One gear slows time like bullet time and the other makes your weapons power up temporarily. It is completely optional so if you'd rather just play straight up late NES era MM then here it is. 

Controls are tight, graphics are super appealing, story isn't deep but kind of fun, music is just awesome and the level design is perfect. Only complaint I have (which is also something I praise it for) is the runtime. You'll beat it in about 2 hours which is the same as the rest of the og MMs but the Wily castle is pathetically anticlimactic: two stages, the rematches and then Wily and thats it. It ends so abruptly which is a shame when the rest of the game's pacing is so perfect. I praise them for not artificially extending the play time with a second castle like 3 through 6 but they should've had four stages, the final two ending with the rematches and the Wily fight respectively. If they had done that I think the play time would be absolutely perfect.

At the end of the day MM11 is fantastic. I'd put it in the top 5 of the series its that good. Not just for people who enjoy MM but anybody who enjoys a 2D action platformer. Presentation is great, gameplay is even better. Like I said the only real flaw is how anti-climactic the Wily Castle is but otherwise fantastic job. Hope if we see a MM12 they bring back the 2.5D style and Double Gear mechanic but add a bit more content (Protoman is missing here which suckz).

54173359.review:
[h1]RECOMENDADO[/h1]
[b]Sencillamente infaltable en la biblioteca de cualquier fan de MM y de juegos de plataformas y acción.[/b] 

[b]Síntesis:[/b] hablamos de la secuela de los 10 primeros títulos originales y numerados de MM.

Este es un juego absolutamente nuevo con toda la potencia que capcom pudo darle en el año 2018.

Todos los juegos de MegaMan siguen la estructura del "piedra, papel o tijera" donde el arma del robot A que obtendremos al derrotarlo, nos servirá para derrotar al robot B y la de este al robot C hasta completar el círculo con A.

Todo el entorno de los juegos es robótico y artificial, desde árboles, decoración, animales, jefes y subjefes, con la excepción de los 2 científicos. 

Este MM para mi gusto es el mejor de toda la saga hasta el día de la fecha y con creces.

Existe un dlc de músicas instrumentales totalmente gratuito para su descarga en la tienda.

[h1]HISTORIA:[/h1]
En un futuro lejano del año 20XX un científico llamado Dr Light cree en los robots especializados para ayudar a la humanidad cuando su antiguo amigo, ahora némesis Dr Wily considera que los robots deben tener IA propia incluso si eso implica que sus fines no sean pacíficos. Mega Man será el robot prototipo que debe traer la paz a la humanidad.

A esto se añade un flashback de ambos científicos de jóvenes cuando el Dr Wily exploraba la posibilidad del doble mega, la nueva característica de este juego a la que Light se oponía por considerarla peligrosa y que Wily siempre quiso investigar.

Se ve como Light bloquéa esta investigación de Wily lo que le hace ganar la enemistad del último. 

Luego en la actualidad del juego se ve como el Dr Light vuelve a crear 8 robots (como en MMI y MM9) pero estos son secuestrados y reprogramados por el Dr Wily en su contra. 
[b]Extras:[/b]
[list]
    [*]Nuevamente como el último MM podemos escoger la dificultad desde novato a superheroe, la dificultad máxima.
    [*]Modo desafío donde poder completar logros especiales de esta colección.
    [*]Modo Museo donde podemos apreciar arte original de todos los juegos, con ilustraciones de enemigos y personajes.
    [*]Ranking de jugadores por todo el mundo
[/list]
[h1]EL JUEGO:[/h1]
[b]Breve resumen[/b]
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]MegaMan 11[/th]
    [/tr]    
[/table]
Continúa la historia de la saga clásica M. Los robots maestros al igual que en MMI y MM9 son creados por el Dr Light.

MegaMan recupera su barrida y mega buster como en MM8 y previos.

Siguiendo la tendencia de MM9 y MM10 el juego no sigue la numeración romana característica de los juegos clásicos.

Nuevamente como en MM8 y previos existe un escenario a modo de introducción y previo a la elección de las 8 fases principales.

Se agrega el nuevo sistema doble mega que expande la modalidad de juego a niveles nunca antes vistos y le dan una frescura y genialidad nunca antes vista en la franquicia.

El modo tiempo donde será como en Matrix que nos moveremos en cámara lenta pero más rápido que los enemigos y entorno, y el modo poder donde nuestros disparos y armas estarán potenciados y tendrán nuevas características; y finalmente el modo simultáneo de ambos. 

Activar esos modos sobrecalienta y drena energía de una barra roja extra, por lo que tendremos que ser cautelosos en como usarla para no quedarnos sin poder.

Abusar de la misma puede dejar nuestro mega buster débil y casi inútil.

Los gráficos son impresionantes para un MM y la música es buena.

Los robots maestros son únicos aunque rememoran antiguos enemigos de la saga, los poderes que adquirimos de ellos también nos recuerdan a otros de títulos pasados pero lo genial y nuevo ahora es que al equipar un arma de un robot maestro también cambiará nuestro aspecto, como un casco distinto, brazos, o cañones diferentes, incluso cuernos y antenas.

Los escenarios son variados y muy hostiles.

Yo lo terminé en dificultad máxima y sufrí los primeros niveles pero luego vamos ganando tornillos y compramos muchos tanques e items que nos solucionarán la vida.

Los jefes son difíciles con mecánicas únicas y llegar a ellos no es tarea fácil, pero la gran cantidad de items que podemos comprar, entre consumibles y permamentes en la tienda del Dr Light hará que se sienta el juego más fácil y tolerable.

Entre algunos de los muchos items permanentes nuevos habrán unos botines que nos aferrarán al hielo para no resbalar y un sistema para expertos que nos drenará casi toda la vida, pero tendremos más poder en el disparo y el mega buster.

Habrán otros incluso que tendrán requisitos especiales como terminar el juego y otros que por el momento desconozco ya que me aparecen bloqueados a pesar de haber finalizado el juego en dificultad máxima.

Luego de la fase de los robots maestros accederemos a la fortaleza de Wily que gracias al motor gráfico se ve espectacular. 

La primera fase es muy compleja y difícil con muchas plataformas y entorno aéreo.

El jefe es otro modelo del diablo amarillo, nada fácil.

La segunda fase es más corta y menos hostil, el enemigo es menos duro que el diablo amarillo.

La tercera fase es directamente enfrentarse a los 8 robots maestros de nuevo con una pequeña fase corta introductoria previa.

Y finalmente tenemos la fase final con Wily en una máquina con 2 fases que si bien es difícil, con la ayuda de items y objetos será mucho más sencillo que en juegos anteriores.

De más está decir que a diferencia de todos los juegos previos, entrar a la fortaleza de Wily no impedirá que nos equipemos en la  tienda del Dr Light lo que hará que el juego que empezó muy difícil se vuelva sumamente sencillo.

Como única contra, el juego se siente un poco corto.

Como conclusión y opinión personal, es el mejor MM de toda su franquicia, empieza difíficil y duro pero termina siendo sencillo por los ítems.

Es sin dudas una obra maestra de capcom que dió en el clavo con este MM11.

Solid Mega Man title that is actually quite challenging without all the upgrades. I do have a few qualms about controls and hitboxes, but outsides of that this is a really pretty take on the formula. I don't think it will top any of the best Mega Man games, but it introduces a new generation to Mega Man and gives everyone a good chance at winning with all the power ups.

Some people will probably say it gets too easy. I at first thought you could only get lives and stuff like that. With just lives this game is still very challenging in parts, and you really have to make sure you get the sections down well before you proceed to the boss fight. But after a while I went looking in the store and you can pretty much buy your way to easy mode. I'm not gonna knock the game for it, because there are achievements for doing it the hard way, but sometimes I feel they go a bit too overboard with the help.

Outside of the that you have two sets of music tracks to occupy your time on the levels, and I very much enjoy switching between the normal more retro soundtrack and the piano tracks. The graphics and music together pull off a modern Mega Man vibe nearly perfectly.

Personally, I needed a lot of antideadzone on my DS4, but after that controls are very precise on analog or dpad. Overall, this a very solid entry with graphical prowess that fans and newcomers alike should enjoy.

This game has so many problems...
First, the voice acting is terrible. Changing the voices to Japanese makes it a little more tolerable, but still annoying. 
The 2.5D graphics are also questionable. A series with so many anime overtones would make more sense as a strict 2D game with hand drawn animations, but that opinion may be in the minority.

Buy it on sale if you love Mega Man, otherwise, pass.

50933586.review:
Mega Man, one of the oldest franchises out there with so many titles, different series and even gameplay styles that endured the test of time and remains dearly loved by many to this day. One of Capcom's greatest faces still proves to be strong to this very day. This review is made with both regular fans and new people in mind.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
[b]If you're someone who is already familiar with the Classic Mega Man series[/b], you will be right at home with Mega Man 11. The game is completely loyal to how you play the oldest titles and it feels perfectly like a classic Mega Man game with better graphics. You got all the classics: enemies that still behave just like they did 30 years ago, disappearing platforms, precise (often frustrating) jumps, usage of abilities and weapons for certain situations, harsh improvement after failure and all that. If you enjoyed the classic Mega Man games, will you enjoy this without a doubt.

[b]The Gear System mechanic[/b]: This is Mega Man 11's theme and gimmick, the gear system is like a temporary power up that can either power up your attacks (and special attacks) or slow down time (actually speeds you up, but everything will move slowly). The effect lasts for a few seconds and then you need to wait for it to cool down to use again, you can cancel the effect whenever you want to make the cool down faster, as using it until the time limit will overheat you and make you unable to use it again for a while.

Even though the game can be completed without ever using the gears, as there's even an achievement for that, you might end up thinking it's obligatory for certain parts of the game and of course that's intentional, the game was made with the gears to be used in mind. So here's the thing: when I first saw the first trailer of the game a long time ago, it felt like it would be too easy with the whole gears thing and you might be thinking that too but rest assured that if you're looking for a challenge, there's a lot of room for that, be it from not using special weapons to not using gears or both and ignoring extra health items, etc. the game gets a lot harder when you decide to make it harder, so don't shy away from the game thinking it is too easy because it certainly isn't if you want it to be hard. If you are one of the hardcore Mega Man players, this game got you covered and if you're just some casual player, you're also covered.

Now [b]if you're someone who never played a Mega Man game[/b], this is a platformer where you will move around shooting enemies, dodging their attacks, jumping over obstacles and things like that. It takes time to learn the stages and bosses patterns, it can be frustrating but it's incredibly satisfying when you are able to run through a stage without dying once after struggling to get to the first checkpoint a few hours ago. Mega Man is one of the greatest examples of games ever done where you improve with time and effort, practice makes perfect and it feels damn great when you see yourself overcoming difficulties you had before, you truly can notice yourself improving.

However, before you decide that this is the Dark Souls of platformers and not for you or whatever, I must tell you that Capcom made sure to adapt the game to all kinds of i̶n̶c̶o̶m̶p̶e̶t̶e̶n̶c̶e̶ players. Mega Man 11 features a number of things that make the game tremendously easier, first of all there's the old bolts mechanic where you collect bolts dropped from defeated enemies to improve yourself with extra items, parts and things like that. Those improvements can make the game an absolute joke, moving around with 9 extra lives, 9 E-tanks that restore all your life, 9 W-Tanks that fills up all your special weapons ammo entirely each, 3 usages of Eddie to drop you random recovery items, 3 usages of Beat to save you from dying from doing a bad jump or falling into a pit and several parts that make your life easier like making enemies drop more recovery items, less ice sliding, less damage, making the Gear system even more powerful, etc. Not to mention that aside from all this, there are still difficulties to choose, so even a r̶e̶t̶a̶r̶d̶ game "journalist" should be able to complete the game.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
In terms of appearance, Mega Man 11 is what a lot of people have been waiting for a long time now, it's another installment of the classic Mega Man series but now visually adapted to a more modern standard. Many of the older fans still love the 8bit jump and shoot action but this new look is definitely welcome and nice. Things look great and still cartoonish enough like the series characteristically has always been like. They did it very well.

[h1]Music[/h1]
It's Mega Man, music has always been a most distinguished characteristic of the series, the soundtracks are great and they really fit the stages very well in terms of changing the beat or tune according to the average player's pace advancing through the stage and things they encounter. For a game like this, having good music is mandatory and in Mega Man 11 it is done very well.

[h1]Game length and replayability[/h1]
Clearing the game on normal difficulty took me almost 8 hours, that's a very short of time for a "main campaign" of a game with this price tag. At first I was decided to not use any special weapons and upgrades, as that's how I usually play my Mega Man games, but things were too frustrating and I eventually started using everything the game offered me, which made progress extremely easy as farming bolts doesn't take long and I had over 4000 of them without intentionally gathering them while stuck on my second stage of choice without much progress, so I was able to buy all parts and tons of extra E-Tanks, etc. After clearing a few stages I decided to stop doing that because it was making the whole experience shallow and short. Still, I wouldn't say the clear time is a negative thing though, most players just clear their games without doing all optional stuff and consider it "done", so in my case I can just jump into the game whenever I feel like it and challenge myself with another run following more difficult "rules", try a harder difficulty or even go into the Challenge Mode the game has, which while not interesting to me, it's something to do for those looking for rankings and all that. With all that said, the game definitely has replayability.

[h1]Final thoughts and nitpicks[/h1]
Many people thought the Mega Man series was done for after Inafune left Capcom years ago and with the overall failure of Mighty no.9 to deliver expectations (I [url=https://steamcommunity.com/id/uselessbunny/recommended/314710/] reviewed it [/url] too if you want to compare them), but this game proves Mega Man is still strong and the people behind it are perfectly capable of honoring the series and creating something great.

In my personal opinion, Mighty no.9 did a couple things better than Mega Man 11, such as the interaction between bosses and the protagonist and their presence in the story itself, while in Mega Man you're just destroying all your fellow robots that were turned evil (?) without looking back. I think both games are great but I'm really glad to see Mega Man 11 turned out to be so good after all.

There's only one problem, the usual problem: IT NEEDS MORE ROLL. CAPCOM PLS, IF YOU'RE STILL NOT GIVING ROLL HER OWN GAME AFTER ALL THESE YEARS THEN AT LEAST MAKE HER MORE RELEVANT, GIVE HER MORE SPACE FOR THE LOVE OF GOD. Also where the heck is Protoman and what happened to Bass?

[h1]Verdict[/h1]
A great new entry to the series, excellent adaptation to a more modern version of the game (something rare). Veteran players will enjoy it without a doubt and people who never touched a Mega Man game before will also find themselves an enjoyable experience. If you are a hardcore fan then buy it at full price without looking back, if you are not really that of a Mega Man fanatic or you're new to the series, wait for a sale. It's definitely worth it.

50731221.review:
Mega Man 11 Review

After 8+ years of middle fingers to Mega Man fans from Capcom and a game that went from a Mega Man spiritual successor to a Mighty No. 2, the Blue Bomber is finally back with some new gameplay mechanics and a new visual style while maintaining the classic side-scrolling 2D action from the previous titles.

Opting to go for a modern 2.5D visual style as opposed to the 8-bit style used in Mega Man 9 and 10 turned out well and visually stunning. It's almost what Mega Man X7 should've been rather than a 3D platformer.

The new gameplay mechanic, the Double Gear system, allows you to enhance your attacks via the Power Gear or speed up your movements via the Speed Gear. This doesn't take away from the tried and true gameplay mechanics and is a welcome addition. The Double Gear system is optional and you don't have to use them if you're a purist. But it is a useful system if you need to avoid enemy damage or power up weapons, especially the Tundra Storm and Acid Barrier weapons in particular.

The eight new Robot Masters are unique in both design and attacks. Each one also have a special gear attack when their health is low. For example, Block Man can use his Power Gear to transform into a giant stone robot and Bounce Man can use the Speed Gear to bounce around the room at high speeds. The weapons you obtain are probably some my favourites from the franchise.

I won't say that it's a perfect game. The game feels a little short, especially during the final levels of the game and as of this review, there seems to be no plans for some much need DLC to expand the game upon. I sure miss playing as Bass and Proto Man sometimes. Also, the challenge modes, while fun, can get boring quickly aside from the time attack modes.

Bottom line, Mega Man 11 marks an excellent (and welcoming) return of a much-beloved franchise with some new additions while maintaning the classic Mega Man gameplay. It's not perfect and it has its flaws, but I'll keep on replaying Mega Man 11 1000 times over before I even give Mighty No. 2 another shot.

On a sidenote, I hope we get a Mega Man 12 and a Mega Man X9! Maybe Mega Man Legends 3...

Overall recommendation: Highly recommended.

50637966.review:
I used to play Mega Man quite a lot as a kid, especially the "X" series, and I was genuinely interested to play a new Mega Man in 2018, to see how it would play out in this current era, and it disappointed me. Grossely comparing, it would be like releasing a new Resident Evil with the same (tank) outdated gameplay of the older games with updated graphics. Here is similar: the game looks good but doesn't play as well as it should have. This game is too conservative, with the respawning enemies, very limited interactions with enviroments, sparse checkpoints, restricted ways to save the game, silly storyline, simplistic nice graphics and gameplay, double gear system is fine but just a way to appeal better to casuals... nostalgic hardcore fans will surely enjoy this, but this game in particular should have gone beyond to be more ambitious. 
This game is worth at least 75% discounted,  but at least isn't a Mighty Nº 9...

50471111.review:
I was in the mood for a platformer and some nostalgia and I needed a break from all the FPS/Battle Royale games I've been playing. So, I picked up Mega Man 11 on sale for $20. This game brought me right back to where I needed to be and I had a hard time putting it down. 

Anime style cut scenes set up the classic (never ending) story involving Dr. Light and Mega Man needing to save the day from Dr. Wiley and his band of evil robots. Throughout the levels you get nice cell shaded animations and a modernized feel to Mega Man without changing the classic format that made it a hit back on the NES. The Bosses could have been more creative, but they still offer some challenges and force you to learn the patterns and they will kill you. I would say the difficulty is fairly modererate unless your an avid platform gamer. There are times that the enemies and the level design will drive you crazy, especially when you have to start from the beginning of the level all over again. But is it worth it? Hell yeah! and it is and it makes it that much more rewarding when you beat it! Its good to feel some emotions in games, even the ones that may give you the feeling to chuck the controller across the room, luckily I didn't do that.

For $20, it gave me my fill. If your in the mood for some fast paced action with a challenge and some of that nostalgic feel, I thought this game did the trick.

50365560.review:
Easily one of the best Mega Man games to date.

Pros:
*Great graphics and visual design that use cell shading so well that it often looks like you're seeing HQ sprites rather than models
*Great level design and boss battles that are actually fair and not mind splittingly difficult, while still offering a reasonable challenge and being really fun to just play
*Good writing, particularly with the robot masters, this game oozes 90s cheese which is always a plus from me
*Runs well with no visual, audio, or gameplay glitches that i noticed

Cons (all of these are really minor complaints):
*The music is okay, but not very memorable
*The game is a bit on the short side, but still in line with your average Mega Man game
*While the visuals during gameplay are good, there are a few cutscenes that just look kinda bad, but they don't look terrible and there aren't that many cutscenes to begin with.

Seriously buy this game, even without a sale it's absolutely worth $30.

Easily worth the $20 I spent on it. 

I am not a big megman fan, but it was an enjoyable game and well made. The graphics are crisp, lively, and smooth. Think of cg version of Mega Man 8's color pallets.

Also the difficulty level on hard or super hero is insane. You have to have the force abilities to deal with some of the cheap shots and craziness.

The voice acting is pretty decent on the US side (I am probably biased against English voice actors), and even better on the Japanese tracks.

The music is good. Not megaman 8 great, but good. I never felt like muting the game from the music.

I also enjoyed how much character are in the casts. They are voiced and have short, but amusing back stories. They also have cute animations and interactions.

The only downside are not being able to play as roll.No I am not some feminist SJW, I would just like to play as Roll. The other is Rush is largely useless. I used him like 3 times and all 3 times was me accidentally hitting the B button.

50324271.review:
I'm not recommending this game. Steam asked if I have changed my mind. I haven't. 

Well. Looks like Mega Man, smells like Mega Man so it's gotta be Megaman. The thing looks exactly how a new Mega Man game should look like in this day and age. 

However... It appears that Capcom have lost their thread on level design and are confusing fun with frustration. They took every trick that copped Mega Man 9 out of any replay value and used steroids on them. I don't really know what to make of levels that are so frustratingly difficult that you don't want to go back to them even in the easiest difficulty. 

These kinds of things sometimes make me wonder who these games are actually targeted for. I mean, sure, the basic gameplay is there and it feels like Mega Man traditionally does... but in the recent games the level design has gone down to hell, really. 

I managed to run through the game in Beginner mode. Well... that's one way to beat through this heap, but what fun is it when everything dies around you so quickly that you'll miss half the game? Mega Man's near immortality helps you somewhat with the levels you probably never want to revisit again. 

Switching to Casual mode still makes you miss half the game - only this time it's because the level design won't let you see it! After playing in the Beginner mode you'll have a grasp of the level design and you're already disgusted by the mere thought of returning to Acid Man, Torch Man or Bounce Man's levels. Now that Mega Man is a mere mortal you're going to need nine lives to clear the levels. 

Actually, nine lives isn't going to cut it. 

Also... Could someone PLEASE explain me what Capcom's obsession is with partially assignable keyboard controls? Why is the subscreen put in that random letter somewhere and we can't put it elsewhere? Are they lazy or hell-bent on making something to nag about?

Sad to say, but I think Capcom has dropped the ball.

When Mega Man 9 came out I played it and thought, "Yeah, alright. This is a lot like the old games. I like it." When I played Mega Man 10 it just felt like more of the same. Fine. I'll buy it. I'll beat it once then never pick it up again.
Mega Man 11 is a big change and in my opinion it is defintely for the better!

The switch to 2.5D might have worried some but it's smooth and beautiful and it works amazingly well. I would have been fine sticking to the old 8-bit graphics too, but as long as they didn't go chibi like in Mega Man Powered Up I'm fine.
The new addition of the time slow and power up gears is cool, but I agree that it does make the game a little too easy. 

What's great is the achievements. Don't like the Gear System? Don't use it and here's an achievement to prove you did it. Think the items are too OP? Skip them and here's another achievement.

When I had Mega Man 3 on NES I beat it over and over, but I think this is the first MM game that I've actually played through more times that MM3. The replayability on this one is high. Especially with all the achievements and different ways to beat it.

Plus the challenges are actually pretty entertaining and offer a more pick-up-and-play style that Mega Man often lacks.

Fans new and old need to grab this and beat it again and again. I can't wait for Mega Man 12.

Though it's still no Mega Man Maker. I mean come on Capcom. Mario Maker was huge, didn't stop Nintendo from still making money off new Mario 2D games, and a fan even already made Mega Man Maker. Just snatch that up and add more stuff to it! It will print money!

Mega Man 11 does a lot to modernize classic Mega Man gameplay while keeping it true to its roots. The game has a lot of quality of life changes that make it easier for new players to approach, such as the Gear system, purchaseable support items and upgrades, and multiple difficulty options, but it's still Mega Man through and through. Gameplay is rock-solid (no pun intended) with fun boss fights and weapons. It also does a good job of bringing the classic Mega Man aesthetic to 3D.

New players will find that this is one of the best entry points in the series.

49856624.review: Went back to the roots with this one! No wall sliding, no flashy sleek armor, no hidden areas in the levels, perfect nostalgic MegaMan. I enjoyed this game very much! I have to admit, I personally enjoy the MegaMan X-style base-armor upgrades (sleek, very cool looking), and I enjoyed discovering hidden areas in each stage, which were locked with either a mobility ability you had to earn elsewhere or a boss weapon from elsewhere. I thought this approach added depth to the game with incentives to go explore levels (and pay attention to the beautiful artwork) after the boss had been defeated. In MegaMan 11, there is no reason to revisit a stage once the boss has been defeated, unfortunately. Overall, still a very fun throwback to original MegaMan! Would recommend!

48496085.review:
This is an absolutely incredible Mega Man game. I'm only halfway through the regular bosses and it's one of my favorite of all time. This is coming from someone who has beat every Mega Man game several times and I'm in love with the series. 
Here are the reasons why: 
It's the classic game in an updated art style. The game looks absolutely gorgeous, each stage feels very unique, as are the minibosses and the boss fights. It has a very good sliding difficulty, so it fantastic for newcomers and pros alike. It still has the parts that feel incredibly unfair, like every Mega Man game we've come to love, like getting hit in the middle of a jump from something you could not have foreseen. 
In all, the levels are incredibly well-thought out and MUCH longer than a typical Mega Man stage, which was an awesome change to the series and a welcome challenge. The stages are unique stylistically and thematically and fit not just the ability, but the personality of the robot boss. The enemies are unique to each stage and all pretty challenging. I thought they did a great job of introducing certain challenges unique to each stage that increased with difficulty as you get further into the stage. EX: with Block man, there are patterns of blocks you need to shoot/slide through before you get pushed into spikes. You're introduced to these blocks alone, then with enemies, then with patterns, harder patterns etc... Each stage has a similar challenge. I felt they were brilliantly executed.
The gear system is fun and unique and you can abuse it as much as you like. I chose mostly to use it to mess around, but it can certainly make some of the parts of the game where you're being chased, under duress or can't dodge a particular move a bit less stressful. Also, the power geared boss weapons can be fun. 
The music is great. I particularly love the title, boss select music, blast and fuse man so far.
When you change weapons, your helmet also changes in this installment, which again, is a small artistic change that kind of updates the game, makes it more enjoyable and just looks nice.
The game can be HARD. I had the patience to finish 1-5, which are also rather difficult and I wanted to break my controller at one point, then I calmed down and it put a huge smile on my face.
Switching specials weapons is incredible using the right-stick. You just slide it in a direction and it switches you to a special weapon. If you click the stick you go back to buster. Rush jet/coil are also mapped to buttons - makes the game more seemless!

If you like Mega Man, I can't recommend this game enough. I wouldn't hesitate to buy it at full price, because although Mega Man games are short, I always get enjoyment coming back and running through a few of them from time to time. Also, this is one of the best I've played and if you enjoy the series, you will appreciate the TLC that was put into this game. Koji Oda, the director, deserves some sort of award for keeping the difficulty, uniqueness and fun of a Mega Man game, making it inviting for newcomers, while updating it in a very tactful way.

[table]
    [tr]

[/tr]

[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Apartando los modos extras el juego queda con poco contenido. Si pasas la etapa eso es todo, no tienes por qué volver a ella salvo para los logros. Me hubiese gustado que con todo lo que se lucieron en este Mega Man, hubiese sido maravilloso un mayor contenido para exprimir esta obra de arte y dudo que coloquen un DLC en el futuro.[/th]
[/tr]
[/table]

[h1]Innovación:[/h1]
[table]
    [tr]
        [th]Han innovado en varias cosas pero lo más notable es el dispositivo "Doble Mega" el cual puedes activar la habilidad de Megavelocidad la cual aumenta tu velocidad y la Megapotencia la cual aumenta tu poder de ataque. Los efectos en ambas habilidades son muy buenos.[/th]

48165808.review:
Despite being a popular favorite with videogamers and one of the greatest series I remember playing during my childhood on NES & Game Boy, MEGA MAN hasn't had a new entry in years... until now. MEGA MAN 11 is a glorious love letter to past adventures. To a fault, it doesn't do anything majorly revolutionary, but considering the variable output of its sequels, it's at least gratifying to know that this turned out very well and in my opinion, this is the best entry in the series so far.

 The gameplay remains as fun and glorious as it did for previous MM entries. This game, like most MM games, can be intensely frustrating at the beginning (I played on superhero difficulty first) ; the jumps and timing are extremely tight sometimes and at the beginning, you have to get used to it, find out the right boss order and buy some power ups to make it easier, but that’s what makes it so perfect. Double Gear System is the newest twist to the classic gameplay. Power gear which enhances your buster, and Speed Gear that effectively slows things down around you. Learning to use both effectively is key to making things work in your favor, it's not an overpowered mechanic. I found level design has been polished so they demonstrate the difficulty the franchise is known for without the Gears, yet can't be cheaply run through using said Gears. The content is quite short, like all the MM games, but the various achievements give you a reason to replay the game and there’s even a challenge mode for the most skilled players out there.

 It’s exactly like the old games with a few new twists and better graphics ; the graphic style is rendered in a clean, gorgeous hand-drawn style that feels very much at home with what you'd expect from classic MM. There are cutscenes in the game, thankfully skippable, and yes, there's voice acting ; the story is nice, despite being very simple like it has always been with the previous entries. The music has yet to catch me as truly memorable ; it's passable stuff, although not quite as good as in previous MM entries.

 All told, though, Capcom has done a fine job of producing a game that lives up to its predecessor, and it plays exceedingly smooth on PC (I use a PS4 controller), with no noticeable hiccups.

48127869.review:
Well, it's classic Megaman, alright.

Challenging, cute, mostly* fun. The double gear thing feels a bit gimmicky, but it's neat.

* Having only played a couple hours in a couple sessions, my impression of some of the levels isn't great. The ice level has some obnoxious platforming bits where it's windy that are really pissing me off, but that's just a matter of getting it. There are two spots that I have more of an issue with; the fire level and the water level. Both do things reminicent of other Megaman games, but they're taken up a notch, which seems unnecessary to me. Underwater spiky bits and "move before the moving hazard kills you" have both been done in MM2, and felt more balanced and fair in that implementation than they do in MM11. Each successive game does not need to be harder than the last.

Other than that, I've been enjoying it.

Not sure what to make of the price. On the one hand, it's a new game, and it's polished to the standard I expect (with the noted exceptions above, as far in as I've been), but on the other hand, there have been new Megaman games released this decade that were far cheaper and required no less development (MM 9 & 10) that I enjoyed on the Virtual Console for a fraction the cost. I know these games cost far more back in the day, but that was State-of-the-Art back then; they were the Triple-A games of their era. Maybe I'm just spoiled by emulation, but times have changed. I get that they aren't asking AAA money for this, but I think it's still overpriced for what it is. I got it on sale, but not enough of one. A great buy if you can get it half-price or less.

47445584.review:
I started playing the Mega Man series back on the NES with Mega Man 2, and have looked forward to, purchased, and played each new entry as they've come out.  (The only one I (initially) missed was Mega Man 8, since I didn't have a Playstation.)
I regularly go back and play through the series, as they've always been some of my favorites.

Considering that I grew up on the NES series, and was never really a fan of Mega Man 7 on the SNES, I was extremely  pleased when 9 and 10 were in retro NES style.  So, I'd be lying if I didn't say I was a little disappointed when I heard 11 was going to be "updated".  However, I understand.  They'd done their thing with 9 and 10, and it was time to move on to new grounds, and refresh Mega Man with elements that can't be done in an NES style setting.

Overall, I think they did pretty well, and I recommend the game to anyone who is a fan of the series.  I'm looking forward to seeing what comes next, and I'd eagerly welcome a Mega Man 12 done in the same style (and 13, 14, etc.)

Pros:
The game feels like Mega Man.  Right from the beginning, it felt familiar.

The levels each have their own unique look and feel with some clever designs.

It's challenging and fun without being too angering.  A couple spots had me pretty irritated, but I got passed them.

Despite some "cutesy" graphics, the game didn't feel childish and cartoon-y like Mega Man 7 did.

Mega Man's different styling for each weapon is fun and clever.

Cons:
The music is pretty forgettable.  It's good, but lacks anything that'll leave you humming it later.

Some areas require some very precise maneuvering and controls, but the precision to Mega Man's controls and his moves just aren't sharp enough.  I'd often be bonking my head, or wondering why he didn't jump when I know I pressed the button.

I wish there was more to do in the levels, like secrets to look for, or upgrades to find.  There needs to be something more to do for players that aren't into "challenges".  

Lastly, item purchasing is ANNOYING.  You can only buy one item at a time, and having to listen to Roll ask me I'm sure I want to buy it, then congratulating me for buying it, and then wishing me luck for *every* *single* *item* purchase makes me apologize to anyone else in the room.  Especially when I'm filling up on 9 lives and 9 energy tanks and any other item's I'd used up.  Hearing "Okay Mega, what'll it be!?  .... Are you sure?   Okay! Be careful out there!" two dozen times every time I go to Dr. Light's lab is nightmare fuel.

There's voice acting now and it didn't break the game as I feared.

47011305.review:
As a fan of the old school Mega Man games, this game is total a delight.  Normal difficulty can be pretty hard, but the fact that you pick up currency as you play--which allows you to buy power-ups over time--mitigates the challenge.  The graphics are gorgeous for a side-scroller, and Capcom's effort at providing more of a story for this entry is appreciated.  The double-gear addition adds a very engaging dimension to the controls, and the weapon wheel is perfect.  Part of me is curious about what the game might be like with multi-direction shooting, but it's likely that that would spoil the challenge and the retro appeal of the game design.  

The one criticism I have is that the boss design veers towards the overly-difficult in terms of pattern recognition and evasion, yet too easy in terms of having the suitable counter-weapon.  That said, you can tell the designers are exploring what can be done with Mega Man on modern consoles, and that portends well for future entries in the franchise.

46865201.review:
The very fact that this title was released after so long makes me happier than a metool, safe under its helmet from all harm. The game play is solid, graphics are beyond what I expected, and the incredible challenge this series has always brought. With every stage and its own gimmick I enjoyed the experience no matter how many times I may have fallen into a pit, touched a spike, or lost a boss fight. 

The voice acting is a welcome addition, and even though its nothing too special, it fits with the game's humor. The fact we get to hear what the robot masters sound like is a treat. The music....oh brother the poor sound track.

I know some will disagree and you are welcome to do so. Yet I remember in Mega Man 8, the stage themes had a lot more to it. Clown Man's bouncy circus theme to the chilly slide of Frost Man's stage. If you take the time to listen closely to each stage theme for Mega Man 11, you will notice there is no change in the instruments used. Its the same synth and whatever is used for every stage, and the Wily stages all share the same theme. They're easily forgettable except maybe Bounce Man's stage.

The challenges are what they are. Challenging! Time, effort, and concentration are needed if you want to beat the record. Nothing more could have been asked or improved upon.

I have no rating system, but this is a solid game to me and I will enjoy, as will you, this long awaited title.

46863364.review:
Pros:
- Stages are simple but challenging and a lot of fun. Using fewer elements in smarter ways leads to all stages feeling unique and never getting boring. Every level is designed in such a way that it every challenge feels fair, so your losses never feel cheap and your victories always feel earned.
- Lower difficulty level than previous entries makes the game a lot more accessible, with harder difficulties optional for masochists like me.
- Art direction and polish is off the charts. From small animations and character details to background stories in stages to giving each stage an actual sense of being a place in a world rather than a series of rooms, you can really tell the designers cared about making a great game.
- Enemy and boss info gallery is equal parts charming and hilarious.
- Bosses have a mid-fight "super mode" that makes (some of) the battles a lot more interesting.
- Charged shots against enemy shields now knock the shield away for a short period, which really mitigates some of the most frustratingly unfun enemy types in the series.
- Hitting the opposite direction while sliding will cancel your slide, which is ALMOST like being able to duck!
- Dedicated button(s) for summoning Rush.

Neutrals
- Double Gear system is a solid boost when you need a hand but I rarely found any reason to use it outside of the occasional burst of Speed Gear for some tricky platforming (or getting stunned by an enemy during the wildfire in Torch Man's stage) or Power Gear on Tundra Man's power when I didn't feel like dealing with enemies on a screen. Definite utility for people who want to enjoy them game but have trouble with more difficult areas, but under-utilized and felt a bit tacked on.
- Upgrades system is like the Double Gear system: helps mitigate difficulty, but doesn't really make the game more interesting. Would have like more manual upgrades that change the way the game is played rather than just making Rock stronger.
- Most of the music is fun but lacks the earworm catchiness Mega Man is known for. Tundra Man and Block Man have the best music imo, while the Wily fortress boss fight themes are dreadful.

Cons
- The ending feels like it's building up to something entirely different. Final boss is disappointingly easy and the narrative finale is unsatisfying.
- Lack of hidden areas and secrets mean no exploration, no stumbling on anything cool. That's definitely more of a Mega Man X design philosophy than Classic series, but still felt disappointed by it.
- No alternate modes except for the Challenge mode.
- No alternate characters. Proto Man and Bass don't even show up in the game, let alone appear as platable characters.
- After Mega Man Powered Up I want every Mega Man game to have an alternate mode where Roll beats everyone up with a broom.

Conclusion
A great game, very worth playing whether you're new to the series or a long-time fan. Not without its flaws but most are overshadowed by how much good there is.

46526706.review: Tight controls, challenging stages, interesting character design, and cool powerups make this one of the best Mega Man games I've played in forever. The Double Gear mechanic can help out newer players by slowing down time or powering up your shots, but it's even useful for experienced players, and I'm hoping that they keep it around for the next installment. The shop also has items to help out if you just need an extra life, or to get past that one jump you're having a tough time making, and there's more than enough of the game's currency to go around. The soundtrack is also pretty damn amazing, and normally I'd turn down my game's sound, but I left this one cranked. Overall, it's a great addition to the series, and if Capcom can keep up the momentum, I'll definitely be picking up Mega Man 12 if and when it drops in the future.

46266454.review:
Of course, I would recommend this to others. I also nominated this game for the best game with a machine award as well. 
I rate this game 8.5 out of 10, but that doesn't mean it can't win an award for my rating.

Pros: 
New Storyline
Great OST 
Increased Difficulty over time
LOVE the gear System
Perfect game for Newcomers
Achievements are awesome

Cons:// 
Ending was a bit different than previous games
I didn't enjoy Bounce Man's level as much as I have enjoyed the other Bosses' levels.
I felt like Bounce Man's level was quite frankly rushed as most of the level was climbing floors and bouncing your way all the way to the top of the area... and the mech robots looked incredibly strange in the area. I spent more time navigating myself through this level more than any other level in the game.. 

Down to the meat of the review now.
I want to let you know I did nominate this game for that award due to how much fun I had overall with machines and Robots. This game is like the best Robotic game I have played in 2018. It's a B grade title, because of the level of Bounce Man being unsually different and mostly bouncing your way around the level. Shooting down these pusher blocks and defeating enemies as you make your way toward Bounce man. I also, didn't like the song for that character. All the others, I did enjoy. IT DOES have an AMAZING OST if you're into Techno, Dub-Steps.. that sort of thing. Bounce Man is more pop feeling like you were at an amusement park, but more annoying than pleasant. Mostly, this is my own opinion on one song that I didn't like. But, the other songs like Acid Man, Torch Man, Fuse Man, etc! Are like amazing songs in their tracks! 

I actually pre-ordered this game once I found out it was releasing on Steam. I like the Double Gear System. It's designed as a helpful tool especially with the boss battles. The slow time feature helps with knowing when to dodge enemies, but you can't overuse it or else you have to wait a period of time before you could use it again. [But, it still helps tremendously with boss battles knowing when to evade/dodge them.] The Overcharge feature is helpful when you're really into a Hack/slash mode wanting to unleash a lot of power on your enemies. However, again.. you have to be extremely careful with this even at this setting. Because, the system does turn off when it's overused and you have to wait a period of time before you could use it again. It's handy with the power-ups and with boss battles when you want to unleash wrath on them.

Aside from that... I loved the Artwork. 
characters, storyline... I just didn't understand the confrontation too much between Wily and Light at the end of the tunnel, but it's just me. Who knows if we get more content? That would be awesome! I found Wily's Plan B is super funny when he's trying to get Mega/Rock to "Spare him" = Spoiler warning.

I'm still working on getting all achievements on 11, but in the mean time enjoy the review.
If you played the game and didn't like it. It's completely understandable! 
I know people who bought this and told me, they didn't like it over trying to adapt to Double Gear and the fact the levels are too hard for them. Personally, I love the challenge. Block Man was like super careful for me, as LEVEL 1 choice. I had to really pay attention to Block structure and make sure I landed Mega/Rock accordingly to succeed! The other levels aside from Bounce Man were very ENJOYABLE. 

This game reminds me of Rock/Paper scissors with ELEMENTS among ROBOTS. Still, a super done game! 
I just would have changed Bounce Man's song and overall level to be more enjoyable. 

Still my favorite game of 2018 for more fun with a machine due to I loved the storyline. Although, the ending was rather different than the past Original MegaMan/Rock Man games.

46244315.review:
A lot better than i expected it to be.

There's really only two complaints i have with this game:

The music isn't as spectacular as everyone hoped.  Mega Man games have routinely had top notch exceptional music soundtracks, every song being an instant classic.  In this one however the music is very forgettable and almost unnoticeable in comparison.  That being said there is many music conversion packs people have created and will create to rectify this problem (The most recent one i tried was the 8-bit version)..

The only other complaint i have is minor, in that it's hard to tell where Mega Man's hit box is so jumping in tight areas like Torch Man stage gets a little frustrating, but you can get use to that.

Also, there's really only 2 full Wily stages (not including Wily and the re-fights), but all the robot master levels are longer than normal so it kind of makes up for it.  Still a bit of a disappointment when you get there, but it's not a huge deal.  One more Wily level probably would have done the trick.

Overall, very nicely done.  Might be controversial, but I might even consider it to be in the top 5 if not top 3 best classic Mega Man games (classic meaning 1-11 not including the X or Zero series, which i have actually not played yet).

------------------------------
Control Scheme I Used:
Gamepad defaults with D-Pad for movement.  May have rebound auto fire button.

------------------------------
Worth the current price (CDN$ 39.99)?  This might be a hard sell, even fans of Mega Man.
What I actually paid: $31.99

------------------------------
Completionist Review:
DLC Achievements:  None
Rating:  There's a fair bit of work
Can be completed in one run:  No, there's challenges and things outside the main game.
Chapter Select: Kind of, you can pick the level order, and which challenges to start.
Did I need/use a guide?  No.

Lots of things to get here for achievements, including a speedrun, which took a couple attempts.  Overall lots of fun though really, and the challenges are different and interesting for the most part.

Jeeesus christ... I wrote a review, but... it was apparently too big. I didn't even know steam HAD a character limit for reviews. I mean, my WarFrame one was obnoxiously huge and that posted just fine? I guess my MegaMan-11 review was too obnoxiously huge-er?

Uh... damn... it's really demotivating having to scrap the whole thing. I was kinda proud of it. I guess I'll just summarize my points and if anyone wants a more thorough explanation I guess they can ask?

The main things I wanted to talk about I guess were the Music and the Difficulty. Music because it was the only negative point I thought the game had, and Difficulty because I saw a lot of people griping about it and wanted to respond (similar to my Shovel Knight review).

So, Music...

I don't... I don't HATE the music. It's... good? I have trouble saying that, but I at least know I don't think the music is BAD.

It's just... y'know?

MegaMan has such a STELLAR reputation with music. If I had to make a list of all of the best video-game music I ever heard in my LIFE, much of the top half of the rather comprehensive list would be dedicated to MegaMan songs throughout the ages. SnakeMan, ChargeMan, FreezeMan, Armored Armadillo, Blast Hornet, Mattrex, oh god... how iconic is the X vs Zero theme from X5!?

There aren't enough words on the planet to tell you how I basically WORSHIP MegaMan for all the good music it has. I recall the stage music from every classic bot from 1-11 by heart, and most of the MegaMan-X series (only a few from X8 escape me, such as Gigavolt Manowar and Avalanche Yeti).

But 11? It kinda... it kinda dropped the ball.

Again, it's not like the music is bad. It's just... it has such big shoes to fill. Such phenomenally big shoes. And I've heard people make the unbelievably stupid defense of "oh you just hate it because it's not NES chiptunes". Like, [i]how fucking stupid do you gotta be to forget MegaMan 7 and 8 were things that existed[/i]. And why only Classic? I'm also comparing to X and there's NOTHING unfair about that. MegaMan X music isn't directly superior to Classic MegaMan music. What the hell kinda fan says dumb shit like that? [i]The kinda fan I'd [b]excommunicate[/b], is what[/i].

But, like I said, it's not bad. It didn't hit the mark I was expecting, but it works for what we've got. I'll give the music a barely passing 6.5 out of 10.

As for the difficulty, I'll just say this.

You can...
[list]
[*]A) Play the game the way it's [i]intended[/i], and make full and unrestricted use of your Gear System, Special Weapons, and a variety of consumables and parts lovingly prepared for you by your family who's always got your back, or...
[*]B) Do [b]none[/b] of that, go pure Buster-Only and make life [i]un-necessarily[/i] hard on yourself for [i]no goddamn reason[/i] and then complain the game is too hard.[/list]

If you're looking for a "real" challenge, SuperHero mode is... alright, I guess. It mainly just removes item pickups from the stages, and makes it so the only things that drop from enemies are screws. So if you want to recover health or weapon energy you need to use consumables like E/W-Tanks or Eddie.

So if you really want a challenge just pick Option-B. It's not entirely un-fun! I give difficulty a solid 10/10. Got easier modes if you want, got ways to make it harder if you want.


So... what else to say? Game's good. Looks and feels great. Boss designs are fantastic and I want a TundraMan action figure sometime in the future. Go get it!

I give MegaMan-11 a solid MegaMan-10 out of MegaMan-X.

46070849.review:
This is the most fun a person who enjoys Mega Man could ever have. There is totally no objectivity here. ;)

The stages are pretty good, though definitely long. This makes up for the amount of stages there are. These stages have great level design (Though, I've run into only a few problems with the enemies being in odd places and cheap placements) and have interesting gimmicks. The only stage that has an oddly executed gimmick would either be Bounce Man or Torch Man. Torch Man's gimmick is kind of cheap if you don't know it's coming and the enemy placements that are found in these firewall sections are placed specifically to be annoying if you don't know they're there. This gimmick is fine if you already have played the stage or seen the firewall in a video. The Bounce Man gimmick is just annoying to work with, especially when your motion-sicknessing around the whole place towards the end. Otherwise, pretty good.

The enemies are a nice variety, though you happen upon a select few through several of the robot master stages. They all have pretty nice telegraphs and the enemies that are self-explanatory are, well, just that. The only possibly bad enemy would be the one that shoots in eight directions. Sometimes, it's hard to see with the effects. 

Speaking of effects, the game looks great. Despite Mega Man in 2.5D being an iffy thing to have, this game executes it well in a way that doesn't consistently hinder the player's experience. The only problem is the huge explosions, which can hide enemy shots and can distract players easily. 

The bosses are my favorite part. They have easy to memorize patterns and the ones who focus on distance are usually challenging and fun, like Torch Man. Tundra Man, though doesn't telegraph, has easy to dodge attacks and always does the same thing. Having a Mega Man boss without telegraphs is a risky decision, but the boss works well with less animations to slow the fight down. The Wily Bosses are also well executed, though the first boss didn't really disappoint me, but more of just excited me to see what they would do with the gears. 

Oh, and the gears. The gear system is pretty good for beginners who aren't well practiced with Mega Man, but it also opens up choices for people who speedrun these games due to the Time Gear slowing down time in levels and the Power Gear having the ability to destroy literally every mid-boss and boss in the game pretty quickly. 

This game is also a bunch of fun. There's also replayability in the new game modes, challenges, and different routes that you could take in the game, though, I would probably lower the price a bit because there isn't enough content that would make one play this game for more than several hours unless they were a Mega Man fan. 

10/11 I guess.

45760273.review:
Megaman 11 is MEGA GREAT!

As usual it has its megaman level difficulty, which is quite hard, but it features a lab where you can buy extra lives, health regens, and items to negate insta-kills like spikes or falling off the map.

The new double gear ability allows you to either slow down time, or increase the power of your weapons, or both. Being able to slow down time is definitely helpful in various areas, and increasing the power of boss weapons you've obtained can help out alot against minibosses and robot masters.

While the game has things like water physics, wind physics, ice physics, or water with wind physics, and ice with wind physics, it doesn't do any of these things in too cheap or annoying of a way. In water you don't really move slower, it just lets you jump a lot faster and higher (which can be tricky if there are instant death spikes around).

If slipping on ice is too bothersome, you can also buy boots to negate the ice physics. Though usually jumping constantly is a good enough way to ignore how slippery the ice is, because the ice's friction and your jumping does not take into account your existing velocity, meaning you won't have to worry about things like having difficult to control jumping or landing.

Of course, many of the challenges in each stage aren't too difficult to learn, though jumping into them they may seem challenging, there is usually a way to make things easier, like slowing down time to navigate the tight platforming while you run away from the deadly fire walls in Torch Man's stage, or using Block Man's weapon to destroy the chemical droplet enemies before they turn the floor into dangerous acid, or using acid man's weapon to complete ignore a huge falling platform section full of homing missile and other projectile enemies.

Megaman 11 does what I really loved about Megaman 8 - it's a game where, the more you learn how to beat its challenges, the easier they become, to the point where your mastery of the game becomes a very tangible achievement as you shrug off things that you could previously barely E-tank your way through.

As a closing tip: Making use of the double gear system for time slowing is much easier with a controller than with keyboard controls.

45701433.review:
Not much to say except that Capcom is doing right by the Megaman franchise. Can't complain about the visuals - it's 2.5D that uses cel-shading, so it's pretty smooth and will age well. It's not particularly resource intensive. Even a low-end gaming build from the past 3 years will have no trouble running things.

As far as the game itself, it's exactly what you'd expect from a Megaman game - balls hard and full of instadeaths, precision-platforming, and varied bosses that have specific weaknesses to other bosses' powers. Aside from the gear system (one boosts your offense and the other slows down time) the big difference this time around is that Capcom added a lower difficulty for casuals. Try it out if you're intimidated by the normal difficulty:

The beginner's difficulty lowers the damage you get and removes instadeaths (spikes/acids are no longer instant death, and you have a little bird that will pick you up when you fall into the bottomless pits). Casual players who have problems with precision jumping and twitch shooting will still be challenged, but they'll have ample opportunity to retry until they succeed in specific sections.

The Robot Master have quite short battles (Except for Block Man, not the best battle but has stages which make it quite fun and interesting)
There is no need to use any weakness due to how easy the battles are. I played on the max difficulty and it was a park walk.

Is it worth $30 given current game standards? No… But I believe this is the start for something big.

Too much input lag, even after turning off Vsync. It didn't really become a problem until Wily Stage 1, which is full of quick jumps across small platforms over bottomless pits. I wish it had been a problem earlier in the game (it was noticable before, but easier to deal with in the easier stages) so I could have gotten a refund.

If they ever release a patch that reduces the input lag, or a mod becomes available that does a good job, then I would recommend this game.

UPDATE: I'm going to change this to recommended. After I finally got through Wily 1, the rest of the game was a breeze. 45441248.review:
[u]TLDR:[/u]
Mega Man 11 is the successor the series deserves. It makes a lot of clever improvements without watering down the traditional core gameplay. Despite a few minor shortcomings, the game can be heartfully recommended to veterans as well as to players looking for a challenging shoot n' run. While the game may not be long, it does have a lot of replay value, so the price tag is mostly justified in my opinion.

[u]Story:[/u]
There is a little bit more story than in the older Mega Man games, but this is not a game played for the story. You still fight Wily and that's basically it.

[u]Gameplay:[/u]
Like in the classic Mega Man games you basically run through a linear level, shoot everything in sight, fight a boss at the end and, if you beat him, get his weapon. It feels like it should and I never felt like it wasn't my fault if I died. While the game has a four difficulty settings, beginners should expect that it will take a while until they beat their first level, even on the "easy" difficulties. The trade-off is that it feels amazing to completely annihilate a level, once you have figured out how to beat it.

What's new is the gear system, which is allows the player to switch into one of two modes for a short time. The speed gear is basically slow motion, while the power gear allows you to charge you standard Mega-Buster even further and - way more important - allows you to instantly fire powered versions of the boss weapons you have collected. The later strikes me as a clear improvement tho the old charge-system introduced in the X-Series.

What is great is that the system implemented surprisingly thoughtful. This means that every level can be beaten without using the gear system at all. However, this will make the game more challenging than even some of the classic games. However, even purist should grow to like the system once they learn that it is not just something to help new players, but that it also allows for a lot of new tricks and strategies, i.e. when speedrunning the game.

Also, it is a great idea to use the right control stick to select the weapons and to have to designated buttons for callings Rush Coil (a trampoline) or Rush Jet (allows you to fly). This does not make Mega Man as fast as the X or Zero-Games, but it does make the Gameplay way more fluid to be able to call Rush instantly without opening the menu.

[u]Graphics:[/u]
Unlike the older games, MM11 is fully in 3D, albeit still a 2D-Plattformer. While the artstyle may require some getting used to at first, the developers have wisely shoosen to put visibility first. This means that while the models may look a little bit "flat" like from a flash game at first, I never felt like i didn't have a clear view on the situation. Where the game look truly great is when it comes to lighting and explosions, which look simply fantastic and way more visceral than any Mega Man game before. 

Aside from that, the levels are diverse and you will spot a few very nice touches, like the adorable Metals around the campfire in Torch Man's stage.

Also it runs at a rock-solid 60 fps.

[u]Sound:[/u]
While the sounds for shooting, explosions, etc. definitely do sound like you are battling huge machines, the voice acting and the music may be the weak spots of the game. Mega Mans voice simply sounds a little too "mature" for my taste and may have been more fitting for the "older" X than the Mega Man. However, the Japanese voice-over is a little bit better, but also not great.

The music is definitely not bad, but it tends to get lost in the action. Also, while some tunes are catchy, you will not find anything as iconic as the Metal Man or Wily-Stage tunes from Mega Man 2. But frankly, this is an unreasonable expectation though.

[u]Content:[/u]
While the main story is a little bit on the short side in terms of levels, this gets mostly equalized by the fact, that the levels are a lot longer than in the Mega Man games before. However, I could not help but to be slightly disappointed that the Wily Fortress only consists of basically two levels this time. 

Where the game shines is in the extra modes, which not only allow for competitive speedrunning and boss rushes, but also provide many variations and different challenges on the levels and even a few extra-hard levels. I personally very much liked a mode where you have to shoot every blue balloon in a level while avoiding the red balloons. This may sound boring at first, but the developers did a stellar job positioning the balloons in a way that forces you to truly understand what each weapon in your disposal does. 

[u]Overall:[/u]
I love Mega Man 11. While it may not reinvent the genre, it does bring many new ideas to the table that are not just gimmicks, but actually improve the gameplay and may be used in all Mega Man games to come. Aside from that, the gameplay is fun and rock-solid as ever.

I personally hope that the team will be working on Mega Man X 9 next.

45428678.review:
Capcom manages to retain the classic gameplay, challenge and feel of old school 8-bit megaman, while giving it a shiny new coat of paint that enhances rather than detracts from the experience.

Pros:
-- Classic Megaman, unspoiled by the modern look.
-- Great visuals, especially the explosions and lighting effects on certain stages.
-- Great soundtrack, as any good megaman game should have.
-- Some of the best robot master stage design of the entire series.
-- Incredibly challenging, but with multiple difficulties and an item shop to alleviate the frustration for less hardcore players.
-- Double gear system is a great tool, but never becomes a necessary and overused gimmick or is required to beat any boss or section.
-- Great replayability(as all good megaman games have)

Cons:
-- Robot masters arent particularly challenging, even without using their weaknesses or the double gear system.
-- Price point is a bit steep for a 3-4 hour(tops) game(even if it has great replayability)
-- Robot master weaknesses arent very interesting(none of them change the fight), and their weapons are generally lackluster.

Conclusion:
If you love megaman, this is an easy buy.  It's easily on par with the other great classic megaman games, but has a great new look that enhances the experience rather than distracts from it.  The pros vastly outweigh the cons, which are little more than minor annoyances or things that could have been done better, not real problems with the game. 

It also has fantastic replay value, as there are tons of powerups to buy, and not all are straight upgrades with many offering weird alterations to how you play(like allowing you to go into desperation mode at any time, but with shorter duration).  With 3 difficulty modes, intense challenge(particularly on hard) and the ability(?) to forego any item shop upgrades or the use of double gear for an even more hardcore experience, this is a game megaman enthusiasts will get tons of play out of.

45331166.review:
It's the essence of Megaman, finally in a modern package. The graphics are all in beautiful HD, and there are plenty of modern conveniences.

Of note:
There are a ton of extra controls that finally use more than just two buttons on your controller. There are dedicated buttons to summon Rush (your dog assistant,) and as an alternative to pressing Down-Jump to slide or mashing your fire button, there's a Slide and Autofire button (though these aren't bound by default.)

There are four difficulty options for everyone: Newcomer has infinite lives, Casual simply gives a bit of extra health and checkpoints, and Superhero/Expert removes all items. Though Normal (aka Original Spec.) will give you the challenge that Megaman is expected to have.

All of the graphics are in ultra-high resolution, and it runs at 60 FPS – but there's no lag at all. There are points where the animations seem jerky, but that's intentional: it's so Megaman will always stay responsive to your input.

There is an actual difficulty curve now. You can still pick any stage you want in any order, but simply moving downwards or going clockwise should work nicely.
