I love Megaman. He reminds me of my childhood, so I guess I'm biased. This could've turned out terrible and I still would've bought it on day 1. Thank goodness that while some animations aren't fantastic, and the game gets a little too easy thanks to the gear system + the store, it's still really good.

The particle effects are really sweet and all the robot masters are really well designed. Each stage has a gimmick that plays really nicely, except maybe for the endlessly frustrating Bounce Man stage. This makes for a brand new experience every level, which is kind of a staple for the Megaman series. The robot master fights are all very fun, with each robot master having a distinct pattern to their attacks, so while they're hard to avoid, it'll never feel unfair. 

Unlike other games in series, Megaman now looks different with new armor parts and weapons every time he switches to a different robot master weapon, which I absolutely love. Other purists don't like it too much but I feel like it should've been something that was in Megaman 1. Can you imagine how Megaman would look with Cut Man's weapon on his head? 

The Dr. Light's Lab store makes the game a lot more accessible. The same can be said about the double gear system, even on the hardest difficulty. But good news is they're all pretty optional, so you can choose to make it very challenging. There's also an achievement for not using the store, so there's that.

All in all, it's a good Megaman game. It's probably one of my favorites.

45279399.review:
The introduction of a shop into Mega Man games has thrown them off balance. This one goes even further by having powered up versions of weapons which absolutely shred bosses and mid-bosses. It's a good game, but you will have to decide on a substantial amount of self-imposed rules to have an enjoyable experience; otherwise you can just plow through with 9 e-tanks, 9 lives, a time slow that trivializes platforming, and powered up versions of moves that trivialize the rest.

My personal recommendation is to play through superhero mode without buying consumable items and a life cap of 4-6 lives depending on personal preferences. Patricians might want to consider a Buster Only run.

45276090.review:
I've been a Mega Man fan ever since I was a kid back in the NES days, and I really enjoyed this game. Its great. I'd even say its one of the best games in the classic Mega Man series. The gameplay is great, the controls are great, the stages are great, the stages have different elements and things going on in them gameplay wise to make them stand out from each other, the boss fights are great, the weapon upgrades you get from bosses are cool, upgrade system similar to Mega Man 8's where you pick up bolts as you're playing and buy stuff when you're at the stage select, etc. Unlike the previous Mega Man games, this game runs on widescreen instead of a normal aspect ratio, and unlike lets say first person shooters, different aspect ratios have a significant impact on sidescrollers, and this game makes good use of widescreen, which is cool. I think I can speak for everyone when I say that this is how we were hoping Mighty No. 9 would turn out.

Mega Man 11 introduces the double gear mechanic, you can use it to either do a bullet-time like slowdown to avoid attacks and stuff easier, or to charge up your buster for an even more powerful shot beyond the regular buster charge. When you have double gear active, it generates heat, and theres a cooldown while you're not using it. If it heats up beyond the threshold then it becomes disabled and is unusable until it finishes cooling down (I think the cooldown actually might be slower after it gets overheated than the regular cooldown).

The graphics are good, they're simple but look nice and the game is very visually readable. The different weapons don't just change Mega Man's colors, they also give him different helmets and busters, I thought that was a neat touch. The music and voice acting are decent. The game also has extra stuff outside of the main game, such as all of these challenge missions and so on which all have online leaderboards, you can also upload your own and watch other peoples' replays of them doing these challenge missions. I imagine speedrunners will be happy as one of the challenge modes is a time attack mode where you can see how fast you can complete a stage and it shows your exact time.

One gripe I do have about this game is the superhero difficulty level, its unbalanced, poorly thought out and can use adjustments. In superhero, there are no longer items scattered throughout the stages, so the risky and tricky areas that have an extra life, energy tank or whatever lose purpose as the items are no longer present on superhero. Health, weapon energy and so on no longer drop from enemies, which is fine, but bolts still do and their chance to drop is increased by a good amount, so you're able to buy way more consumables and get upgrades way earlier than usual. So superhero takes a good step towards the hard direction, but a few steps back towards the easy direction. The amount of health enemies have in superhero is increased too, in another type of game having the difficulty level increase enemy health would be a good idea, but for this its a bad idea. The only thing superhero does right is increase how much damage enemies do. So I recommend playing the game on normal.

The greatest thing about this game is how gameplay feels. 

It plays just as tight and as responsive as classic 8-bit MM games, but while having very fluid and great looking animations at the same time. It shows that a lot of work went into this to get the best of both world. 

They learnt from the past not to repeat the same mistakes: in MM8 they added more frames to all anims just because they could, the result felt sluggish. In MM7 the low FOV made everything worse than it should be, but here with a widescreen ratio we end up with good looking characters and enemies of a reasonable size without hindering gameplay.
Animations and gameplay were really thought together, there are some nice touches like being able to break the guard of most shielded enemies with a charge shot and witness the funny anims that go with it. 
The only time this feels wrong is when Robot Masters use their Gear power-ups, as it took me a long time to figure out when you could hit them or not when they did.

There are only 10 full stages + 2 small ones, but each of those 10 stages is at least 50% longer than in previous classic MM games, so there is more base content than in MM7 or 8 for instance. This being said, I would rather have more but shorter stages instead, game flow and feeling of progression would be better that way.

I am a little disappointed however by the design philosophy of those stages. While MM9 and 10 dared to challenge players, 11 doesn't so much, and on top of this, keeps giving the player a ton of easy way outs that they can use instead of having them learn. The Double Gear, although not the only one, is the prime element of that philosophy, press a button and you have an easy way out, and an un-fun one at that: fun comes from fast paced tight action, while the speed gear slows down everything... Also, the more you use the easy way outs, the more the game helps you by unlocking upgrades for them, that's how far the philosophy goes. 
You don't have to use any of those easy way out if you don't want to though, except for one exception.

This being said, the stages, bosses, and challenges that come with them are still better than in 5, 6, 8, perhaps even 7.

Weapons could have been more fun, half of them have their attack delayed one way or another, which sucks the fun out of them. Press button, mandatory wait, attack unleashes... 
The Pile Driver though, a dash attack that you can even pull in mid air and as long as you energy for it, is amazing.

With this base content comes a bunch of challenges, some of which are fun and unique content like Doctor Light's Trial. 
The hard difficulty was very disappointing compared to 9 and 10's hard modes... These changed enemy placement to play around players' expectations, but here there is no changes in stages except stats (MM recieves double the damage, basic enemies take 2 shots to kill instead of 1) and all pick-ups disappeared...  The AI of bosses is enhanced like in 10's hard mode, but unlike in 10, only less than half of them in a substancial way that really asks the player to fight them differently.

Despite what I said about the quality of animations, and although I've seen worse, I'm not fond of the general graphical style and "2.5D" in general, and would rather have had high-res 2D graphics, like Wario Land Shake Dimension or Duck Tales Remastered. 
This approach takes more time and ressources though, and those games are shorter probably because of it, one can't have everything.

Musics are good, but the sounds they use lack power. It all sounds too smooth, mixed in together, and what should sound impactful doesn't.
Cutscenes are sluggish, they drag on and on for far longer than they should. All skippable.
Voice acting is a little annoying, a bit less so in Jap. Volume can be turned down.

Despite all the negative points I said, this is still a very good classic MM game, not the best MM game but far from the worst. 
Tight gameplay, good stages and bosses, fair amount of content, and that's what matters most.

P.S:
- Where's Protoman ?! It's the first time he's absent since he appeared. I hope they hid him only to bring him back harder in a DLC.

As a fan of the games since I was a kid (but mostly Mega Man 6 and later Mega Man X, honestly), this is the perfect throwback with a combination of tight gameplay and frustrating timing-based puzzles.

What I like best is that it's about as frustratingly difficult as Mega Man 1 (played on Normal anyway).  Still the required perfect jumping and sliding and furious shooting.  One major difference from the ones I remember is that in addition to Rush upgrades and boss weapons, you also can collect gears for buying upgrades to your core abilities, things like auto-charging your weapon or sliding less on ice.  These are a great offset because the more casual gamers like me still get some kind of payoff for the hours of dying over and over again, because at least you can stock up on stuff and probably make it through the level.

For all you hardcore gamers, you can just do it "hardcore" and not get any upgrades.  I, for one, enjoy the more casual approach since I don't have hours and hours to dedicate to this game.  It's a good balance between the two, I think.

$30 was a bit high in my opinion; should have been $20, but obviously I bought it, so I guess they had my number.

45242778.review:
This game is easily summarized. It's an adept imitation of the old Mega Man games on the NES, with polished graphics, modern tunes and some challenge/time attack modes (presumably because speedrunning has become a fairly notable community). This would be a good package, if slavishly imitating 30 year old NES titles were in itself interesting or commendable. Unfortunately, it is neither of those things, and this game is a boring, archaic throwback. Capcom themselves recognized this, and packed the game to the gills with itemization that band-aids the harshest failures of such mimicry.

Do yourself a favor and dust off your copy of Mega Man X, instead, or go check out 20XX right here in the Steam store. Remember what it's like when a series goes forward and the people making the games recognize that just because there's a way something has been done in the past, doesn't mean it's the way to keep doing it.

Mega Man has always been my favorite video game series. I could not have been more excited waiting for this game for the last several months. I loved the NES art style of Mega Man 9 and 10, and was equally excited to see the art return to a format similar to Mega Man 8. Will some fans criticize the art style or voice acting? Of course, but this was still a very enjoyable experience no matter what your initial worry may be. 

The stages offer a few fresh gimmicks to keep you on your toes and the difficulty seems just right to give this that classic Mega Man feel. I enjoyed seeing some familiar enemies and bosses as a nice "nod" to the classic games. Expect to die several times on the first play through, maybe even use a few E-Tanks, but be able to breeze through each stage after a few plays. Lots of replay value too with challenges.

Overall a great new addition to the series and let's hope Capcom won't make us wait so long for the next installment.

I suck at this game though I don't have the intestinal fortitude to keep bashing my head against the wall to try and beat the game. The fact that this is difficult for a veteran platformer like myself is awesome.

45225027.review:
The perfect megaman game to introduce both newcomers and veterans. The stages are long and challenging, the bosses flashy and fun to fight against and the weapons, oh the weapons, they feel great to use. The greatest attraction of this title is that it allows the player to make the experience as casual or challenging as they want. You can choose one of several difficulty modes, and then opt in to purchase in game items from the shop using currency you collect. Damage reduction, extra health, ammo, powerups, etc. You could stock up on 9 E-tanks and spam heal yourself if you chose, it really does allow you to play how you want. 

The main change with this title however is the introduction of the double gear system which allows you to either slow down time to avoid attacks/platform, or boost your damage dealing capabilities. Again, the game does not force anything on you, so its entirely possible to beat the game without this system. Its added in as another fun tool for the player to use.

All in all, a great title for the series.

[b][ Personal Notes ][/b]
A new single player Mega Man 11 is finally here. If you are a fan - stop reading this and get the game. For others, if you are up for a challenge and some precision platforming I have a couple of things to say about the game.

The story of two professors who were once friends but now pursue their own goals with superb voice acting. The artstyle is beautiful and the game looks really polished and clean. The soundtrack is amazing and enjoyed it so much that had to download it. SFXs though are more on a generic side.

You'll face 8 Robot Masters before confronting the final boss and each of them will have their own thematic wolrd filled with unique mechanics, enemies, hazards and an unlockable special weapons. Each bosses have their own basic and unique attacks, but all comes to learning their patterns and mastering it. In fact the whole game relies on memorisation of enemy locations and if you remember all of it, you can easily finish stages without taking a single hit.

Level design is great because obstacles and hazards change depending on the chosen world. You can use you helpful robo-dog Rush in order to jump higher or surf towards a rare consumable. Your double gear system, which was introduced in this game to aid you in your journey (slowing down everything around or boosting your power) will give you an extra edge in a tight situation. Furthermore, if you are low on health, you can go all-in and use both gears simultaneously. While this will heat up Mega Man very fast, it can and will save your life if used properly (good balance of risk and reward).

Battling in general is great, while you can skip most of the enemies, I tried to fight every single enemy I could. Every robot master as well as enemies inhabiting their world are vulnerable towards specific element. So unique wepons, which you get from robot masters, do not feel useless at all. In fact you are likely to use them more than just exploiting weaknesses of the bosses because they can aid you to traverse levels faster or clear the screen of smaller enemies entirely.

In-game shop offers consumables and upgrade parts. While you can forget about your extra consumables, upgrading parts feel satisfying and on point, giving you exactly what you wish you had.

What I disliked the most are the challenges and Bounce Man world. 
Most of the challegnes are simple, with even simpler rewards (gold, silver and bronze medals). Others will test your patience especially Dr. Light's Trial which leaves very little room for an error. If you are an achievement hunter, this will be the hardest one (although some may argue that beating the game in under an hour is tougher). 
Hitboxes of balloons in Bounce Man's world are infuriating sometimes. You will hit it before you should and bounce like crazy before your brain will catch up what happened there, so you've been warned.

Lastly, beating the game on hardest difficulty, getting golden rank on all challenges and unlocking all of the achievements rewards you with nothing. Really, no special upgrade, no bonus ending, nothing for completing the game.

I would recommend this game to newcomers, casuals, obviously fans but for completionists - just pass it. You will put yourself through a lot and get nothing in return, apart from satisfaction that you have finally beaten everything.

45212112.review:
[h1]Rock-y Controls![/h1]

The control set-up is significantly different than previous titles in both the Classic [i]MegaMan[/i] series and also the [i]MegaMan X[/i] series.  I am happy MegaMan's back, but what's the point of playing if the controls hamper the player's ability to do so?

[b]Unlike in all previous games of Classic [i]MegaMan[/i], Rush Coil and Rush Jet CANNOT be mapped to the same button as other weapons and must be assigned separate buttons (including from one another) or not at all.[/b]
Other than control sticks and the d-pad, most controllers have the following buttons:
Start,
Select,
L1 and R1 (and sometimes L2 and R2),
And the four "main" buttons of square (X), cross (A), circle (B), and triangle (Y).

In [i]MegaMan 11[/i], The Power Gear and Speed Gear as well as the Previous Weapon and Subsequent Weapon toggles are reasonably mapped to L1 and R1 and L2 and R2 by default, but there are also six other non-movement functions: shoot/charge, jump, slide, shoot rapid-fire, Rush Coil, and Rush Jet.  But (other than Start and Select) there are only four other buttons these functions can be assigned to.  To its credit, the game does allow sliding by pushing the 'jump' button while pressing 'down' on the d-pad at the same time, but it is much more comfortable to assign 'slide' to one of the four main buttons, like how the 'dash' function is assigned in the [i]MegaMan X[/i] series.

[b]In [i]MegaMan 11[/i] the player can call Rush even when his special-energy gauge does not appear on screen![/b]  Rush Coil and Rush Jet now use the same special energy, and the special-energy bar that allows players to see how much of Rush's special energy is left is only visible when MegaMan is in "normal style" (i.e. when he does not have a special weapon equipped).  This keeps the screen from becoming cluttered, which is a good thing, but the player ISN'T able to see how much special energy is left for Rush abilities if a special weapon is equipped; yet the player can still call Rush when MegaMan is equipped with a special weapon, automatically unequipping the special weapon, which if Rush's special energy turns out to be low may in the heat of battle prove to be a disastrous mistake!

[b]The controls feel like a big step back from [i]MegaMan 9[/i] and [i]MegaMan 10[/i] in which all special weapons and in-game functions were accessible without pausing the game.[/b]  The Rush abilities are realistically still special weapons just like in previous classic MegaMan games, and they still have a special-energy gauge and take special energy, so pressing the same button to use special weapons as to use one of the abilities like in earlier games would have made more sense and seems more intuitive.

Plus, why bother to map Rush Coil to a button by default if Rush Jet does not have a button by default?  If players such as speed-runners like the option of being able to call Rush at all times, that's fine, but I prefer not being able to de-equip my special weapons needlessly or by mistake.  Again, I do like how the player can use Rush abilities with "normal" MegaMan now, but [b] without the freedom to freely assign which button I want to press to use my special weapons the new control scheme remains finicky.[/b]  In any case, [b]making both Rush abilities separate from special weapons has crowded out other functions such as 'rapid-fire' and 'slide', which was not the case in past MegaMan titles[/b]; this has hampered me so much that I have resorted to only calling Rush by means of the in-game menu, which defeats the point of making the other abilities accessible and slows game-play down unnecessarily.

Even though MegaMan also has the ability to metamorphose into different 'styles' just like in the MegaMan Battle Network games, which is very cool, this new ability doesn't affect the game's mechanics in the slightest.  The styles make me feel motivated to complete a stage with the same special weapon equipped, but [b]using 'rapid-fire' automatically unequips special weapons just like calling Rush does, plus MegaMan reverts back to normal anyway if his equipped weapon runs out of ammo, so it becomes impossible to complete a stage with a single style if the special weapon runs out of its special energy.[/b]  Ideally, it would be preferable to allow the player to keep the equipped special weapon even if there is no ammo left for it, allowing the player to survive with buster shots until MegaMan picks up more special energy for the equipped weapon (after all, any special energy MegaMan finds normally goes towards his currently equipped special weapon if he has one equipped).  Doing so would also show how MegaMan's metamorphoses have a positive impact upon game-play beyond their visual appeal by allowing MegaMan to more easily maintain his special weapons.

As for the controls, [b]a better set-up would be similar to the controls of [i]MegaMan X4[/i], which gave the 'special weapon' function its own button and allowed the X-buster to be used with a special weapon still equipped alongside the two other functions of jumping and dashing[/b]: four functions for four buttons.  As I mentioned, [i]MegaMan 11[/i]'s has many separate functions but only four buttons to use for them.  Even so, a new set-up for [i]MegaMan 11[/i] could look something like this:

[u]MegaMan (no special weapon equipped):[/u]
1 (square/X) > Shoot and charge buster
2 (cross/A) > Jump
3 (circle/B) > Rush Jet or Slide
4 (triangle/Y) > Rush Coil or Shoot rapid-fire buster

[u]MegaMan (special weapon equipped):[/u]
1 (square/X) > Shoot and charge buster or Shoot special weapon
2 (cross/A) > Jump or Shoot special weapon
3 (circle/B) > Rush Jet (auto-unequips the current special weapon) or Slide or Shoot special weapon
4 (triangle/Y) > Rush Coil (auto-unequips the current special weapon) or Shoot rapid-fire buster or Shoot special weapon

The 'Shoot special weapon' function, when equipped, would take precedence over whichever other function is assigned to the same button, and this set-up has the additional benefit of allowing MegaMan to fire buster shots with a special weapon still equipped similar to the controls in [i]MegaMan X4[/i]; if balancing becomes an issue as a result, perhaps the charge shot could be reduced one level while a special weapon is equipped (similar to how only a small "partial" charge shot was ever possible in [i]MegaMan 4[/i]).  If players prefer mapping 'Rush Coil' and 'Rush Jet' to buttons, perhaps 'rapid-fire' could also be achieved with 'jump' + 'up' on the d-pad, just like 'slide' can be done with 'jump' + 'down' on the d-pad, or alternatively as I would prefer 'Rush Coil' could be 'jump' + 'up' and 'Rush Jet' could be 'jump' + 'down', and 'rapid fire' and 'slide' could instead be assigned to buttons.

[b]I sincerely hope that in an update Capcom gives players greater freedom to change the control scheme in the options' menu, such as the ability to assign the ability to shoot special weapons to the same button as either Rush Coil or Rush Jet[/b]:  They did after all share the same button in past games of the series.  [b]It would also be very welcome if MegaMan could fire buster shots while having special weapons equipped.[/b]  For now I am too frustrated with the new control scheme to be able to progress any farther in the game.  (Ironically, as I said, I haven't had any trouble with the Speed Gear and Power Gear controls.)  I've never had issues with the controls of a game I haven't been able to fix by means of the options' menu before, and I was greatly looking forward to this game so the wonkiness of the new controls was a huge disappointment to me.  I hope my comment is able to draw attention to these issues; nevertheless, I am happy other people have found enjoyment in the game.

[u]P.S.[/u] In [i]MegaMan 11[/i], MegaMan's never called by his real, civilian name: Rock.  That's like Lois Lane never calling Superman 'Clark'.  Boo!  [b]Call MegaMan 'Rock', sometimes, Capcom![/b]

45193839.review: 9\10 Hands down the best Mega Man release in over two decades. I have been a blue bomber fan since the beginning back in 1987 and have been waiting a long time for a title this good. 45192066.review:
Well, this a classic Megaman game like we love them. Beat the robot masters, proceed to Wily's castle, beat more bosses, get killed by spikes, fall to your death...

I like the level design of this one. There aren't that many spikes, platforming is manageable, overall it's not too hard, but still challenging.

There's a shop in game in which you can buy more lives, energy tanks, and tools to help you beat each level more easily. To be honest, they tend to make the game too easy, as you can just buy as many lives and enery tanks as you can, and spam them on the bosses. But that's up to you.

The Double Gear system is nice, but just like the shop, you don't need it to complete the game. I've been using the Speed Gear a lot because I suck at reacting quickly, but a player with more skills wouldn't need it.

The OST isn't too bad, but forgettable. You can't beat 8bit tunes for a classic Megaman game. The problem might come from the instruments, I don't know.

I haven't tried the challenges yet, not my cup of tea, but if you like to compete with other players, you'll love it. Boss rush and time attack modes are always welcome.

Overall, I'm glad I bought it, though I feel that 30€ is a bit too much. But I'm happy enough that they keep making old-school games like this one. If you enjoyed NES and SNES megaman games, go get this one, you won't regret it !

Oh, also, it's nice to see young Light and Wily ! In this game more than in any other, Wily seems to be a misunderstood lad whose pride won't let him give up.

45191650.review:
Ok let's get down to the point: is it good? Yes. If you are a Mega man fan this is a good Mega Man. And if you are not and want to try and play one of these for the first time, the Slow Motion ability will help you get up to speed, appropriately enough.

Now I'm on the first camp, being a MM fan since the 90's so I can attest that even though the basics all work, the game feels a little lacking. There are no secrets to be found on the stages, and the game is only like 12 stages long. They are all challenging at first, but soon you'll be flying through them. Some.
There is also the fact that the Super Shot that is meant to be the other half of the Double Gear mechanic is basically useless. Or at least it was for me, I only used it in like two bosses and the rest of the game I use the Slow Motion which... is kind of OP.
And once you get a handful of Bolts... the game is basically over. You got instant access to 1ups E and W tanks and other useful stuff, so you can load yourself up with them and blaze through most of the game. But that is something you opt into so it's easy to ignore, and great help if you are struggling I guess.
Oh, and most of the boss weapons are great fun. I am usually switching between 6 out of the 8 at any given time.

Now my computer is not the best, but I understand the game in general can have performances issues. I saw stuttering at the most busiest boss fights like Block Man or Blast Man. I understand other had bigger issues though, so you should check the negative reviews to find more details.

To summarize, it's Mega Man. And it's good, if a little short. I have now defeated the game on Normal and Hard on about 10.6 hours plus a couple of the boss rush challenges (there is a challenge mode but, most of them didn't really sound interesting). So if you are worried for value over time you might want to average that with the price. For the record I am a long time MM player that is surprisingly not that great.

45190857.review:
TLDR: This looks and plays just like a MegaMan game should, but with way less stuff than previous games gave us.

The Double-Gear system is not a tool for newbies to get the hang of MM games.  Every stage ramps up in difficulty to the point where you are pushed to use the Speed Gear to survive.  (Or you're just insanely good to manage without.)  That's sort of a good thing, because it gave the new feature use, but it doesn't exactly make MM11 a better game, just a different game.

Here's the list of things missing that were prevalent in the previous MM games:
[list]
[*]No intro stage. (just cutscenes)
[*]No mid-game stage (after 4 bosses). (just cutscenes)
[*]No Protoman appearance.
[*]No Bass and/or Treble appearance.
[*]No utility aspect to weapons.*
[*]Run animation still looks stupid.
[/list]

* Regarding the "No utility aspect to weapons" part, think of Crash Bomb's ability to destroy certain walls in MM2.  Nothing like that exists with the exception of the Pile Driver obtained from Impact Man, which can allow you to get under certain platforms.

If none of that bothers you, then you'll have a fun MM time.  There's still the 8 robot masters you'll have to fight again in Wily's stages, and you can buy upgrades between stages.  I personally don't mind the voice acting at all, but obviously if you're a weeaboo, you probably won't like it and I think you can switch it to Japanese anyway.

I recommend against this game because for $40, you are getting a pretty watered down MegaMan game.

It's just great, many of the robot masters look like or draw inspiration from classic robots in the series, the graphics are beautiful and the level design is inspired. 45180664.review:
Megaman 11 is a great example of a modernization of a classic franchise. While Megaman 9 and 10 were great games in their own right, their desire to stay so similar to Megaman 2 ended up hurting them in the long run, removing long standing mechanics implemented in the franchise such as the charge shot and the slide, and only having them available as DLC in the form of protoman, who had these mechanics as well as a shield to block projectiles, but at the cost of taking more damage. Now, in Megaman 11, the slide and charge shot have finally returned for Megaman, and it's very nice to have them back. Not only that, but the game comes with a brand new mechanic - the double gear system. This system allows you to use the Speed Gear to slow down the world, and you as well (unless you buy an upgrade in the shop), and the Power Gear, which soups up your systems and gives you the ability to fire multiple charge shots and power up special weapons, almost as if borrowing from the X series. These perks come at the cost of a limited timer, and should you exhaust it, you will be left on a cooldown unable to use the function until you run the timer out or collect a gear powerup that reduces the cooldown. Not only that but there is also a final desperation mode, where if you are at low enough health you can activate both gears at once, but make sure you take out your opponent or you will be left even weaker than before after the timer runs out, being able only to have one projectile on screen at a time along with being unable to use any gear powers.

The robot masters this time around are all super creative, and I really liked all the special weapons they gave me, especially when superchanged with the Power Gear. They also make short work of the robot masters as well, once you find their weakness, and it's pretty exhilarating to figure out the weakness order. Another neat thing I noticed was that the weapon a robot master was weak to also had a lot of great utility in their stage, so it's now a tradeoff - do you want an easier time in the stage, or an easier time fighting the boss? The bosses can also use the double gear system as well and make the fight a bit more intense, such as moving at blinding speeds or super charging their attacks. Overall, all 8 robot masters are vert challenging and I had a great time tackling them and their stages.

We're going to get a bit into SPOILER territory now, but I feel I need to talk about the Wily stages, as in my honest opinion I feel they kind of dropped the ball here. MM9 and 10 may have spoiled me, but I've been so used to the castle stages having a unique music track for every stage. Not in 11 - you only get one single music track for all 4 stages. While it's a great theme, it does get a bit old after the first few stages. Not only that, but the bosses are a bit underwhelming too. The first boss is just the Yellow Devil again (it's technically the MK III but it looks identical to the original apart from the gear pattern in its eye, which is admittedly a nice touch). I'm really getting sick of these Devil-type bosses now. The boss of the second stage, while definitely more creative, kept reminding me of that bubble boss that was also from Megaman 1. The third stage is just a short drop to the Robot Master refights - no boss at the end, you just take a warp and the stage ends. After that, the final stage is just a climactic lift ride to the final boss, where small robots shoot at you every so often which ends with a Portal-esque end at a spike wall which I am embarrassed to say killed me a few more times than I'd like to admit. Eventually, I realized you just jump down off the lift. Then comes the Wily Machine, which of course leads into a Wily Capsule which this time takes heavy inspiration from Megaman 7's. While an overall challenging fight, it doesn't make up for having essentially only 2 full Wily stages.

Overall, despite the lackluster final stages, I still really appreciate the direction the series has taken. The Double Gear System is a fresh addition to the franchise and I hope another installment will come soon, hopefully with no hiatuses in between, that gives a slightly more fleshed out endgame.

45179050.review:
==========WARNING=============
This review is long. TLDR version is "It's awesome and accessible. Likeable and will be satisfying for both newcomers and pros alike" 

Ok, Here we go. 

I have to say that I was not at all a Megaman fan/player. I mean. I grew up during the boom of X series. I have heard and I have seen my older cousins got teir asses kicked playing classic series. But I never actually enjoyed plaing it myself. Why? Because it was frantically tough! That's why! And when the time passed. Video games evolved. As things got flashier, edgier and more complex, the blue hero started to fade out from my memory and it never really piqued any of my imterests at all despite several attempts to emulate it and play it on my PC. Same goes for X series.

But this changes everything! This is the first time I really enjoyed playing Megaman. I don't feel like a dumbass dying to bosses or failing to jump onto platforms. This game is amazingly accesscible for an adult me with a full-time job who gets to play games only on weekends. 

Here's why;

-Nice, clean and beautiful 2.5D style graphics! Superbly megaman!

I mean, I like the old 8 bit looks but i think we  can agree that it is time for an upgrade. And I have to say that this conversion from 2D to 3D or 2.5D is amazing. It really captures the essence of Megaman in a way that it's not too bland despite generous amount of flat colors used. The character designs are so great that the basic coloration and lighting bacome complimentary to the overall visual. As I said, It's very clean looking which I think a lot of fans and newcomers can appreciate.

-The difficulty options in abundant! You can now choose your poison!

I am not sure about the "new" new ones like 7-9 but from my memories when I was younger, 1-6 got nothing. You started the game. You kumped right into the actions. The somewhat difficulty choices might be the boss order that you go through because some are vulnerable to the weapons you get from the other bosses and if ou figure out where to start and where to go next, things might be slightly forgiving for you. I said slightly because the enemies along the way until boss battle will plough you hard no matter what. 

As for this iteration, you get to choose before you start the game which difficulties you want. You want easy? Go get it! You're a masochist? Who am I to judge? You can choose whatever you want which will affect the damage you take during the stages and also in boss fights.

-In game Shops! You get an item! You get item! Everyone gets an item! 

During the game, you collect bolts(?) which act as in-game currency for you to buy stuffs. And the stuffs are so damn good! Bored of sliding uncontrollably on ice platform? Here's a pair of spike boots! Running out of weapons power constantly? Here's weapon power tanks! Died from spikes much? Here's a save for dummies from spikes! and so much more that you can buy to make it easier or more accessible for you. I understand that the hardcore fans will be like "Heck! This is an insult! We don't need this at all! It's a disgrace". But hey! it's all optional. While it's there and the newbies like myself can buy some to alter our first time experiencing the game to suit our needs, the hardcore playing can totally avoid them all and play with none of theses upgrades or items with NO PENALTIES AT ALL FROM THE GAME DESIGN PERSPECTIVE. 

-New element in gameplay with double gears system!   

Ok. We all know by now that the game comes with double gears system. It's nice. I wouldn't say that it's something that will blow your mind but it can and will spice things up for you. To sum it up, Megaman now has 2 gear modes to activate at any given time. The power gear and the speed gear perform like the name suggests, one gives you attack boost and the other the speed. The stage was designed with this system in mind and you will be wise to utilise it. However, from my playthough, if your good enough, you don't really need them. The fact that it's there but quite optional makes me appreciate it a little bit more, to be honest. I mean, It means they're not forcing this down your throats which will definitely be frustrating for the old fans. 

The game is still the same. It still follows the same formula of 8 master robots gone rogue. Megaman is the only one to stop them and save the world from doctor Wily. You jump in. You fight 8 bosses. You go through Wily fortresses, fight extra bosses, go through boss rush and kick Wily's behind. Then the game ends. Credits roll. 

And that's that! It is new. It is exciting. It is highly accessible. I won't talk about the challenge mode or extra modes because those are not for me and it is very likely that I will not play them at all. But for those of you who looks for extra value out this game, I heard that you won't be disappointed.

For 30 USD or your regional equivalent, if you like what you read and you like what you see in the trailer, buy it. Can't really go wrong with this one!

45179000.review:
Let me start this off by saying that this game is amazing! It plays smooth as butter, looks great and even the little additions to the game like allowing you to shoot and use the Rush items at the same time are great. The gear system, though I had my doubts, is great and compliments the gameplay perfectly.
There is one thing that I had a problem with, and that was the difficulty. This game is way too easy, which isn't like a Megaman game at all. I've played every classic Megaman game (bar Megaman and Bass) and I can confidently say that this is the easiest one so far. Most of it comes from the Screw Catcher item which makes screws drop from nearly every enemy, and the fact that Doctor Light seemed to always be dropping the price of E-Tanks and lives, meaning that I always had a full stock. In addition, the Power Gear means that Robot Masters are pretty much a breeze if you have their weakness.
Overall, this game is great if you're just looking for some good platforming fun, or if you're new to the series; but if you're looking for that classic NES difficulty, you've come to the wrong place.

45175052.review:
Okay so let's get started with my first review ever, ahem

-Graphics: many people have a lot of strong connection with the 8-bit style to the point where some people argue megaman should only stick to 8-bit, replaying all classic games back to back in one week and a half i had a gist on why people think this......for one it's more distinct, another reason is because it feels extremely smooth to play with those controls (may be another reason why many don't like 8 or 7) and also because the sprites are small enough so they take a small amount of the screen, making it possible to have more complex platforming and enemy placement (reason why people don't enjoy 7 much, sprites are too big) But in megaman 11 most issues are fixed, it has a distinct look, framerate is smooth as butter and character models are small enough to have a lot of complex platforming and enemy placement on-screen......i want more games to look like this, this is a really good start

-Level design: HOT DANG so much variety i want to spoil none of it but rest assured it is fair, balanced and i have witnessed 0 cheap deaths whatsoever, stellar level design.

-Controls: the best they have EVER been, smooth as butter, the speed is JUST right, animations are smooth and every death, damage or bad positioning was my fault entirely, flawless.

-Innovations: double gear system where power gear lets players have more damage, more reach and so on on their attacks and speed gear where it is a newcommer's dream, taking their time to clear levels as calmly as possible and also making things slow enough to analyze the level design and boss patterns, controls where the weapons can be switched using the right control stick on the controller and having rush in 2 dedicated buttons and ALSO having the double gear on your buttons......quite frankly.....other than using the subtanks, you can pretty much finish the entire game without EVER pausing the game, i LOVE IT
-Difficulty: making it easier so anyone, and i mean ANYONE can play it, finally able to make megaman games for the more casual audience, good job.

Conclusion:

I love the megaman games a lot.....like.....a LOT (favorites being megaman 6, 8, 10, and 9 in no particular order).
And quite honestly i was a bit scared of this game and how i would take it being too used to the graphical style, the camera positioning, enemies, bosses, weapons, music and especially level design.
Then i played it and.....good GOD this has to be up there with the greats, WHAT A DAMN WAY to revive a franchise :D

It's GOOD to have ya back megaman :D

45167309.review:
First impressions are mostly positive and this definitely feels like a MegaMan game.

My main gripe at this early stage is with the controls.  On classic MegaMan games I could jump and use my regular shot to hit anything every time.  The timing seems just a hair off with the old arm cannon especially during the jump animation.  I've been able to deal with it, but it doesn't feel 100% on the mark.

One other small thing that doesn't feel right is the animation and stun that goes on after being hit.  You get knocked back an amount that I would consider to be the width of a 'block' in this game.  This would be similar to a single block graphic in the original that was repeated to create the level.  I feel that after this slight immediate knockback I am more frozen in place and for slightly longer than usual.  This creates an unfamiliar feeling compared to the classics and it causes some deaths that the old series in a similar situation would not create especially when converyor belts are involved.

Also, as others have stated the music I have encountered so far isn't of the caliber of MegaMan 1-3 (my golden video game years), but it isn't bad by any means.

The game is indeed hard and my instinct as a classic MegaMan gamer is to not use the gear system to 'nerf' my way through it, but I am definitely being tested for not doing so.  Just on BlockMan's stage alone the miniboss which I just got to a second time is tough to predict soon enough to get out of the way without using the Speed Gear especially the second time around when the game throws a conveyor belt into the fight which seems like a cheap shot in my opinion.

Would I recommend it this early on?  I think so.  But I do wish the gameplay were tweaked a bit with the old games in mind as noted above.  I'll get used to it, but it is so close to what it needs to be it makes me want even more for it to get past that 98% mark and to feel exactly like the old games with a fresh coat of paint on it.

Will update as I go along ....

45155475.review:
[h1]Not perfect, but okay even so[/h1]
I'll keep this bit short: Mega Man 11 has some flaws, but it is a mostly good game. If you like Mega Man, or Shovel Knight, or A.R.E.S. or any other good platformer then this is a game you need to play. If you are still sceptical, grab it on sale, but its worth full price i.m.o..

[h1]Slightly more detailed[/h1]
I love the original Mega Man series. I love the X series, the Zero series, the Legends series and so on. I've been a fan since we got 2 on the NES back in 1990. You may think me a fan boy, but the truth is I'm especially critical of any additions to my fav platforming series. Mega Man 11's announcement therefore filled me with both hope and dread, would it hearken back to what made the series great? Would it simply be another cashgrab after the appallingly poor X collections? The answer is a bit more grey than a simple yes or no. But personally, I think its worth it on weighing pros and cons. Lets get into the details.

[b]The Good[/b]
11 is a new game under a new team, with an interesting new gimmick in the form of the dual gear system. The robot masters are interesting and more challenging than average since they too use gear systems. 

Many of the stages are beautifully designed, despite my reservations about the 3D form of the game. I especially love the designs in Torchman, Blockman, Blastman and Bounceman's stages. Most stages offer a good, interesting challenge as well, with unique mechanics. 

The weapon designs are good too, for the most part. That's one of the innovations in the game as well, each weapon alters the look of Mega Man more than in previous games, though Blastman's weapon turns you into Axl from MMX7-8-CM.

[b]The Meh[/b]
The music. Its not bad, but... unlike previous entries, its damn immemorable. No standout themes, bar maybe Fuse Man's, all fairly muted too and some  a bit... reminiscent of earlier themes. Some stages are also underwhelming in design. There's challenges too, but... not particularly impressive ones.

[b]The Bad[/b]
Frankly, there's some less than optimal level design here and there. Acidman, Impactman, Tundraman and the Wily stages have segments that troll players. Such as instant-death spikes in a forced movement area, a gruelling trek before a mid-boss and a slippery segment with blizzard storm to name a few. Yes, you can try, try and try anew and there are items to help you, but these segments and others feel less natural than hazards or challenging areas in previous games. 

The voice-acting is to put it mildly quite bad on the English side, ranging from reading aloud while bored to being on crack like Bounceman. Seriously, I'd rather turn them off tbh.

Then there's the Wily stages. All two actual stages and two more walk to the boss ones. Frankly, they are underwhelming in extremis. The first one is the most challenging, but not in a good way. You need to use your gear gimmick a lot, with upgrades just to pass some trolling segments. And then the MK3 Yellow Devil is the boss. IT ISN'T FUN HERE! You need to use your speed gear to avoid his segment-rush and miniversion-rush (he has speed gear too) and then you just HAVE 1-2 seconds to hit his eye before the damn thing goes blue AGAIN and trolls you for having better speed gears.

Frankly, the second boss in the Wily stages is a pushover if you have a W-tank, as are the Wily Machine and capsule-esque. They really dropped the ball here as Wily stages should be a fun challenge with interesting bosses well before the boss rush.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Mega Man 11 is a fun game despite its flaws. The new team does give hope for the series' future, but I do hope they address the issues mentioned in this review.

45154057.review:
I didn't know I needed this game until I played it.

The story was actually pretty good and I enjoyed the voice acting of every character, even when they were making terrible puns.

Most of the base mechanics and controls are intact from the classics, but there were some differences. Some examples include Mega Man getting the knockback from damage right away instead of being gradually pushed back for the duration of the stun, or how Mega Man's hitbox is a bit larger, so you can lean further off ledges, but as a result you'll also bump your head on low ceilings easier too.

I didn't like the Double Gear system at first, but as I played the game and got more used to it, I actually started to really like it. There were some moments where tapping into a gear's power at the right time saved me from certain doom.

Although I find the soundtrack really good in this game, I still don't feel like some of the tracks give that Mega Man "vibe". I honestly can't say if it's just nostalgia speaking, however.

EDIT: Totally forgot to mention that the game's Extra Modes menu has a bunch of challenges that you can do once you're done with the main game, which is cool.

I definitely recommend this game to anyone who's into Mega Man. I also recommend it to anyone who hasn't really followed or played the series, but might be interested.

45153505.review:
The game's a little short, but I found it throughly enjoyable. I had no issues with the gameplay experince. Controls are tighter than my ass. The game's engine finds a way to make the controls as close to their classic counterpart as possible; yet has many modren tweaks that make some stages play better than they ever have before with similar concepts. 

THE GOOD: 
-Tundraman's stage is my #1 favorite, I love it! You go fast, and shoot stuff, wonderful!
-Rush Coil and Jet being on the top and far right button of your joypad makes perfect sense, and feels great.
-Right-Stick to change weapons on the fly, and click in the right stick to switch back to the buster is a clutch/time saver.
-Sliding feels a bit stiff when constantly dashing, however! Being able to now slide back and forth, while keeping your sliding height feels awesome, and helps out a lot with dodging. 
-Gear System, I found myself loving the speed gear (although not using it too awful much, it makes quick work of mid-bosses and some platforming areas.)
-The graphics are great, and I think they'll age well over time. Game comes in japanese and english, a great perk if you're bilingual, or find megaman's english voice to be to manly. (sorry Ben.)
-My rig is old, like REALLY old. So I found it some-what suprising that I could run the game with all the (few) settings they allow, and had v-sync on without any frame drops. I'd recommend keeping vsync on to be honest; game can get fast at times and if the screen were to tear, I think it might take away from the exp.


Neutral (eh): 
-Main game's pretty short, but solid, and well crafted.
-Music, nothing outstanding (apart from the stage select theme imo) But nothing bad, it's all is fitting to the stage/boss.
-No Protoman or Bass in this title. Maybe they'll be added at a later date, or in the next game. 
-English V/O(Voice over) Isn't great. The acting is totally fine, but the inflection sounds wrong. Stick with included Japanese Voice. 
-Rush Jet is kinda useless. I pray for the day they go back to Megaman 3's style of rushjet, but then I guess it'd be too strong.
-Rush Coil and Jet use the same energy bar; not a huge deal, but something to consider while playing. 

Cons: 
-Bounceman stage is annoying, but it's not a deal breaker at all. (Think somewhere between Springman from Megaman7 and Clownman from Megaman 8) 

Keep up the good work!!

45153031.review:
The majority of megaman games (except 7 which was 16 bit and 8 which was 32 bit) were 8 bit affairs.  This game is 2.5D with stylized 3D models and I actually like it a lot. It's about time this franchise modernized. 

Like most of the Megaman series this is a difficult platformer. However, unlike the rest of the series it has a lot of mechanics that make the platforming pretty fun. The Gear system really compliments Megamans jump and shoot gameplay and all of the levels and the bosses seem to be designed to compliment it. 

If you are not used to playing Megaman games or old school platformers Capcom has thankfully added lower difficulty settings which is pretty neat. In addition if you keep losing you can also go back to the in game shop and power Megaman up which in a way lets "grind" out an easy difficulty. 

I thought the music was pretty good though at times the synthesized sounds get repetitive. It's not Megaman 2 or 3 music good but, its fine and has few catchy tunes.

Only thing I don't really like about the game is the lack of extras after you beat it. No extra characters (Roll, Protoman, and Bass) and only the challenge mode for replay value. 

I got it for about $23 discount deal I think that is the right price for this game. If  you see any deals for this game under $25 (it will probably be between $20-$10 this summer) I think that is really good price for this game.

45151698.review:
Pros: 
+ The game generally FEELS good to play. As you play it more, you get better at using the new tools like the gear system to your advantage. 
+ The gear system and special weapons feel FUN to use. These weapons are a useful bunch in comparison to other classic series entries.
+ UI and Character Design is very clean. The Robot Master designs are some of the best in the series, and the fights are very fun.
+ The story cutscenes are better overall compared to other Mega Man games, which should be applauded. Most of the voice acting is also pretty good!
+ Challenge Mode and Time Trials add a lot for experienced players to play the levels in new ways.

Cons:
- Some levels (Block Man, Impact Man, Wily 1) are just too long or needlessly frustrating, especially for newcomers. The scarcity of checkpoints on "Normal" difficulty is a little ridiculous. You can add checkpoints and take less damage / no instant-deaths, but the level layouts are the same on all difficulties, so it doesn't really help new players adjust very well.
- The end-game isn't very satisfying as there are only 2 real WIly Stages and then 3 and 4 are just boss fights. Maybe this was because the main levels are longer than usual, they thought we wanted less of them? In any case, it feels less satisying to complete because of this.
- The entirety of Wily 1 including the boss. This level is a mess of half-finished ideas and enemy spam. Also, returning boss fight from hell that no one likes.
- The knockback is really frustrating because it added extra time where the player cannot act and this feels TERRIBLE. Getting hit feels really frustrating at ANY point in this game.


Overall, my annoyances are very minor and the positives outweight the negatives. This Mega Man game has slid up the ranks in my favorites and lands squarely in my top 5, as it does enough new things and has some quality boss fights and weapons to make up for the greivances. It's not perfect, especially by a veteran's standards, but it's pretty great! 8/10,  definitely worth the price of admission.

45146183.review:
It's hard to know how to feel about Mega Man 11 at times.

THe visuals and controls are very good, and except for the music being a little weak, it initally seems like a fine return to form. I played using the Switch Pro Controller and it worked flawlessly. 

However, the difficulty is all over the place, which was my largest complaint. Sure, you have the various actual difficulty settings, but I'm just talking about Normal mode. If you start running through the stages like you would in the NES era, you're going to get stomped and trolled hard by the stages.

You quickly realize that the way to beat the game and make it feel like classic Mega Man is to get bolts and buy upgrade items, including lives and tanks. However, it's so incredibly easy to grind for bolts  that you can easily destroy any trace of difficulty that the game has, as many of the upgrades are overpowered. Sure, it can be fun to get that RPG level-up sensation, but you don't want to get bored. And Mega Man puts too much of that responsibility in the hands of the player isntead of designing the game to have balance.

Upgrades are not, some of the stages simply have too many spikes  and frustrating mechanics (don't get my started on Bounce Man's stage), as well as sometimes being too long. When you die and get sent back, sometimes it's a long, long way and it's simply discouraging rather than being a slight annoyance like back in the NES days. 

On the other hand, the special weapons this time around are a blast, and the game's signature double gear system adds much needed variety, if not further muddying the waters of difficulty. You can use the trigger buttons to either slow down the action or boost/change your special abilites to a stronger version. The abilites feel more useful than usual, and experimenting with them is fun. 

You have access to both English and Japanese voice acting, with Japanese being the better option in my opinion. The story is simple, but gives some extra depth to the Wily and Light relationship, and even makes Wily feel like more of a sympathetic character. But don't worry, it's not too text heavy or over-complicated. 

I expect I might enjoy this game more on a replay than on my initial run, now that I have a better feel for the upgrades and how they affect gameplay. And replay value is high, for certain. 

You probably already know whether you're going to buy this, but I'll just say that I think the game is worth it, but really could have used some more fine tuning before release.

45145958.review:
This is the one Mega Man fans have been waiting for.

[b] What You’re in For	[/b]

[list]
    [*]Fully-customizable controls.

    [*]4 difficulties catering to everyone from newbie to the hardest of the hardcore.

    [*]New Double Gear system has allowed the designers to create much more challenging and interesting levels overall where players can choose to take the purist approach or make use of the slow-mo and buster power-ups it grants to fine-tune the difficulty on the fly.

    [*]Each level is thematically distinct with its own compelling twist on the Mega Man formula.

    [*]Boss battles are more dynamic than ever, each with unique phases that dramatically alter the flow of the fight.

    [*]Particle effects like hit sparks and explosions have been rendered in a cartoon-like, hand-drawn style, which really helps to sell the moment-to-moment action

    [*]Top-notch animation really breathes life into the cast. The attention to detail adds such character that I couldn’t help but fall in love.

    [*]Composer Marika Suzuki, known for her work both with the Megaman and Monster Hunter franchises among others, has contributed a lively and energetic sountrack that fits perfectly.

    [*]Extras include a long list of unlockable challenge modes, Leaderboards, and a gallery featuring the full cast of characters and enemies with additional lore for those who couldn’t get enough of the story. Unfortunately, the gallery only displays 3D models; I haven’t encountered a single piece of concept art thus far.
[/list]

From gameplay to presentation to replayability, this platformer has it all.

45131391.review:
[b]Oh great... another pointless Mega Man entry.

Do I even need to write a review for it? Jesus H. Christ...[/b]

[h1]Mehga Mehn[/h1]

Yeah header says it all... the ELEVENTH FUCKING ENTRY to a basically dead franchise / series that seems to never want to WRAP IT UP B!, WRAP UP THAT GAVEL B! and tie the two best entries in the franchise together... Not sure when Crapcom is going to tie the plot lines from Mega Man to Mega Man X but it won't be in my lifetime that's for certain.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]

Yeah it's Mega Man... now with extra frames of animation even worse than the likes of Mega Man 8, the knock back is unreal in this game as well, you can buy a power up in the shop that reduces the knock back by 50% but that only brings it back down to standard Mega Man levels of knock back... so they purposefully make bumping in to any enemies a death sentance if you're near the edge of a pit until you buy this power up.

So there's this "new" Double Gear System, how does it work? Well it's simple... you hit the RB on your controller to slow down time, and again, there's a power up that enhances this broken ability so you move at normal speed during the slow down, otherwise you move only about 20% faster than most enemies initially. 

When you hit the LB Mega Man goes in to a power fueled rage and does double damage with his Mega Buster, can fire a red energy shot or an ultimate shot that pretty much decimates anything it touches but over heats you, I dunno I barely ever used it. Slowing down time is a lot more beneficial to you over all, especially after the first boss you kill, right after Googling the boss weakness order that is...

You only have a finite amount of time in each of these modes, you have a bar, it fills red, when you shut off the over clocking it will reduce the bar but if you stay in overclock mode you'll over heat. If the bar fills completely it will put you in a weakened state... So basically what I'm saying is, don't let the bar fill, like ever. Firing off Mega Mans Ultimate shot will instantly put you in that weakened state as well but it pretty much kills any normal enemy / mini boss in a single hit and will take off about 30% of a bosses life bar... again, not sure, never really used it much... no need.

The game difficulty is spiked against you on Superhero mode, like it's pretty tough. It's about Mega Man 9 tough, let's just put it that way. Normal mode is a good place to be generally, it's difficulty is around Mega Man 4 or 5... fairly balanced... anything lower and you're going in to Mega Man 2 and 3 territory for difficulty... really easy.

Auto is back, so the shop is back, bolts are back, so you know, go hack your bolts with cheat engine and start buying up the shop... you can hold 9 E tanks, 9 W tanks and 1 M tank... this is literally overkill, the game isn't this hard. Beat can rescue you from pits, Eddie can deliver a random crap item and you can get spike guards if you die 5 times to spikes.

On Superhero mode, you'll take tons of damage from normal enemies so be careful. Mega Man 4's Mega Buster is back again, which means if you're charging a shot and get hit... yup, you guessed it... gotta charge that shot again.

The Boss weapons are actually really well done though, I will give this game some credit for that, they are all generally useful at one point or another. The only weapon I found rather pointless was the block dropper for the most part, it's rather situational... same with Blast Man's weapon... it's meh. Other than that, at least 6 of 8 weapons have great utility.

Also, no Protoman, no Bass... why? I have a good idea. They seemed to be utilizing those extra characters well but I guess they wanted to go back to basics and make this strictly a Mega Man only title... Which I'm fine with honestly because I was starting to get the impression that Mega Man is a total basic bitch. Bass is far superior to play with and a lot more fun and that was kind of ruining it for me... this is Mega Man, not Bass Man... you want that shit go play Mega Maker.

[h1]Plot[/h1]

Nothing new... literally. Wily drudges up an old grudge that he just seemingly forgot about this entire time. Wily has a nightmare about this old grudge and wakes up wanting to make life miserable for Dr. Light.... surprise, surprise.

Again Mega Man 1 style, Wily kidnaps Dr. Lights Robots and reprograms them with his overclocking system he developed so as to finally stop Mega Man... but of course, you can't stop Mega Man so Dr. Light takes a chance, AGAIN, and installs Wily's experimental overclock system in to Mega Man. Dr. Light trusts that Mega Man will do the right thing with his new found abilities...AGAIN, and go out and put an end to Dr. Wily's madness....AGAIN...zZzzzzZZZzzzzZzzzzzzzzzzzz....

[h1]Music[/h1]

Non-existant... literally. Can't even remember a single track from this game, and I beat it about 3 times in less than 6 hours... not even sure if there was music really, a complete shame really. Mega Man is known for it's rockin' soundtracks and somewhere in there, they just forgot to include one in this game... not kidding, I can't remember a single song, it just felt like background noise... nothing memorable.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]

Shameless cash grab, nothing more, we fell for it. They wanted to stick it to Inafune for betraying them with Mighty No. 9... well I can honestly say, nothing will ever replace Mega Man, which is something Inafune should have realized... Mega Man 11 is far superior to Mno.9 but it's still just a mediocre title at best.

Hot garbage really... the art design was cool, I enjoyed the weapons and creativity they put forth in designing said weapons but the rest was just meh. The slow down gimmick was just that, a total gimmick, I didn't enjoy that double gear / overclock system one bit, felt tacked on and the game could have been fine without it.

Rush has his own hot keys now which makes for some flashy jump maneuvers for speed running the game, Coil and Jet though... they decided to keep it basic this time around... Rush Marine was still the best 3rd utility Rush could have ever had and I would like to see its return, but that would mean they'd have to make another MM game and I think this game just tapped me out completely... I'm just over Mega Man.

6.5 / 10... it's alright. There are much better MM games out there that make you feel better about playing them... This game is just a souless, shameless entry to get back at Keiji Inafune and honestly, if Keiji was involved, it probably wouldn't have been much better because that guy's ideas are out to fucking lunch.

MM is dead... just deal with it. 

Buy it on sale... don't pay full.

I never want to see another MM game as long as I live... not unless they intend to do something drastic like introduce Zero in to it...

45125586.review:
The Pros: A solid return to the Mega Man formula. Levels feel much longer compared to earlier entries. The stages are enjoyable, and the challenge is tough but fair. The new double gear system is a nice edition to the formula without feeling too foreign to the traditional gameplay: granting the player either enhanced power or to slow down time for better mobility.  This system is heavily encouraged through gameplay, which may make Mega Man purests a little uneasy, but it is not impossible to play without.
 You have access to an item shop inbetween levels where you can buy consumable items (extra lives, energy tanks, weapon refills etc.) and parts, which act as permanent upgrades. These upgrades help alleviate some minor stresses of playing such as not having to hold the button to charge your shots, or having weapon ammo refill all your weapons instead of just one. The parts are a nice reward without taking away from the game's overall challenge.
 Special bonus features such as gallery mode and additional challenges with leaderboards are there for those looking for more which is a nice bonus.

The Cons: The music is a little uninspired, which is disappointing considering the history of great music in the Mega Man series. If you have access to the arranged soundtrack DLC, I highly recomend replacing the standard soundtrack with the special instrumental track, as those are much nicer to listen too. The art style may be a matter of preferance to some players, as the colors are not quite as bold as the days of sprite-art.

Overall, it's a welcome revival of the Mega Man series, and a refreshingly tough one at that.

¡El rey ha vuelto!

¿Te gustan los juegos de Mega Man clásicos? ¡Éste es tu juego! ¿Quieres adentrarte en la saga pero temes que la dificultad pueda contigo? ¡No te preocupes! Hay varios niveles de dificultad para que juegues a tu estilo. ¿Quieres que la dificultad se adapte a tus necesidades? ¡Sin problemas! A lo largo del juego se irán desbloqueando mejoras según como juegues que podrás comprar con los tornillos (la moneda del juego).

¿Jugabilidad clásica? Sí. ¿Música acorde? ¡También! ¿Historia? Bueno, la de siempre, pero podemos ver al doctor Willy en pijama.

¿Y qué es éso del sistema Double Gear (mal traducido a Doble Mega)? Pues una nueva mecánica jugable, opcional y de uso limitado, los jefes también lo tienen, así que saber gestionarlo es importante. Podemos aumentar la potencia de las armas (lo usarás muy poco con el Mega Buster) o reducir la velocidad (modo cámara lento, ¿quién ha dicho tiempo bala?).

¿Merece la pena el juego? ¡Sin lugar a dudas! Tanto si eres un fan de la saga como alguien que quiere empezar con buen pie, deberías jugarlo.

¿Por qué no sale Zero en este juego? Porque es el Mega Man clásico, no es Mega Man X, pero CAPCOM ya ha dicho que si este juego vendía bien, se plantearían hacer un Mega Man X9 (saben chantajear al público).

¿El juego es rejugable? Pues sí, incluye desafíos y varios modos de dificultad, así que podrás estar entretenido para rato.

45121960.review:
As a diehard MM fan, I was cautiously optimistic about MM11. I can now say with relief that Capcom absolutely nailed it. I love the gameplay and the aesthetics of MM11. The controls are solid, the stages are unique, and the bosses are show stealers.

Gone is MM8-10's idiotic habit of removing fundamental mechanics for no good reason. You have the full and iconic Mega Man arsenal at your disposal. E-Tanks, Rush Coil, Rush Jet, sliding, charge shots, etc... These are joined by the largest shop in the series, with plenty of  old and new items. The game is properly designed around a fully powered Mega Man so that none of these abilities and goodies feel over-powered or under-utilized.

Stages are tough, but feature a fair learning curve. Some tend to be a touch on the long side. The only complaint I have so far is that the length can make backtracking after dying to a mid-boss or boss frustrating. Plenty of bolts for E-Tanks and 1-ups helps to mitigate that problem, thankfully. The stages themselves are reasonably attractive. What really stands out are the wonderful background details. Scenes such as Metools sitting around a bonfire or Block Man's adorable hieroglyphics give a great deal of charm to the stages.  

The boss fights are some of the more imaginitive in the series. They are very much on the difficult side, but none of them feel like you won't be able to master them with practice. Added to that, each boss is given a fully-formed personality to shape their fights and make each one memorable. (<3 Tundra Man.)

The mechanics are solid, and the new double gear system is a worthy addition. It's simple, useful, and unobtrusive. You'll never feel annoyed at having to use it, and learning to complete harder sections without it is quite satisfying. Two small control problems did arise. First, Mega Man's ladder climbing speed is glacial. It feels slower than Mega Man 1&2's painfully slow ladder climbing, and that is quite an accomplishment. Also Mega Man seems to bonk his head occasionally trying to jump through narrow gaps. This is particularly a problem with Torch Man's stage. These are minor gripes on what is otherwise a game that matches or surpasses the earlier games' controls. 

In short-- This is the game I've been waiting for. After twenty years of handheld spin-offs, 8 bit MM2 clones, and dubious Kickstarters, Classic Mega Man has returned triumphantly.

45116334.review:
After 8 years later we finall have another classic megaman game. And man it doesn't dissapoint. 

Presentation:

The graphics are colorful and nice. I am not one of those people who hate the idea of this game being 8 bit or modern graphics. To me the 8 bit sprties will always look great and age better in the end but that being said this game looks really good. They also took advantage of the higher quality graphics by making stages have a lot of unique nods. I love Blast man's stage for example thanks to all those billboards in the background.

The music is nice but I need to give it a few more listen to it. With megaman 9 and 10  (and all the other megaman games except 5 maybe)  every track stuck to my head in my first playthrough but not so much with this one. It also has to dow ith how loud everything can be so I will play around with configurations and do a second run (well more like 50 more runs , I am a big megaman nut)

The voice acting I really love. All of the voices are fitting especially Willy's . Infact this is my fav voice for him. I especially love how the actor gets into his lines during the final battle. It actually kinda made me emotional and feel bad for Willy.

The stages:

They are all fun imo. Everyone mentions how anoying Bounce Man's stage is but I don't know I never had any problems. I just hold the jump button and no directional movement and boom I am done. Now the stages do have a few "gotcha" moments which annoyed me. I mean 9 and 10 were pretty good with this but this game not so much. Its only a problem during your first playthrough though and if you are like me only a few moments will get you.

My fav stage is probably Tundra Man's stage so far. I love how fast it can be. Reminds me of Commando Man's stage from megaman 10 which is always a good thing.


The weapons:
A lot of people usually say that the weapons in megaman games are not that good but I HIGHLY disagree with that. 1 , 2 ,4 ,7 , 9 and 10 are filled with amazing weapons (especially 4 and 9 ). And honestly this game has some great weapons. There are a lot of moments during stages where the weapons are super useful. It might be an enemy that is hard to reach or the weapon might just destroy a mini boss combined with the power gear. If I had to rank the weapons in this game , well , I would put them on par with the ones in 4 but not quite as 9. To be fair though the weapons in 9 are just godly. It might be the only game where the effs of the weapons can be combined too now that I think about it.


The gear system:
Our new toy for this game and how do I feel about it? Well most people say that the speed gear is good but the power gear is useless but honestly I am the opposite. I LOVE the power gear. I always combine it with certain weapons and it just DESTROYS the minibosses when combined with the right weapon. The speed gear is good for dodgin certain boss attacks but I never felt like I had to use it to dodge an attack which I like. My fav thing about this system is that it is not MANDATORY. A lot of people say that there should have been more sections in stages to make these things useful but honestly I prefer it this way. Its all about your creativity to make them useful. The potential for this thing is pretty great and I can't wait to try it out more in my future runs. 

Ironic considering how I was not a fan of this sytem from the beginning but now I love it.

The charge and slide:
.....I never liked these. Why? Well not so much the slide but the charge shot means one thing. The devs want to make this thing feel useful so they make a lot of the enemies take more hits than they need to and the bosses have more eye frames. Meaning you NEED to use it if you wanna have a good time during bosses. 9 and 10 fixed this problem by making the eye frames shorter meaning a normal buster shot was enough to beat a boss with ease AND if you were playing as Protoman you had the CHOICE the OPTION to use it. It was never needed to have a good time. That beeing said there is an auto-charge upgrade in this game meaning I can just equip that during boss fights and not have to worry about holding my thumb on that cursed fire button.

And the slide killed me more than it helped me.


Few things in general:
This game kinda does away with a lot of the things that 9 and 10 perfected. The slide is kinda like megaman 8 slide which is bad, the latter climbing speed is slow just like in 1 and 2 and the movement is not as fluent as it was in 9 and 10 (still good but not as good). Also the knockback , this is the only megaman game where it bothers me. Sure there is an item that you can buy but whats the point. Just give me the normal knockback from 9 and 10. Also where are Proto man and Bass? Those 2 were great in 9 and 10 and increased replayability. 

So overall my opinion on this game is that it is great. It is probably my 3rd fav in the series (9 and 10 taking the first 2 spots). This is a great game and I can't wait to replay it. (which I am probably doing right now)
 I will say that while yes this game has better graphics it feels kinda empty compared to 9 and 10.
