45113342.review:
Mega Man 11. Wow. Just saying the name blows my mind. Where do I start with this masterpiece?

The best way to sum this game up is "damn".
Damn this game is pretty
Damn this game is fun
Damn this game is addictive
Damn this game is a throwback
Damn this game was worth the wait
Damn this game is well-made
Damn this game is slick
Just.... Damn.

Now there are flaws of course, I mean really there is no such thing as a truly flawless game. Although these flaws are few and far between.
For starters, the main controversy is that you don't get to jump through the door to the boss as a transition (I personally don't care about this but I have to add it as a "flaw" because I might get hunted down if I don't). The game has a pretty dumb plot but then again it is the 11th installment in the core series so I can let it pass. Each stage works the same way as the original 6 as well as 9 and 10: pick a stage and beat it, BUT THERE'S A CATCH!
You  now don't have to just jump and shoot to progress through the level. There are new mechanics like the Slow-Down powerup and of course the Boost powerup. Also the Rush Coil has its own button which is amazing. I found myself using the Slow-Down and Boost barely ever yet I used the Rush Coil A LOT to get to hard to reach places or even just for convenience. The 2 new game mechanics can be combined although it drains your power meter in seconds so it's pretty much not worth doing unless you got a really good reason to.

There are new parts in the puzzle section of each stage, keeping you on your toes.
The voice acting is decent, although when you go to Dr. Light's Lab for items and whatnot, Roll and Dr. Light call you Mega and honestly I find that uncomfourting since no one calls him Mega. Really gives me some Jack Torrance-style cabin fever hahaha.

The game is the length of an average Mega Man game but constantly throws new things at you and it is really fantastic for doing that. During every Game Over screen or completion of a stage, you have the ability to save your progress which is also really fantastic. The game is extremely addictive already but with the save slots added it makes it way more fun to progress and then play again once you beat it. It feels like a true Mega Man game, one that goes back to the style of the old games but also keeps things fresh and original.

The robot masters you face now are Block Man, Fuse Man, Blast Man, Torch Man, Impact Man, Bounce Man, Tundra Man and Acid Man respectively.
Acid Man is the stage I started out with on my first playthrough and it is honestly one of the most fun stages in the whole game as well as a great music loop to accompany it.
I don't want to spoil much about the stages but yea they're really good.

Overall, Mega Man 11 is an excellent sequel. Too bad I can't say the same for Final Fantasy 11, but that's a story for another day.

45111366.review:
Absolutely the Mega Man game we needed.  

It's a true blue Mega Man with some great graphical polish, decent voice acting for a Mega Man (shout out to Mega Man 8), and best of all, it's got a system that appeals to both old time fans and newcomers to the series - the Gear System.  

The gear system has a lot of great applications, but at its core, its a temporary 'easy button'.  You get the option to rapid fire powerful semi-charged buster shots or you can speed up (meaning slow time) for a brief period.  This system can be used to clear difficult playforming sections or blast through obstacles quicly if you're in a tricky spot.  However, a proficient use of the gear system opens up a LOT of potential for speed runs.  But the gear system is ENTIRELY OPTIONAL.  Don't worry, my fellow retro Rock Man Ride-or-Die's, you can still beat the game with only the buster ;)

45109902.review:
A great return to form for the blue bomber with a lot of action, challenging platforming and great bosses.

Pros:
- A great return of many mega man elements we all know: 8 robot masters that can be picked in any order, bosses who are weak to certain weapons and 4 difficult wily stages to beat.
- A shop system that allows you to use bolts to buy e tanks and beat whistles (like in mega man 9 and 10) but also allows you to buy upgrades for mega man (like in mega man 8) which range from ice resistant boots, lower knockback and more double gear time.
- A great introduction with the double gear system that allows mega man to either slow down time with the speed gear or power up his weapons with the power gear, making a major change that the series hasn’t really seen since mega man 4. 
- Some of the best boss battles in the series, even if you use their weaknesses.
- Fantastically designed levels with action packed moments 
- Runs at a near consistent 60 FPS.
Cons:
- The music is quite lacklustre in comparison to some other games in the series. A few good tracks but overall underwhelming.
- Some bugs that range from minor (occasional stutters, audio glitches once in a while) to major (Game freezing on starting up screen, 30fps lock [didn’t happen to me but happened to others]).
- Some unfair level design that harkens back to some of the earlier NES mega man titles.

Overall, a really really good platformer game and a great return to form. Definitely recommended.

45109600.review: It sucks that Mega Man's been inactive for over 8 years, but I gotta say it was well worth it for the thrill I got from Mega Man 11.  This game takes everything about the Mega Man series and quite literally cranks it up to 11!  The story is essentially the classic "stop Dr. Wily and his evil robots" plotline and is as lighthearted as ever, but it also has a small hint of seriousness as the game explores some new lore about how Drs. Light and Wily split up over the Double Gear System.  Speaking of, the Double Gear System - the game's selling point - is a fun, unique, and interesting new mechanic that adds a fresh twist to the already fresh and fluid gameplay Mega Man 11 has to offer.  The levels are well-designed and the boss battles are crazy fun!  And not to mention, Mega Man 11 has arguably the best lineup of Robot Masters and Special Weapons since Mega Man 9!  The visuals and music are top-notch too; the graphics and character models are beautiful, and the game's soundtrack is full of catchy tunes!  Final Verdict: 11/10, would play again multiple times.

45105335.review:
This game laughs at Mighty Number 9.
Without the Double Gear System, it's probably the hardest Mega Man game overall, given most of the game is designed for you to actually utilize it, and a lot of enemies are much faster/more intense to balance this all out. Not impossible, but you'll need to be on your toes the entire time to not get murderized.

I found myself using Speed Gear more often than Power Gear, unless you decide to use the Power Weapons. Then everything dies, the end.

Graphics look fine to me, I don't have any personal problems with the game's art style (only the one miniboss in Bounce Man's stage looks kinda weird, but besides that). 

The music is good, but I don't know if I quite like how they only really used one soundfont for the whole soundtrack, blending things in a bit. Fuse Man's stage and Wily stages do stand out a bit, but besides that, a lot of it is "just good."

Bosses are fun to try and destroy, and jesus: The weapons are probably the most powerful in the whole classic series. If you use them, you can really make mincemeat out of both stages and bosses. 

That being said, for an "AAA" title $30 is a pretty good deal, and an incredible deal if you can get it for $15 or $20. You'll get your jollies if you like Jump N' Shoot Man. You've probably already bought it if you like Mega Man, but if you haven't, give it a go. Give it a fair chance, and you'll like it. Much like every Mega Man game, you'll get kicked in the mega balls until you learn how things work and telegraph, and then it's smooth sailing.

My only potential gripe is that the stages can be a bit longer than the past games (or at least feel as if they are), so try and stock up on an extra E-Tank or few lives to not redo them, and then there's only two Wily Stages in reality. But they'll kick you in the pants, so good luck!

45103668.review:
[h1]Holy fuckoly, it's another MEGA MAN GAME![/h1]

Real quick before I start the review, I just want to say that I've been a long time megaman fan, since megaman 1. I've played lots and lots of megaman games and was so sad to hear that they weren't going to produce any more megaman games.

But then [b]WHAM[/b] they fucking hit me in the face with a suprise attack game that I didn't even see coming.

So how is it?

[h1]Graphics:[/h1]

[b]This game looks awesome![/b] The levels look really well done and have beautiful views, amazing parallaxing, and they still feel true to the old megaman style. I love it!

As for the fx, things such as the boss attack effects, mega buster charges, and explosions look [i]cool[/i]! It's both stylistic with a more 'realistic' look to it at the same time.

[h1]Music:[/h1]

The music is awesome! I really enjoy the soundtrack, it feels just as modern as the graphics. Toight!

[h1]Story:[/h1]

No spoilers here. I just want to say that the story mostly follows the same sort of format as earlier megaman classic games, which is a good thing! I enjoy the story itself, though, I feel like it really develops the characters of Dr. Light and Dr. Wily a lot, which makes them even more interesting!

[h1]Voice acting:[/h1]

They got this one right. Ooooh they did a good job on voice acting in this game! No childish megaman, no DOKTOR WAHWEE AND DE ENERGEE WESOURCES, no WHAAAAT AM I FIGHTTTINNNGG FORRRRR (Even though they were fuckin' golden). I enjoyed every voice in this, they really connect with how the characters look.

[h1]Gameplay:[/h1]

Okay, here's where Megaman 11 gets [i]really[/i] good. You've got your classic megaman moveset: Move left/right, jump, shoot, charge (2 levels normally, same as old school charging), and special weapons. However, this game introduces an amazing mechanic: The double gear system. Feel free to look at the spoiler if you want to know more about it instead of finding out yourself (It's really cool to find out how everything works and looks yourself!)

[spoiler]

So the double gear system gives you two main 'modes' you can swap between: [i]Speed gear[/i] and [b]Power gear[/b].
Each uses a shared energy gauge which does NOT work like special weapon energy. Instead, it's a seperate cooldown bar that slowly overheats as you use each gear, and slowly cools down when you're not using any gears.

Speed gear allows you to slow down time, which allows for easier dodging, platforming, spam shots, and really just breather time. It's a very nice mechanic that makes the game more accessable for players that find megaman to be too tough normally, or who just want a smoother experience with the game. I enjoy it a lot.

Power gear increases your damage output. Your uncharged/level 1 charge shots will be doubled (Meaning two shots for one button press), plus you will have TWO extra charge levels (One that charges up at a good speed after the normal max charge, and one that charges up for the whole duration of power gear (Meaning you'll have to spend your entire power gear time charging it up) for a massive blast that destroys enemies.), however the max charge level can be lost if you get hit during it, making it a high-risk, high-reward playstyle. 

Any special weapons used with power gear will be extra powerful, as if they were charged. You cannot charge special weapons.

Lastly, at roughly 4-5 health left you can press both gear buttons at once to [b]DOUBLE UP[/b], activating both gears until they're both overheated (You cannot cancel out of this process). Your max charge level will charge quicker in this state, meaning you can usually get 2 max charged shots before it runs out.

This is meant as a last resort attack, as once it is over you can only fire 1 buster shot at a time and cannot charge your shots until the overheated gear charge meter slowly goes back to 0%. VERY high-risk high-reward play, which is my kinda thing!

Also, while gears are overheated, they cannot be used again until they are fully cooled down.

Also also, bosses have access to the gear system as well :)
[/spoiler]

This game also uses the part system from megaman 8 (And I'm sure other megaman games), which I enjoy quite a bit. I didn't enjoy it as much as how megaman 8 did it, but it still is a very good system.

The bosses are very fun and feel a lot like megaman x bosses, I won't spoil much about them. Their personalities and voice acting is awesome, and they feel like well developed characters in my mind.

The powers themselves are also very fun to use, it still stays true to the old megaman format.

So, the main question:

[h1]Is it worth 30$?[/h1]

If you're a die-hard megaman fan, this is definitely the game for you. It is VERY fun for a megaman game and the new gear mechanic adds a lot of spice to the already fun gameplay. This game follows the old megaman format heavily, so you'll get a LOT of nostalgia from seeing some familiar faces!

If you're playing megaman for the first time, it can also be a lot of fun. This can be a great first megaman game, as the speed gear really lets you adjust the difficulty to how you see fit, while not being overpowered.

I payed 30$ for this game and I did not regret it one bit. I thoroughly enjoyed every last bit of this game and I hope you do as well if you're thinking of picking it up! Going in blind is awesome, I recommend it.

45102431.review:
Really stellar Mega Man game. 

The controls and flow of the game feels really, really good. The stages and bosses are generally speaking well designed and the Double Gear system feels more like optional training wheels rather than an absolute necessity, which is great for newcomers and casuals alike.

While Rock's runcycle is a bit iffy, the overall art direction is pleasing to the eyes and nothing feels out-of-place; It definitely is what I imagined a modern Mega Man game would look like, graphically. Soundtrack however is a bit forgettable, with only a very few tracks standing out, though the instrumental tracks improves nearly every stage theme, I found. Shame though that it seems to be pre-order exclusive only, at least as of this review's posting.

In conclusion, MM11 is a very good start for what I'm hoping to be a new Mega Man revival, and one that won't be over after just two games. You did good, Capcom. You did good.

45098156.review:
Good:
 + The best storyline in the series. (Although it doesn't focus much, not only it explained why Light and Wily are like oil and water, but also strengthen the connection between Classic and X series)
 + The best voice acting in the whole series. (Again, for obvious reason)
 + The best level design I've ever seen. (You guessed it, for obvious reason)
 + The best-looking Mega Man Classic game today. (although it's so obivous, I hate to see Mega Man 11 or later will be in 8-bit, which may hurt its presentation)
 + The control is as tight as it used to be.
 + This game isn't easy, but no cheap death and bullsh*t pixel perfect timing requirement.(look at YOU: Quick Man's stage, First-run Heat Man's stage, Boobeam Trap boss fight, etc.)
 + The weapons are obviously powerful and easily the best, but not as overpowered as the famous Metal Blade, which is a good thing because none of them break the game. They use for what they should be in the first place: covering the attack that Mega Buster can't normally reach.
 + Double Gear system is a welcome addition to the series and it's related to the storyline. No-Double-Gear-System playthrough is possible. Again, Double Gear doesn't break the game.
 + High replay value.
 + OMG, they added a new method to kill Mettaur (charge shot him will make him reveal his weakness)? So Mettaur is finally dethroned? F&&& YEAH!
 + Holy sh*t, you can stop during slide??? Am I f&&&ing dreaming???

Bad:
 - Rush Jet got nerfed ... again (cost 2 bars instead of 1 unlike previous games. Wait, Rush Jet is in MM8?)
 - System requirements (at minimum) demand higher than it should.
 - Keyboard doesn't have a complete control configuration. (I can't change the menu button?)
 - Extra Life, E-Tanks, and W-Tanks won't respawn after collected ... permanently.
 - There is no indicator of how to unlock all parts even though all conditions make sense (you still have to "buy" them after unlocked)
 - The soundtrack is good, but very forgettable. (isn't Mega Man well-known for amazing and memorable soundtrack?)
 - Dr.Light's Lab (A.K.A the shop) can tone down the difficulty, so ignore it forever if you want a maximum challenge.

If you're new to the series, this (or Mega Man 2) is your best starter kit. If you're looking for an old-school platformer challenge, it's worth $30. However, if you just want to play the game in 1 playthrough only, I recommend you to wait for the sale.

(Final words as a Mega Man fan) After all those years that Capcom thought Mega Man franchise was no longer relevant, and we all know it's their fault for releasing way, WAY too much Mega Man games in 2000s. I'm so glad that my old friend back after 8 years of "retirement", and THIS is the Mega Man Classic game that I've ALWAYS looked forward to. I'm grateful to see MM11's presentation step up with the modern era, not stay in 8-bit for the sake of nostalgia and low budget as possible. This showed how much effort Capcom dev team put into it. And now, the only thing I can do right now is wait and see if the game sell well or not because I really want to see the series continue.

Anyway, Welcome back, old friend! ;w\)

[spoiler]Update: I sense something similiar to Double Gear System, and they were already introduced before ... hmmm ... Hero Time and Sengoku boost from Sengoku Basara franchise?[/spoiler]

45096836.review:
Mega Man is my favorite franchise period, and the long-awaited return since Mega Man 10 in 2010 had me both excited and skeptical. I didn't know if Capcom could pull off a successful entry in the series after it's been so long. What if they lost touch? Would they take an entirely different style that crossed a line that shouldn't be? Well, I'm happy to report that the game has exceeded [i]almost[/i] every expectation of mine. I'll explain in brief what the game does and doesn't do right.

[h1]The Feel[/h1]

When I saw the 2.D style, I was immediately concerned of the possibility of the game lacking the tight, snappy, and satisfying physics of the games of old. In particular, I was worried about the game turning out feeling clunky and slow like Mega Man 8. Thankfully, this game feels very close to the 8-bit games, with some minor nuances and differences. If you are familiar with the Classic Mega Man games, you should feel right at home.

[h1]The Gears[/h1]

By now, you've likely seen the trailers, so you understand what the gears are. The Speed Gear is particularly very useful, adding a bullet-time mechanic that lets you platform and shoot more effectively while slowing the flow of time around you. On the other hand, the Power Gear is an incredibly awesome way to enhance your weapons almost in the vein of Mega Man X. You can use it to dump a hoard of bricks, a far-reaching air dash, and a literal screen nuke. They're great, once you get used to them. Best part? You can complete the entire game without touching them once. They are optional. If someone says otherwise, they simply have yet to stop relying on the gears to win. The mechanic is seemlessly incorporated into the core Mega Man experience, and I had a lot of fun with it.

[h1]The Stages[/h1]

I won't beat around the bush. The stages here in 11 are definitely the longest on average of the classic series. They feel about 25% longer than the ones in past games, but the good news is that despite this, they keep throwing new and interesting challenges at you that makes each stage memorable and fun. Just like in the past, the challenges are fair, but difficult, and you must keep a sharp eye out to learn how to bypass them safely. 

[h1]The Bosses[/h1]

In what probably benefits from the style shift the most, the bosses this time definitely have more life to them and their fights are executed in some of the best ways I've seen in the series. Each one not only sports an appealing design, but they all come with multiple phases utilizing the gears. Yet, if you're familiar with past Mega Man games, you should know what to expect for the most part. 

[h1]The Music[/h1]

Yeah, this is definitely the most controversial part of this game. The songs are definitely taking a more synthy EDM style here than in the past, but most of them are catchy and simple enough to remember. Ones I enjoy specifically being Fuse Man, Bounce Man, and Acid Man.

[h1]The Content[/h1]

Outside of the main game which is as replayable as past games in the series, depending on who you are, there are some challenge modes that are fun, but overall not that staggering. They're simple Time Attack, Score Attack, etc. type of modes with some neat ideas like Balloon Rush and Jump Saver. Fun, but only for a while. 

Also. this may change with DLC, but the lack of Endless Attack and any appearance of Proto Man and Bass whatsoever leaves me disappointed in that regard. Especially the latter. I hope to see them in future updates. 

[h1]Verdict[/h1]

A great Mega Man game, with possibly the best and most versatile set of Special Weapons yet. Hopefully this is a sign for the series to make a full comeback at last. X9 when?

45094014.review:
Mega Man has been one of my favorite video games series for as long as I can remember.  I had been eagerly waiting for Mega Man 11 since the moment I watched the original trailer.  As excited as I was, I still held some concerns.  It has been 8 years since Capcom’s long running series received a new entry.  I wondered how the game would be with a new graphical style.  After all, it wouldn’t be the first time they tried to depart from the classic NES style with mixed results.  I’m happy to say that Capcom did a great job with Mega Man 11.

Deep story lines were never the draw of this series and that doesn’t change here. To absolutely no one’s surprise Dr. Wily is at it again and it’s Mega Man’s job to thwart his schemes.  There is a bit of information revealed about Dr.Wily and Dr. Light’s past that is used to set up the new gear system mechanic.

There are two gears.  The speed gear allows the player to slow down time and the power gear increases Mega Man’s damage output.  When I first learned about it I was worried that the entire game would be geared around it and the use of gears would be required.  I played through on normal and can confirm that at no point is it mandatory.  That said, the gears are very powerful and will make the game easier for the player if utilized.

Beyond the gear system there have been a few quality of life upgrades.  Rush jet/coil now have dedicated buttons and weapons can be quickly swapped with the right analog stick.  There were a few times where I accidentally swapped weapons by tapping the analog stick.  It didn’t bother me much, but it’s worth mentioning that it’s possible to turn the feature off in the options menu.  Other changes include ditching the classic boss door transition motion freeze as well as health pick up freeze.  I would have liked to keep the boss door transition but it’s not a big enough issue to bother me much.

Aside from some minor changes it’s still Mega Man.  There are eight robot masters followed by Wily stages. I wasn’t hoping for anything more than that, though I must admit the Wily portion of the game felt shorter than usual.  In addition to the main game there are quite a few extra challenges, most of which feature leaderboards.  If you’re new to the series it’s probably a good place to start as Capcom has made the game especially accessible via the gear system, multiple difficulty options, and generous currency drops for the in game shop. But if you do start here I imagine it would be difficult to go back to some of the older games after playing this one. The game is what I hoped it would be and I’d recommend it to veterans of the series without hesitation.

45093828.review:
Summary: They got it right!

Mega Man 11 is a revival of the 30 (or 31 if you're from Japan) year old series, and it seriously seems like they listened to fan input along the way. Mega Man regains all of his core moves: running and jumping, but also sliding and charge shot. In addition, if you wish to use the gears, you absolutely can. They enhance your speed and your weapons, but overall they make the game easier. You can actually beat the full game buster only, and that's one of the areas in which they were clearly listening to the fans.

The controls are tight as ever, though bear in mind that using a wireless controller or analog stick will not effectively replicate the feel of the classic series in its prime. Thankfully, there is generic gamepad support, even though it uses Xbox button icons to represent said gamepad's buttons and can get confusing. Want to play on an SNES controller? No problem -- I finished the game doing so! You'll need a couple more buttons to use everything, however.

Of note, Mega Man's jump distance has been increased by around 25%, likely to facilitate the switch to widescreen. Aside from that, however, it'll feel more like playing Mega Man 4 or 5 than any other title.

The graphics are beautiful, though the perspectives used in cutscenes are a bit limited. Obviously core gameplay should lock it as is done, but cutscenes don't need to be beholden to these limitations. The audio is catchy as ever, though default settings really drown out its wonderful soundtrack. I'd recommend adjusting the voices and SFX down a bit before beginning.

If you're worried about replayability, challenges have you covered. The developers made good use of the fairly short roster of maps to design some clever, if not incredibly evil challenges. Getting gold on them will keep you busy for quite some time.

A few people have mentioned slowdown issues similar to those experienced in the Legacy Collections. Luckily, I didn't experience this, in spite of having slowdown in LC2 and XLC1. It seems to be fairly rare.

That aside, with the difficulty vets expect and the easier difficulty settings making it accessible to newcomers, this is a fantastic run-and-gun for anyone.
(also, I will throw my money at any Bass DLC Capcom shoves at me)

45093008.review:
Double Gear System is the highlight of MM11, and I want to talk about it:

What I like about the gear system is that the game does NOT force you to use the system to complete, even in Superhero mode. This means that designers can create levels that are difficult by default, and players can utilize the gear system to make challenges manageable. You can totally tackle any stages first by making good use of the gear system to overcome challenges before you get your first special weapon.
I do think introducing power gear right at the start might not be a good idea; speed gear tends to do a better job anyway, not to mention when double shot could punish you with it's knockback. Power gear will shine once you obtain special weapons. Personally, I love the power gear over speed gear; in the past games, usually only 1 special weapon out of 8 has a powered up version, and now all 8 weapons can be powered up without charging! With proper usage of power geared special weapons, you will annihilate enemies and environments in no time!

We will have to see if Double Gear System will only be exclusive to MM11 like Jet Adapter in MM7, but even without it, sliding, charged buster, special weapons, Rush coil/jet, items are at your disposal, so you could totally set your own rules if you wish to play MM11 in classic style.

After clearing the game, I can definitely say that Mega Man, being absent for 8 years, has made a triumph return, and more!
I definitely recommend MM11 to fans of the action-platforming genre.

45091555.review:
I grew up with Mega Man. It's easily my favorite video games series. All things considered, Mega Man 11 is still a Mega Man video game. A very forgettable entry, though.

Pros: Graphics are generally nice(albeit sometimes distracting to the point where you can't see yourself). Better than Mega Man 8 in that regard. 

Cons: Seemingly no real use for Rush Jet other than to accidentally summon it. Too much of the gameplay seems like it requires using the gear system rather than just being optional. When they added the powered up buster MM4 it was great cause you did't *have* to use it to complete a stage. It seems like you absolutely have to use the gears for some parts. I don't think the gears really added anything fun to the game.

Biggest con: The forgettable music. I don't know if it's the mixing or the synths they used for it, but most of the stage music sounds exactly the same and just blends into the background. None of it is memorable which is pretty sad for a game series that has many iconic tunes. 

Over all: They should have stuck with what made the 8-bit Mega Man great: challenges within a simplistic design.

45091448.review:
Pros:
-Good character development
-Good atmosphere
Great 2.5D Artstyle
-Animation was perfect
-Game ran at smooth 60fps
-Double Gear System greatly affects gameplay mechanic such as Powering up Mega Buster/Special Weapon or Control Flow of Time
-Gameplay and level design feels classic Mega Man games 
-Game has several difficulty to choose: Newcomer, Casual, Normal, and Superhero
-Music was excellent
-Game renders with native DirectX 11 API Renderer to leverage CPU cores and threads
-Comes with graphics option such as Resolution, V-Sync On/Off, Anti-Aliasing, Fullscreen, Windowed, Windowed (Borderless) Fullscreen Mode

Cons:
-Capcom implemented Denuvo Anti-Tamper DRM which places great concern to consumers who want to keep their legit copy of their game, otherwise Denuvo Company may go out of business
-Game consumes more than 1.5GB VRAM, so you'll need at least 2GB VRAM to prevent game hitching/stuttering, regardless game resolution.
-Game may require decent CPU to avoid potential frame rate choppiness
-Voice Acting was okay in English, though you can switch between English & Japanese. Not to mention, you can also set Voice Volume down to 0, though character voice dialogue may be bothersome to some audience.
-Game may be hard for the first time, but once you get familiar with stage and boss fight pattern, you can beat the game in no time, especially speedrunners. 

Verdict: I was having a blast with Mega Man 11. Game felt very challenging and it was very fun too. Although it's been 8 years to release new Mega Man game since Mega Man 10, it was well worth it to buy &  play as Blue Bomber again and defeat new robot masters, and of course Dr. Wily. But one important question remains here, is it fun and better than Mighty No. 9? The answer is yes!  Input lag was responsive, game feels classic Mega Man, lots of replay value, outstanding character development, good atmosphere, music was good, good plot, and overall very entertaining and enjoyable. All in all, I highly recommend this game if you love 2.5D Side-Scrolling Action Game.With that being said, Capcom did good job delivering best 2.5D Mega Man game in 2018. Hopefully in the near future, I would like to see Mega Man X9 in either 16-bit/32-bit art-style if the sales are doing well in all four platforms: PC, PS4, Xbox One, and Nintendo Switch.

45081029.review: This is the return Mega Man needed! Modern, responsive, colorful, fun, everything a Mega Man game should be and then some. You'll want to crank the difficulty up because it's easier than some of its predecessors, but not by much. The new 2.5D art style is sleek and responsive, and, in my opinion, adds a lot of life and color. The soundtrack, though some tracks are relatively weak, is strong overall, particularly Fuse Man's stage. 45080861.review:
This game is a pretty severe disappointment. The gameplay has its moments, but these tiny gems of pleasure are overshadowed by a watered-down Mega Man experience.

The music is utterly forgettable. This is a capital sin for any Mega Man game. From the game intro to the individual stages, the music is about as generic as you can get.

The voice acting is a nightmare. I don't play Mega Man for the voice acting or the deep story, but good lord, it is just unpleasant on every level.

The item system (Dr. Light's Lab) completely changes the Mega Man formula, but not in a positive way. No longer do you need to weigh the risk vs reward of attempting to grab difficult-to-reach E Tanks and 1-Ups. You can just stock up on them in the lab. I'm not even sure why the permanent items, like the anti-ice part, have costs, as they are so inexpensive that you will own them all within the first 30 minutes of gameplay, and they actively diminish the gameplay elements of the game. Why have a "slippery ice" mechanic at all when I can just choose not to have to deal with it?

The boss fights look neat, but the bosses themselves and their abilities are underwhelming and confusing. A staple of Mega Man games is figuring out what weapons will be effective against what bosses. From my experience, no weapon is substantially better against bosses than the plain ol' Mega Buster. Heck, no weapon is better period. The cost of using the weapons is so great and their value so little that you will never really find yourself in a situation where you need to switch from the Mega Buster, except just for the sake of mixing up the jump-and-shoot gameplay.

When it comes to the boss fights, they really just boil down to pew-pew-pew-E-Tank-repeat. Since you can stock up on E-Tanks, it's basically impossible to lose a boss fight. If a player wants to challenge themselves then sure, you can choose not to use Dr. Light's lab, but when you have to ignore an entire aspect of the game's design in order to find it enjoyable, then that is bad design.

The 2-gear system is just an all-around oddity. There is no point in using the power gear except to access your special weapons' secondary fire. But since you'll almost always be using the basic Mega Buster, this never really comes into play, leaving 99% of the gear system being used to slow down the innumerable death walls that pop up in almost every stage. Why use the power gear when I can just slow down time and get in twice as many regular shots?

Finally, there is an issue with the Steam version of the game's audio. At least on my system, I am unable to adjust the game's audio via the volume keys on my keyboard. If my computer falls asleep while I have the game paused, the game will be muted until I completely exit and restart. Due to the terrible voice acting and bland soundtrack, I'm actually not sure if this can be considered a negative...

So overall, it is with a heavy heart that I rate this game as Not Recommended.

45079882.review:
A REAL CRITIQUE NOT CLOUDED BY NOSTALGIA(but clouded by other bs)
CURRENT SPEEDRUN (my best) IS 57:37.  That's after 15hours of grinding so I have seen alot of the game already multiple times.

FPS ISSUES
-For completely unknown reasons(though I suspect it could be Denuvo), FPS drops to 45 from 60

SOUNDTRACK CRITIQUE
-The soundtrack feels lifeless and very anime.  If you turn on instrumental version, it gets worse.  The instrumental tracks sound like they were pulled from various visual novels.  I am not kidding.  Wily 1-4 all have the exact same track as well.  Even Mega Man 1 had two separate tracks for the Wily Stages.  Why are we going backward?

VOICE ACTING
-So, Mega Man has grown some balls.  That is nice.  However, the English VA is still pretty bad.  Not Mega Man 8 bad, but it comes close.  The Japanese VA sounds pretty good but again, it now feels like I am playing an anime platformer, not a Mega Man title.

CONTROLS
-So, it usually feels pretty solid, however, I have two issues: Sometimes my inputs are just eaten(usually a jump input).  I am using a mechanical keyboard that has no issues in other titles.
The second issue is global input prevention.  This game DOES NOT allow you to have keystrokes recorded in other applications.  I use WSplit for speedrunning(and yes, global input is turned on).  MM 11 refuses to allow inputs to any other application.  You have to mouse out of the game window.  You also cannot use PrintScreen...

GRAPHICS
-While the Saturday morning anime/cartoon feel is done very very well, it does not feel like we have progressed.  It could jsut be my "old" age, but I would have preferred a 3D art style closer to Mega Man 8(MM11 is very anime already) instead of a age 7-13 anime.  Preference, but doesn't detract from the experience, mostly anyway.

STORY(spoilers)
-The plot device(double gear system) is a pretty shallow of a reason to have conflict.  ALso, this game in no way contributes to the overall plot of the entire Mega Man franchise.  It could have been called something completely different or made as a side title.  Bass, Protoman, hell, even the Rush Jetpack is missing.  No mention of the previous viruses.  No mention of Zero and reploids(such as prototype development of X).  Just feels completely out of place in the timeline.  Oh, and Wily actually jsut leaves at the end of the game.  No capture and in jail.  Just up up and away.  Thanks, Mega Man!

OVERALL
-It is a fun game.  Feels like it should have been priced 14.99 or maybe 19.99.  The boss designs are cool but nor original and all the fights are pretty boring...like, really boring.  All the bosses seem influenced by particular anime archtypes.  Burstman being an obvious doppleganger to Bakuga from Boku no Hero(not kidding at all).  Even some of the sound effects were taken from Boku no Hero(right before Mega Man warps out, you here a little pew pew jingle.  That is the EXACT same sound effect Boku no Hero used for commercial breaks in Season 1 for when the My Hero Academia logo fades in).

It is a nice game - just not a very Mega Man in audio or visuals if compared to others in the franchise.  Maybe this is the direction Capcom chooses to take from here on out.

For the record: my current any% speedrun is 57:37.  I have grinded the game out quite a bit already.

45079792.review:
[h1]==Presentation[/h1]
+A great step into the modern era, coming from the nostalgic NES visuals of Mega Man 9 and 10.
+Models, FX, and backgrounds look amazingly well for a 2.5D platformer.
-Mega Man's animation can look stiff/off at times, notably his iconic walk cycle.
[h1]==Gameplay[/h1]
+Movement and controls is as spot on and precise as ever.
+Special weapons are all viable and varied, including their power gear upgrades.
+The double gear system is seamless, yet not required to complete the game.
+The inclusion of dedicated Rush buttons and right stick weapon selection (for gamepads) is amazing.
+A large variety of optional shop upgrades to lower the difficulty, and can be unequipped at any time.
[h1]==Difficulty[/h1]
+A great selection of difficulty modes, ranging from the aptly named Newcomer mode to Casual/Normal/Superhero (Easy/Normal/Hard).
+Normal presents a notable challenge despite the name. Similar in difficulty as Mega Man 1-3.
-A few abrupt difficulty spikes, notably Torch Man's stage and Wily stage 1 can be daunting.
[h1]==Sound[/h1]
+A great electronic soundtrack, but...
-The soundtrack can feel repetitive with the overuse of synth.
+The instrumental soundtrack (DLC/Pre-order bonus) is also top quality and can be enabled in game, though it only covers the first 8 stages.
+The VO cast is decent this time around, compared to infamous examples in Mega Man 8.
-Cutscene pacing is off, making it uncomfortable at times.
-Unnecessary VO quips in shops, notable when buying items in quick succession.

[h1]==Overall[/h1]
A great next step in the series. Accessible for any players interested into getting into the series.

45078745.review:
A true return to form that manages to be accessible for newcomers, traditionally demanding for veterans, and fresh for both. Effectively the best middleground I could have imagined.

Each world, corridor, and boss is given special detail that tells a story and brings you closer into Mega Man's world more than ever. Let this be a lesson that even budgeted games can be immersive and breathtaking with the right art style to compensate limitations and direction. Just imagine what they can do with a Mega Man X game, or dare I say a new Ghosts 'n Goblins?

Regarding gameplay, weapon switching is a much needed mechanic revitalizing the series, alongside Speed Gear that can actually teach you how to dodge attacks, and Double Gear technique that can save you in a pinch if used correctly (and doesn't feel too overpowered due to the more sophisticated bosses that counteract it) and of course the Gear shop from Mega Man 9 returns. Despite all of this, the game remains challenging (unless you farm for screws and max out E tanks) but never feels unfair. With practice, everything starts to make sense.

The Gear system might seem overwhelming at first, but you'll get used to it in due time, and interesting enough, you don't NEED the system either. There's no pattern that requires the Speed Gear for instance (except one attack in the final boss battle and Impact Man's giant Power Gear attack, I have no idea how to dodge that) and many of the attacks in this game I learned how to naturally bypass by studying their animations during slowdown, which helped me save Double Gear meter when I needed it.

It plays wonderfully, looks great, and feels fresh, but some issues that stood out are:

-  The level design is MOSTLY solid. There's a few bizarre corridors in some worlds that feel pointless, if not redundant. Such as a room almost completely repeated except with an extra enemy or two, or a screen in the later half that features one insignificant enemy you need to climb towards. It just feels like padding, and the last boss battle is exceptionally strange in that regard because you're forced to ride a lengthy floating panel towards the location, with enemies attacking you, but it's actually almost impossible to die because of how few enemies exist on screen, and there's no pits or spikes to instakill you. It's a literal ride for no reason, you can just put your controller down and eventually reach the boss unless one of the minions knocks you off the platform and forces you to jump back on. But before reaching the final boss, there's full replenishes for health and energy, so even if you took slight damage, it didn't matter. The whole thing just felt like a waste of time, it could have just been a single room.

- The music in this game is also... Kind of bad, they're opting for EDM-like tunes and most of the OST just comes off unmemorable, and grating at worse (Bounce Man stage)

I haven't tried the instrumental playlist yet, perhaps it'll be better for a replay.

45075940.review:
The overall presentation resembles [i]Mega Man 8[/i], with its cartoony characters, painterly scenery, and poppy music, but the gameplay and level design harkens back more to the tried-and-true 8-bit era.

Mega Man controls as well as ever, with your standard assortment of abilities, and a few nice quality of life improvements, such as a weapon wheel to quickly swap powers and Rush Coil being made available from the start as a baseline ability. The stages are a healthy mix of old and new, featuring several familiar enemies and obstacles as well as some creative new ones, which bring with them some new mechanics never before seen in [i]Mega Man[/i].

The game's key feature and largest innovation is the Double Gear System, which allows you to temporarily toggle on one of two special modes; Speed Gear slows the world around you, and Power Gear improves your attacks. Overusing the Double Gear will cause Mega Man to overheat, preventing you from using it again until it cools down, which both balances the system and adds a degree of extra tension to gameplay. The system is a perfect fit for [i]Mega Man[/i] and it's hard to imagine not having it in future titles.

There are about a dozen upgrade chips to unlock and purchase, which augment the rest of your arsenal in minor but appreciable ways, such as reducing the recoil of your High Power shot or allowing you to tweak what kinds of items drop most frequently,

The game's story is typical of the Classic series, fun and fairly low stakes, though it does delve into the history of Light and Wily, offering us a never before seen glimpse into their past. While it doesn't do a great deal to propel the narrative forward in the overall timeline, and a few fan favorite characters are missing in action, it does feel like it's laying a new foundation for future stories to be built on.

The art direction is, frankly, phenomenal. While the engine isn't pushing any boundaries, the scenery is gorgeous and resembles the hand-painted backgrounds for [i]Mega Man 8[/i], and the characters have solid models and textures, as well as exceptionally charming animations. And while you may not notice it in the heat of the moment, the attention to detail is extraordinary. The backgrounds are full of unique objects and easter eggs, and the stage enemies are endowed with a great deal of personality thanks to expressive faces and creative death animations.

The soundtrack most resembles that of [i]Mega Man 8[/i]. It's solid and suits the stages well, and there are a few memorable themes, though it unfortunately doesn't come close to the iconic soundtracks of the earliest titles in the franchise. The English voice acting is a marked improvement over nearly all past entries in the franchise, and is actually quite good, with the Robot Masters having enough dialogue to keep things sounding fresh each time you fight them. Japanese voice options are also available, or you can simply mute the voices entirely if you want a more traditional experience.

On Normal Mode the game's length and difficulty is about average for a [i]Mega Man[/i] title, with eight Robot Master stages and four levels set in Wily's Castle. Some post-game unlocks allow you to replay any stage in the game with enhanced abilities, and completing the game also unlocks a large number of challenges with online leaderboards, including time trials, a score attack mode, boss rush, and several minigames, to name a few.

The PC port seems to be solid. It's fairly low spec and runs extremely well. There aren't many video options to toggle (resolution, anti-aliasing, vsync), though it doesn't really seem to need any. It supports xinput controllers (I played using x360ce and a Dual Shock 2) and is [i]almost[/i] fully rebindable.

All told, it's an excellent return to form for the series after being gone for so many years, and for a budget title you can't ask for much more. Though no DLC has been announced as of yet, there are already some systems in place that would support special events or holidays, and I'm sure fans would love for those missing characters to show back up in playable form in the future.

As a longtime [i]Mega Man[/i] fan, I really couldn't recommend it more, and sincerly hope that it performs well enough to get more content and/or a [i]Mega Man 12[/i] headed up by the same team.

45073138.review:
This is arguably one of the more difficult Mega Man games.  You'll really need to rely on the double gear mechanic to get through some of the levels as it's nearly impossible to clear a stage without using it.  I just started playing the game but I suppose repeated farming for bolts will be required to get the E-Tanks and upgrades in order to make the game less frustrating to clear.

Apart from the new Double Gear System Mega Man 11 stuck to its roots and played things safe by retaining the traditional Mega Man tropes: 8 robot masters that recommends to be beaten in a certain order, weapons to obtain, upgrades and items to purchase, and of course the Dr. Wily castle at the end.  As for the storyline it's pretty straightforward where Dr. Wily is upfront in his schemes instead of manipulating someone.  Judging by the flashback scenes I suppose this game would be one step towards ending the Light-Wily feud, or at least move the plot towards the X series.  Nah.

Graphics are pretty beautiful, using 2.5D cel-shaded graphics but overall this is just your traditional NES Mega Man with beefed up graphics.  The best thing I liked is that the game requires less than 2GB of space to download and it runs well on my GTX 750, making it well-optimized even for a potato PC.

If there's a gripe I would have on this game that would be the lack of secrets and branching paths.  There are no collectible letters or armor parts to find, so once you clear a level there's pretty mucn no reason to redux it other than getting the Steam achievements.

If you're a Mega Man fan or a fan of platforming games this is a sure buy.  Not getting this game is like being an anime fanboy on prom night!

45068624.review:
[i](Played through on Superhero Mode)[/i]

Without wasting any time, if you are a Mega Man fan, you probably already have the game. If you haven't played Mega Man before, or aren't certain if you will enjoy it, the selectable difficulty modes really open up the game to first-timers so you can continuously retry without running out of chances, so don't fret.

[h1](Length)[/h1]
The stages are heavily based on the NES styled titles, with large rooms and unique gimmicks. There are 8 Main Stages, 2 Wily Stages, a simple Boss Capsule Refight Stage, and a short ride to the Final Battle. There is no intro stage in this game, which is a minor disappointment. The total amount of content is brisk, so if you know what you are doing, expect to complete the game in a few hours, tops.

The extra modes pad out the content a little, but the entire point of this game is to challenge yourself. You can get a lot of replay value out of trying to play the game without using special weapons or the gear system, essentially replaying the same content with restrictions to unlock achievements or self improvement.

[h1](Balance)[/h1]
There are only two areas I can recall where you get trapped into taking a hit, one in Blastman's stage, and one in Impact Man's. Unless you have foresight, you will likely take a hit there. Thankfully, there is no such forced hit involving instant death. All falling blocks and spikes are clearly telegraphed, and any player skillful enough can feasibly avoid such obstacles without unfair deaths.

E-Tank Spam trivializes a lot of the difficulty on all modes, but especially the easier ones, due to the sheer amount of bolts that drop. E-Tanks only cost 100 bolts a pop, and you can walk out of a stage with 1000+ if you pick up every drop. You simply never run out of these things, which means most of the game can be beaten by standing on top of bosses and tanking the damage while you burn the bosses down, chugging E-Tanks every so often. This is only a problem if you choose to use this form of recovery, though.

Everything felt great playing Buster Only, so if you are interested in a playthrough without powers or special weapons, look forward to an excellent challenge.

[h1](Weapons)[/h1]
The special weapons in this game are easily among the most powerful in a long line of games. They have very generous hitboxes and have enormous utility, making almost all of them a pure upgrade over your default buster. Power Gear toggling just to wipe the screen with overwhelming special weapons feels extremely nice.

In addition, there is a new option to change your special weapons with the right control stick. It has never been easier to utilize these things.


[h1](Soundtrack)[/h1]
Although music is a very subjective thing, I have to say that I found the vast majority of the soundtrack to be utterly forgettable. This is very much a soundtrack made for a newer age, and felt much more modernized than ever before. You won't find the same level of catchy melodies as any of the past Mega Man titles. None of the music is outright bad, but it pains you much moreso when the series is known for such well made music and you end the experience without any of the tunes stuck in your head.


[h1](Final Notes)[/h1]
The game is short and sweet. There are really just 10 meaty stages with a few extra short walks to the final bosses. You will get your money's worth if you decide to try the higher difficulties or want to play the side modes, but they are more of the same. If you enjoy challenging yourself, grab this for sure. If you are more of a "variety" gamer and will only play this once, you might only get 3-5 hours out of it, so do keep that in mind.

If you want to see this series prosper, you really owe it to yourself to support the Blue Bomber so that his games may continue. The sales are essentially votes, so vote with your wallet! 

[b]Welcome back, buddy. MIssed ya.[/b]

I only played for about  a hour which isn't much time. But durning that hour i spent more time watching you tube then i did playing that hour. I'm going to post what i saw.

What i enjoy is the Story, just because it seems soo cheese but something about that seem to fit to me. The models aren't bad either. now to what i didn't like

1. To me the animations are just bad. Walking is strange and MM doesn't even seem to interacte with the ground'. What i mean he seem more like he's flouting then running. Then in a modern't game he doesn't make any sounds when he walks which just adds to my point. Yes in the older game he didn't make sounds but they did in the PS2 games. 
2. The levels kinda suck. I played almost all the games before mega man 9 but for the 4 levles i played all had a active mini boss. This part wasn't what i had a problem with. What i had the problem was with the check point system. All of these levels have no check points before these battles so if you die you will have to go back to the beginning.

45068386.review: This takes me back to a place where the games are great, challenging, had great music, and excellent controls. This is the Mighty No. 9 that we should have gotten with Inafune. And I am very happy to say that this will be an instant classic!

45068274.review:
Sweet, Sweet, Mega Man Goodness. On the PC with great 2.5D Graphics and tight controls, difficult but fun levels and precisely what you'd want out of a Modern Megaman title...

Glorious.

45068152.review: Mega Man 11 plays solid, but I hope jump, climbing stairs, and slide is just a bit faster. Also, when finish climbing stair, it takes a bit longer than before to climb up. It's a little annoying. You can use the right analog to change weapons quickly and that is a BIG plus. The double gear system is fun but Speed Gear (kinda of like Slow Down in Viewtiful Joe) is WAY TOO GOOD. It makes the game easy. I also like the new weapons. They are mostly fun to use and some of the less useful weapons are pretty strong during Power Gear. The levels are longer than previous games. They are mostly well designed, but I am not a fan of the Torch Man stage and Bounce Man stage. All in all, I think MM11 is a good game, but not great. I feel the game is a bit short and the music is really average. Hope Capcom is willing to take more risk making the next game and bring back Proto Man and Bass!

45068041.review: Simplemente FANTASTICO. La jugabilidad bien fluida como debe de ser para un plataformero, escenarios con diseños clasicos traspasados al 3D con graficos hermosos (cuando vi el trailer deseaba que no fuera en 3D y tuviera los graficos 2D como los de shantae half-genie, pero el diseño y el cuidado que tienen los graficos me cerraron la boca), enemigos muy variados, los jefes frustrantes (algunos mas que otros), las habilidades incorporadas (Double Gear) no son precindibles para terminar el juego pero en algunos casos son de gran ayuda y la musica muy buena (algunas piezas son muy pegadizas), aunque en este apartado me esperaba que tuvieran mas influencia con el rock como se sentian en los de NES. La pase de 10, primera partida y en superhero, tengo que decir que algunos niveles/jefes me fueron muy frustrantes pero nunca senti que fueran tan dificiles porque si (es un Mega Man en toda regla). CAPCOM lo hiciste muy bien, el bombardero azul volvio.
